0.description: After being told about Cuetzala by our neighbors three months ago, we go here once a week. Their Carne Asada tacos are nothing short of spectacular. For me, a little cilantro, some diced red onion, a dollop of crema, some of the included avocado. Joy. Every damn time. Pure bliss. It's amazing how different asada tacos at different places can be made, but when the meat is Perfect you know it. At Cuetzala, they always are. Juicy, thick, generous, perfectly seasoned, double wrapped (to prevent TRAVESTY). Yeah, I guess you could say I'm in love!I typically get the 2 taco dinner which comes with awesome rice and beans. Next time I go, I might get 3 tacos Ala carte. Or 4 tacos, or 5....or 6.... Wash it all down with some horchata or a Coke in a glass bottle. WIN. The restaurant itself is very clean, bright, and cheery. Nothing fancy-shmancy... although the beautiful mural on the arched ceiling always makes me smile. Service is outstanding. I've only ever seen two servers there (and that's all they need). Denise is as friendly as the day is long. We went there Christmas eve and I got free atole, free sweet breads, and some free additional horchata for the road. C'mon now, people. Seriously?! I already love you. Whaddya want, a ring? Okay. A ring you shall get. My girlfriend and I have been desperately looking for the Perfect neighborhood taco for years. We've tried *many* places. After finding Cuetzala, our search is over. We've struck the motherload. PS: Free parking in a lot around the back! Don't take our space. =P

38.description: I finally forced myself to sign up for Yelp to review Cuetzala. We frequent this place for breakfast on Saturdays, and it's usually pleasantly empty. I haven't had a less-than-delicious dish yet. Their pico de gallo is the best I've ever had.Staff are lovely and bring us the occasional complimentary avocado and extra limes, and their cinnamon coffee is outstandingly delicious.One added delight: women's restroom (which is spotless, by the bye) looks like an eight-year-old girl's dreamscape exploded gloriously all over the walls. Hot pink paint with sponged-on stars and a framed Pegasus in the corner? I am sold.

51.description: Camarones El Diablo!!  Done.  They will burn your motherf*ckin mouth out, but in the best way possible.  The pain is so good here!

27.description: Always friendly and delicious. Burritos are huge!! Tacos are good. The pastor was seasoned well, the chicken was rather bland.

32.description: I moved away from Rogers Park but still come back to Cuetzala for the great $2 tacos and BYOB. I love the vegetarian tacos with grilled peppers & mushrooms along with avocado  (I got yellow peppers even though the menu says green).

54.description: Great place!  While the decor leaves something to be desired, the place definitely rocks.  Unlimited tortilla chips with salsa, good appetizers, and good entrees.  They definitely leave you full and satisfied.  No alcohol is sold on the premises, but they do have a sign in the window that says "BYOB", so I presume that if you want to have alcoholic beverages, you are welcome to, but you must provide your own.In any case, I highly recommend this place if you're up in Rogers Park.

48.description: The chef is amazing. Delicious carne asada, and very creative ideas in terms of serving.  It costs a bit more than other RP Mexican restaurants, but totally worth it.  The food is always fresh and delicious.

44.description: I'm updating my review because i did return and the service was better. I didn't have to wait a long time for my food and it was again SO delicious. Great prices, too. I actually havent tried any other mexican food since moving from texas (we have the best mexican food there...) but i'm not sure i'll need to go anywhere else. these food is delicious!

24.description: Ordered delivery twice , food is okay , ordered some nachos last time and I was disappointed,  box came with 6 nachos with melted cheese on top with some meat and was on bed of lettuce with side of guac, not mexican nachos in my book... I dont think I will order again , better choices elsewhere

7.description: The carne asada and the horchata were amazing. The tamales nejo tasted like rice cakes and had a strange spicy sauce. I didn't enjoy it much. The guacamole was fresh. Chile relleno was quite good as well. Overall, the carne asada makes this a must try.The enchilada was not great, but the lengua was phenomenal.

49.description: The caldo de siete mares is delicious! The boyfriend and I also ordered the al pastor burrito and the milanesa torta. Both were okay. I liked the soup more. Disclaimer: I always prefer soupy things... and I love, love, love almost every seafood dish.The burrito was good. I thought the torta was too dry, but that's been my experience with almost everything with the milanesa... I may just not be that fond of it.Go get the seafood soup.

40.description: We went in and ate there last week. The waitress brought my girlfriend the wrong thing and the waitress told us we were wrong. Never a sorry of an offer to take it back. The food was great. Tonight we ordered delivery. It took to hours to 2 hours after 3 phone calls to find out where our food was. Once again, no accountability for making us wait that long. We asked for a reduction on the bill and we were offered free Flan. IF THEY MAKE A MISTAKE KNOW THAT IT WILL BE YOUR FAULT.

53.description: I am Mexican and I can be a bit pickier on certain things. I haven't tried anything with beef yet which may change my review. I have had their chicken soup which is truly prepared old-school Mexican style with the big pieces of chicken and huge pieces of veggies so you have to be prepared to take it apart yourself. Their chicken tacos were great although I am not a fan of the double tortilla (in Mexico its used when serving very small tortillas not regular sized ones). i actually like their rice which inmost laces I ignore and their drawback so far is that they are super skimpy on the beans and their 'order' of tacos for almost 8 bucks had only two tacos... that seemed sad to me. No Mexican can call that an 'order' but I guess I will call it a "sad order". Basically they are a bit overpriced for a Mexican joint but the food was tasty and well seasoned and I LOVE that they give you the lime/cilantro/onion mix for the tacos and I like that the lady answers the phone in Spanish :)

30.description: Best damm Mexican joint around. For example,  if you order steak tacos, you actually get slices of skirt steak, not hamburger!!! The most friendly waitress they have is Denisa! She does a great job. Saul and Maria the owners have a real gem!!! Go and try it, you won't be disappointed.

46.description: Steak taco was very good. I was do looking forward to the nachos as the looked so good until I saw the hairs in the nachos. Had to toss them as I know it wasn't my hair.

1.description: With so many Mexican restaurants in Rodger Park, you would think you would have a lot to choose from.  Unfortunately, most of them are sub par.  Not Cuetzala Gro.  Super clean restaurant and fresh delicious food.I ordered shrimp with garlic and the shrimp were fresh and big.  Chips, salsa, and guac all fresh and delicious without being too spicy.  I will be back!

55.description: I love this place.  I usually order from Grubhub and they are always fast and friendly.  Great Nachos Supreme, great Lengua Chimichanga, excellent guac and Caldo de Siete Mares soup.  Oh, and they sprinkle cinnamon on top of their chocolate shakes.  Such a great touch!

9.description: Great Mexican food. The setting is casual and service is is excellent. The carne asada is delicious and cooked to order.

26.description: My favorite Mexican restaurant. Ingredients are always fresh and cooked very well. The food is almost always very tasty. Staff are very nice. There are a lot of Mexican places in Rogers Park, but of the ones I've tried, this is definitely the best. Try the vegetarian burrito, although you won't find it on the menu anymore. It's just stuffed with properly cooked fresh vegetables, red and yellow bell peppers, onions, avocados, mushrooms. The green salsa that comes with the chips is very tasty.

25.description: Love this place.  My wife & I go here once a week for our Mexican fix.  Best Mexican food without going to Pilsen.  Food quality is fantastic & it's very modestly priced.  I always get chicken enchiladas in green salsa but everything is really great.  The wait staff is friendly & service is fast

12.description: This place really is a diamond in the rough.   From the outside it looks like a typical run-of-the-mill cheap Mexican restaurant (i.e.  one of those "El", "La," "Los", or "Las" places).   Actually, from the inside it looks that way as well.However, the food is a step or two above your usual burrito/taco joint.   The fresh chips/salsa they bring to your table is definitely not the jarred nonsense you typically find.   They also make tamales nejoes (pre-hispanic tamales made with ashes and wrapped in banana leaves instead of corn husks) traditionally served with mole verde which are almost impossible to find.

59.description: We just moved from McKinley Park and I must say, we sooo took our authentic Mexican food options for granted! We were sitting here, seriously craving it and said to ourselves, "we're seriously f'd!"I spent over an hour that night looking for a decent Mexican restaurant, with good reviews that delivered in Skokie. Yelp and Google only listed places that didn't deliver or were ridiculously high! So I turned to Grub Hub and this place was listed first, had pretty good reviews, and the best part, they delivered! I had to call to confirm that they delivered because they are some 2+ miles away, pretty unusual but they did!I had the enchiladas w/ red sauce and my fiance had the steak burrito.  The beans, while they look gross are actually really good. The rice is pretty good too.  I also ordered a couple of chicken tacos for my daughter and she liked them alot. Their salsa was very good, both red and green and their tortilla chips are thick and fresh. We will order from here more, not that we have many more options where we live, but so far so good! Delivery was pretty fast and on Grub Gub it said that it was free. However, we didn't get a receipt. I should have called about that so I can't confirm...

21.description: My favorite Chicago Mexican restaurant. My partner & I eat here often. A bit pricier than the surrounding neighborhood taquerias but the quality of the food is excellent. I have never had a bad meal here. A few of my favorites are the fish (tilapia) tacos, the chili relleno tacos and the pollo milanesa dinner. My partner is addicted to the steak tacos. Also, the complimentary chips & salsas (both verde & roja) are delicious...and unlike most places these days, they aren't stingy with them. I LOVE chips & salsa and they keep bringing them.In addition to the food, the restaurant itself is immaculate. The place is CLEAN and you can tell that the owner & staff take great pride in the place. I think the bathroom is one of the cleanest I have ever seen in a restaurant. Finally, I have to give a shout out to Denisa, our favorite server. She is extremely attentive & always has a smile on her face. She made us feel welcome from the moment we first walked in the place.If you are looking for a Mexican spot that outshines all the others in the hood yet won't break the bank, give this place a try. You won't regret it!

17.description: My favorite Mexican restaurant. Ingredients are always fresh and cooked very well. The food is almost always very tasty. Staff are very nice. There are a lot of Mexican places in Rogers Park, but of the ones I've tried, this is definitely the best. Try the vegetarian burrito, although you won't find it on the menu anymore. It's just stuffed with properly cooked fresh vegetables, red and yellow bell peppers, onions, avocados, mushrooms. The green salsa that comes with the chips is very tasty.

10.description: Good daily specials and BYOB

5.description: Great food! Ordered the parrilla special, kinda amazing.  Small place, very clean great staff. Definitely going back, glad I walked in.

3.description: I can't say that this place was memorable.  It wasn't bad..... and it didn't make me puke.  (O:  But I can't say that anything really stood out.  Would I go again?  Well..... if there were not so many choices I'd say yes but the section of Clark just blocks south of this has 20+ very good Mexican places.   The interior has some interesting murals.

35.description: I hate to even give up the secret, but this is the best Mexican food in Rogers Park. Fresh, flavorful, home cooked. Don't tell anyone!

19.description: This is the best Mexican restaurant in Rogers Park.  Its a bit pricy, but people will pay more for food that is better than most. if a restaurant puts in the effort, ill reward it buy paying more. the people are nice, but the delivery driver is a bit unfriendly and kinda weird.

28.description: This place really is a diamond in the rough.   From the outside it looks like a typical run-of-the-mill cheap Mexican restaurant (i.e.  one of those "El", "La," "Los", or "Las" places).   Actually, from the inside it looks that way as well.However, the food is a step or two above your usual burrito/taco joint.   The fresh chips/salsa they bring to your table is definitely not the jarred nonsense you typically find.   They also make tamales nejoes (pre-hispanic tamales made with ashes and wrapped in banana leaves instead of corn husks) traditionally served with mole verde which are almost impossible to find.

45.description: Of the 500 Mexican places on Clark Street in the R.P.  This place is my favorite.  It is always fresh, never greasy,  always high quality meat and it is great service.  I recently discovered you can order for delivery via grub hub.  It is our go to friday night place.  They have some fairly healthy options if you make some small adjustments.  I really love this place.  It is worth the dollar extra you pay for the food as compared to El Famous which used to be my favorite.  It is a cute place to eat at as well.  Very clean

33.description: This is one of our favorite neighborhood go-to's!  Super kid-friendly, free parking in back.  The things I most highly recommend are: 1)TACOS VEGETARIANOS - they're like none I've found anywhere -poblano and yellow peppers, onion and mushroom, all *roasted* (!) and topped with a giant slice of avocado - no skimping here!2)tacos de asada - juicy, delicious strips of steak.  I recommend topping with cilantro and onion and the salsa verde3)caldo de pollo - although I find it inconvenient that it is served (traditionally) with big hunks of vegetables and a full piece of chicken, once all cut up, it is *delicious*!4)mini-taquitos de pollo for our kids - comes with two fried chicken and cheese taquitos and french fries (which we always replace with rice and beans because our kids gobble them up!)A lovely RP family runs this establishment and we feel good supporting their business!

43.description: 3.5 stars, really. I really wanted to love this place. But, everything just seemed good. I was hungry, this place had free delivery via Grubhub and decent enough reviews on Yelp. I pulled the trigger and ordered their Steak Torta, some guac, and a Horchata. Delivery was fast, but the guy who delivered pretended like he didn't know how to work the buzzer so he wouldn't have to figure out how to get to my apartment. It was rainy. I was sitting around in pajamas. I ordered in so I wouldn't have to brave the cold. I pre-tipped 20%. But, the guy refused to work the buzzer (which EVERY OTHER delivery guy has managed to make work), so I had to come outside, hair-a-greasy, PJs a flowing, into the rain to grab my food.Then I attempted to demonstrate how the buzzer worked. I think it was pretty clear that he understood how the buzzer work but just didn't feel like using it. Whatever. Next time they can work the buzzer or refund me my food. Speaking of food, it was pretty good. The guac was fresh and good but not amazing (I would have liked a little more kick). The torta was good and the steak was tasty but, again, not amazing. And the horchata was sweet and cinnamon-y, but again, not amazing.Do you see a theme?So it would be 4 stars for the food, since it was pretty good and the service was fast-- but I docked a star because I have the easiest buzzer system ever and JB Albertos is always willing to bring my food to my door for me.

2.description: These restaurateurs are a step above your average taco/burrito place. Make that TWO steps. Cuetzala Gro seems a bit different each time we visit, yet consistently pleasing.Cuetzala Gro should mot be missed!

18.description: Excellent in every regard. Every plate I have had was awesome. Throw a dart at the menu if you don't know what to get. The camarones diablos and costilla de res are especially great..great to eat in especially with byob..true prize in the neighborhood..

41.description: I tried this place today for lunch (take-out). I had read (elsewhere) someone's review that raved about how good the carnitas are. Since I LOVE carnitas and they tend to be hard to find, I decided to try the place. Only problem was they did NOT have carnitas. Boo. But I tried my second favorite, Chiles Rellenos. It was absolutely out of this world! SO good! The rice and beans that came with it were really light in color, so not your typical rice and beans, but they were delicious. I also got a small order of guac and chips, and for $3.95 it was a great deal. It was really good, the chunks of veggies were large enough to enjoy but not overwhelming in size. So my review is really 4 and a half stars. I just wish they had carnitas. Oh well. I'm definitely going back (and if anyone who reads this wants to share where their favorite carnitas can be found PLEASE leave a comment). Thanks!

52.description: The food is fantastic!  Nothing fancy but what they do they do it well.  When we saw they were homemade tortilla's, that was a great sign it was going to be good.  Plus, they were as nice as could be to us.A little hidden but well worth the find...

50.description: This place features really good, authentic Mexican food! The service was friendly, and they start you off with unlimited chips and two types of salsa. Their serving sizes for the entrees were good- I had huevos con chilaquiles while my SO had chile relleno and vegetable tacos. Don't be turned off by the decor (in my experience sometimes the minimal decor indicates authenticity!) Tons of food only came to $20- the reasonable pricing is very hard to beat!I recommend this place for anyone looking for Mexican food in Evanston.

4.description: This place has pretty fucking great food.There are 3 steps to follow when you go here: 1. Order your food. 2. Eat your food. 3. Go be happy.

6.description: What a great place!Free parking; you don't find that at too many places in Chicago.Amazing murals, good lighting, clean bathrooms, clean tablecloths.Chips were crispy, not salty, greasy, or oily at all. Full flavored salsa, both red and green. They even brought out a second basket of chips after we finished the first one.The guacamole was smooth and flavorful.We had: (1) two chicken tacos that were tasty, full of flavor and not too salty (2) tortas milaneza (one chicken and one beef) were fantastic, good crisp to the crust too. the bread was soft, not dry or too much.Rice was really well done, good taste, not dry or wet, nicely steamed?Beans tasted good, but was a little runny for my liking.Horchata was good, not too sweet, not too much cinnamon.They brought out little bowls of fruit, which was a nice surprise.Service was quick and attentive throughout dinner.I plan to go back to try the enchiladas and tamales with black mole sauce. I'm going to have trouble deciding what to get if I keep going back!

22.description: I will be a returning customer...... The food was amazing! !

15.description: Oh-kay, here I go again. You may think I'm umm Picky.. well, I am!So today we decided to get some good Mexican food to celebrate my partner's return (escape) from the hospital and of course I looked here. [sidebar: you think GRO might have once been 'grocery'??] First thing I noticed.. a not-pleasing smell pervaded the entire restaurant.  I'm very familiar with cooking, grease and other smells (Mom was a waitress..) and this was very off-putting; haven't figured out if it's mothballs or something else you shouldn't smell in any restaurant.It looks cozy, about ten fair-sized tables, salsa (a bit too loud). Had ordered thru GrubHub (wonder if they ever read Yelp reviews..), traffic was not toooo bad; Peter K's 'free parking' must be in the rear, somewhere. No hanging sign, if you blink you'll miss it.Here's the blow-by-blow:Nachos. Or I should properly say "nachos". $7!!! for six or seven tiny pieces of whatever kind of bread base they use, a teensy bit of melted cheese...  OK, so, like WHERE'S THE BEEF? And everything else that I've grown to know and love about nachos?  These are a must-miss.Enchilada dinner (carne asada, mole sauce).  Urp.Corn tortillas: tough.Carne: beefsteak of some kind, non-marinated. Chewy, tough, couple inedible pieces.Mole: now.. I was raised on the South East Side, a melting-pot of cultures. Matter of fact, all my best grammar & highschool buds weren't wedos (white people), their moms could COOK.Cuetzala's mole was.. well, it tasted burnt, tangy, spicy.  That's not what Rosendo's mom's mole was like at all, that was sweet and little tangy, just.  Great arroz con pollo y mole. Man.Quite anemic looking 'spanish? rice' and frijoles; not much of a taste treat there.Some kind of attempt at a salad or veggie toppings and a chunk of aguacate (avocado).That was the best part...(Chicken) Taco Dinner..Fair tacos but they put sauce on that I dint ask for. The rest was a carbon-copy of the enchilada dinner.One carne asada (steak) taco on the side. Same quality as the enchilada.Guacamole: not bad, but too spicy for my partner. Chips? Thin, light, crunchy.Flan (doubt if it's homemade): dint get to try it, my partner Really likes Flan...All this.. for ONLY $37. Wow.Hmm. Revising my rating to One star only, down from two.Go with the guac, but be aware that Jewel has a decent guac as well.Net: -way- overpriced, so-so Mexican food.  There's another place further up ClarkI've been to, hope they're still they're. THEY were fantastic, I just can't remember the name...I think there's a clear divide between those of us familiar with real Mexican food and(pardon me) young urban professionals who ain't.  I think their palates need a considerable amount of further training...But don't take my word for it. Go. Order. Eat. And post, please.Bon appetito.

57.description: This is our first week in this neighborhood, having moved all the way from Devon and Sheridan to Chase and Sheridan.The wife and I decided to make a quick run to the Rogers Park Fruit Market to get Bloody Mary fixings for Sunday brunch and find a local taco joint for a quick bite.Cuetzala Gro was the closest place so we walked in blind (did I mention that we didn't realize that it is Cinco de Mayo?).The first sign that this would be a great meal was the three tables full of CPD.  Truck drivers and cops know where to eat.The red salsa is my ideal.  Nice flavor and a slow heat that makes your head sweat without punishing your tongue or destroying your palate for the rest of the meal.It was busy, and there was only one waitress, but she was working hard and was so pleasant that it wasn't a problem.I wound up forgoing my taco and thinking I would give this place my ultimate acid test (chile rellenos). However, for some strange reason I departed from my normal routine and went for the Shrimp Diablo.  So glad I did.  The shrimp was perfectly cooked and very fresh.  The rice and the salad were great.  I didn't sample the beans but I have heard they are good.  The story is the sauce.  Oh this glorious sauce.  Complex and tasty.  Spicy but not punishing.  Five minutes into the meal I was sweating and loving it.  All I can say is that we will be back.  Soon and often.  Clark street has the best Mexican food in the city and, based on this limited sample, Cuetzala Gro is among the best of the best.

20.description: Went tonight with the folks, brother niece and her boyfriend. Still the best. Great food, great wait staff. They now have a sign on the back door so you can park in the lot for free and walk in.

36.description: Out of the dozens of Mexican joints on Clark, this one is by far the best. The food is always fresh, and I have yet to have a bad dish here. The costillas de res en salsa verde is my fave so far.

14.description: Nice place to stop for a lunch and eat a real soup:). 5 stars because it was exactly as expected: friendly and quick service, clean and bright place, good quality simple Mexican cuisine.

29.description: Go for the friendly atmosphere and nice people.  On the other hand, don't go for the crowded, noisy, cramped nature of the bar itself.

42.description: Go for the clock above the bar and I'll say no more about that.Other than being a neighborhood haunt rife with locals & students, it has little character but a decent pool table. Oh, and no matter how many times you walk in, you are a total stranger to the bar staff. No sweat. It's cheap enough not to be bothersome.

23.description: Looking to get away from your home office?  A place with free wifi, great neighbors gathering, and perhaps a beer instead of a cup of coffee?  Want to BYOF?  Well Cunneen's can take care of you, AND they have paper plates and plastic forks that come with that beer.

47.description: Dive. Dive. Dive. Of the best variety. Up in the RP (Rogers Park), Cuneen's is somewhat of a legend. A Chicago staple, an unsurpassable gem. Sort of. I mean, it's got barca loungers in the front display windows, and it appears that the decor is sealed concretely in 1960's bar garb. Pool tables, a set group of regulars. It's an experience. In a rapidly gentrifying hood, this place might make it...a good stop for a brew after Viet Bistro, Speakeasy Supper Club, etc. And if you get sauced enough...you can go to Deluxe Diner for a greasy plate of beer swaddling breakfast foods. Appreciate it for its dive-quality, and a refusal to ahdere to the yuppie norm. It remains true to itself, and that is half the charm.

8.description: I have really only been here a few times but for the most it's a average dive bar. There is nothing species about there drinks or service. Also bars that do not serve any type of food to me should not exist in today's world of roster ovens. I feel they could do a lot more with what they have. Some effort and better beer selection would be nice.

31.description: One of my favorite bars anywhere. A decent-to-sometimes very good playlist of old music, an unpretentious clientele, homey wooden interiors and nice prices. I have an image of an old, slower Chicago in my head and Cunneens is it. I've had more pleasant conversations with locals here than any other place in my native Lincoln Park.

34.description: I'm giving five stars because for me, Cuneen's really embodies that "pub" feeling. I'm not talking Union Jacks on the walls or even soccer games on the TV or Guinness on tap--I'm talking the chilled out vibes, dim lights, and unimpressed bartenders. I go here once a week with a group of friends and we bring our own peanuts, drink, and have a ball. They also have free wi-fi for customers, if laptops 'n' beer is your thing, and my husband says he is always impressed by the songs playing.

16.description: This place is an acquired taste, but, once acquired, really grows on you. I'll give you an example: Over a year ago, before I was more of a regular, I came in, sat  down at the bar for over 10 minutes, and the bartender never looked up from what he was writing. I suppose I could have said something, but, it was easier to head over to another favorite a couple of blocks away. But, because of the great atmosphere, I gave it another chance, and have actually become somewhat friendly with that same bartender. So, if you like fairly quiet bars built for conversation with friends (and drinking), you're not going to find much better atmosphere in the neighborhood.

13.description: Nice casual clean neighborhood bar.  Had fun earlier in the night with the lady bartender, did not cure for the male bartender, he stiffed me a 10 dollars on change, but he gave it back.  I got the impression he did it on purpose thinking I was too drunk to notice.

11.description: The Reader has the biggest hard-on for this place. I think it's a lot of hullabaloo just for a garish Daley clock and some wood paneling that looks like your uncle's basement (Sidekicks does it better.)  They had decent pitcher prices and I got a Newcastle pitcher for about $12, but was hungry for a bigger selection. Maybe the bartender was having a shitty night--it was a Tuesday. But, she spent the whole night on the other end of the bar and did an actual eye roll and hair flip whenever we tried to order anything.  We tipped decently regardless, but what? She was a couple decades older than us but it oddly transported us back to high school.Maybe this bar is revered by people who don't want to be judged for wearing laundry day clothes.  I say, just own your old navy painters pants and go somewhere else!

39.description: Chill little bar. Good place to knock back a $3 PBR with friends.

37.description: My brother took me here when I was 21 to meet a friend of his that's been a regular for years.  My first foray into the world of "tavern."  It was a cool place.  Not loud, but loud enough.  Met interesting people.  The place is small, so just by being there you're almost inclined to interact with everyone there (a little bit).  The bartender played records behind the bar!  It was kinda like when Boone and Pinto went to Donald Sutherland's place in "Animal House".  Warning: If you're looking to wear an untucked striped shirt and slam Red Bulls and play Golden Tee all night, you'd best go elsewhere.

0.description: Let me tell you something about this place. It's a Pub and it's as real as it gets when you want that Pub feeling.Good feeling all around. I once brought a date here one night and I got to listen to some classic records... yes records. Ol' Boy behind the bar was playing some good stuff too. Nothing like that Vinyl sound. You got a Pool Table there and some Books, Boardgames, awesome tables by the window when available. I can get sentimental about this place... maybe if you decide to go, you might see what I'm talking about.Go! It's good to be thirsty here ;)

38.description: A neighborhood bar that's actually in my neighborhood, but it took me a few months before I actually ended up here with some friends/colleagues as a result of a cocktail-party induced desire to keep drinking.The music sucks, and if it didn't, this place would probably be worth going to more often. This is actually the type of bar that I tend to like the best - a place where you can sit down with your group and not be bothered or thrown up on by anyone else. It seems like the kind of place with a semi-regular clientele, where if you went there more than a few times, the bartenders would likely know your drink order. That probably isn't going to happen with me any time soon, though. Maybe if they had a jukebox (and a better draft beer selection). Then I'd be all about it. After three pitchers, though, I mean, the music (and, frankly, the quality of the beer) becomes a bit less of an issue. BEER LOL

27.description: A great find - my friend Jim lives nearby and we stopped here to check it out for a birthday beer and ended up staying for 5 hours.  Bartenders Janet and John were great.  Awesome ambiance - good lighting, great music.  They have a pool table and offer weekly drink specials.  Dog friendly too (except Thursday nights).  A must go-to place among Chicago's classic bars.

32.description: After a far from warm welcome in the bar at Uncommon Ground, across the street, we headed over to Cuneen's for a first time visit.  Had a terrific evening with our friends - good service, friendly atmosphere, and affordably priced drinks.

44.description: I really like Cunneen's, and I'm eager to experience it now without the smoke.  The service can really be horrid --depending on who is behind the counter.  The blonde woman there most weekend nights goes out of her way to make us feel unwelcome, but we still have a lovely time sitting in the window and enjoying the draft beers and the cozy atmosphere.

24.description: Gotta love this dark dive on Devon.  The drinks are reasonable and the church pew seats give it unique charm.  No matter what day of the week there is a decent set of regulars at the bar or shooting pool.  There is one bartender who isn't quite as nice as the others - and so I refer to her as Salty Sally (don't know her real name).  One downside is that it's cash only, but getting a pint of Sierra Nevada or Berghoff Dark on draft is worth carrying the paper.  And a pizza guy will make his rounds toward the end of the night to offer up hot yet cheap pizza.  The size is just right for the lighting and feeling.  They have free Wifi as well, I believe.  If you're near the Rogers Park/Edgewater area, I definitely recommend grabbing a quick drink with a few friends here.

7.description: Awesome pub! Great ambience, pool table, excellent prices, nice, nice bartender. They do not serve food, but allow delivery from a wide variety of options. 100% recommended :)

40.description: Cuneen's is filled with a cast of characters in the best kind of way.  This is the kind of place for a person who just wants to kick back and unwind from his/her day and get to know some good people.  Don't expect the warm fuzzies from the start, and please don't try too hard.  Just sit down, be polite, order a beer and listen carefully.  You might just fall in love.  Oh, and a little wink goes out to my favorite bartender.  You know who you are.

30.description: A perfectly serviceable, cozy neighborhood bar.

46.description: Ahhhh Cuneen's....I recently discovered this little gem.  If you are looking for a bar to go to and have a crazy night out with your friends, go somewhere else.  Every time I have visited it has been dark, quiet, and pretty much empty.  Decent beer selection, super friendly and talkative bartenders (John is the best).  Overall, a nice little dive that I will return to again.

1.description: best bar in Chicago? I mean, probably.one of the bartenders teaches at Northwestern and from time to time does lectures on the history of Saloon culture in Chicago. PRETTY COOL

9.description: Awesome dive bar! Really laid back atmosphere. Cheap drinks and good people! Chunk it out!

26.description: Great dive! Cheap drinks, good crowd, and tons of places deliver here.This is my go to bar when my wallet isn't as fat as I'd like it to be.

25.description: Cunneen's is a great local dive. It's full of characters. It has wi-fi. The booze is cheap. I like hanging out here. My only problem is that it's cash only, and I don't carry cash that often so I don't often go there. But when I go, I'm always happy I did.

12.description: Cunneen's is the best kind of neighborhood bar, in my opinion. Colleen has been working most nights I've been there, and she's wonderful. I wouldn't necessarily call this place a dive, but it definitely feels untouched by modern entertainment standards, and it's a place I feel at ease and at home..but not at home, which is exactly what I want in my bar.

21.description: This place is an acquired taste, but, once acquired, really grows on you. I'll give you an example: Over a year ago, before I was more of a regular, I came in, sat  down at the bar for over 10 minutes, and the bartender never looked up from what he was writing. I suppose I could have said something, but, it was easier to head over to another favorite a couple of blocks away. But, because of the great atmosphere, I gave it another chance, and have actually become somewhat friendly with that same bartender. So, if you like fairly quiet bars built for conversation with friends (and drinking), you're not going to find much better atmosphere in the neighborhood.

17.description: Amazing atmosphere.Kind and competent bartenders.Wonderful, up-to-date liquor selection as well as a decent, rotating beer selection.VINYL collection behind the bar.  What?!A neighborhood landmark.

10.description: I'm new to Chicago and have only been to Cunneen's once, but I'm in love already. The atmosphere is laid back and homey, and I loved the diverse clientele. The general vibe seemed friendly, but low key, divey, but not dirty. The bar was crowded when I was there, but it never got too loud to hold a conversation with friends. The seats in the window up front also look like a great place to drink and read alone. This place is a bit far north from my neighborhood, but I anticipate making the trip regularly to relax in comfort and enjoy cheap drinks with friends or on my own. TIP: This place is cash only and BYOF. (The taqueria on the corner of Devon and Clark is delicious and cheap.)

5.description: My husband and I just moved to the area and wanted to try this place out because of the good reviews and it's pretty close to our apartment. We walked in and there was a large group of people sitting at a table. We sat down and waited for the bartender. No hello, no anything. We were completely ignored so we left. Probably won't be coming back.

3.description: Real dive bar: cash only; I ordered a cocktail, and the bartender responded with "you don't want me making that...," as patrons looked at me and stealthily shook their heads to advise me not to. PBR and whiskey it is!

35.description: This is a definite neighborhood bar. Strangers welcomed with cheap prices and a welcome atmosphere. Regulars are incorprated early with warm affection. Bartenders vary by shift, no food is served though outside food is welcomed. Cash only and music requests/IPods are accepted. Open @noon. Introdce yourself and relax in your seat. Empty drinks on the rail for refills.

19.description: I love this little corner bar.  Friendly and cool.

28.description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this bar.  It helps for me that it's a half a block from where I work and three blocks from my apartment ("stumblin' distance", if you will) but I would adore it even if that weren't so.John, the bartender (bald guy with an awesome goatee), is great to chat with.  He has a great music collection stashed away over there.  There's nothing like listening to The White Stripes while shooting some pool with your friends.  Good beer too!They have specials that go on during the week days, $1 "snacks" (bags of chips and nuts), and delivery menus available if you want.  The atmosphere is great.  Dark, close-quarters.  The kind of thing you want in a dive bar.  They also have some great board games and good group tables so you can invite your buddies.

45.description: If you want to get drunk for a small amount of money without walking very far or having to worry about too many people or eating any food or dealing with loud music, this is the place.  It is smoky and dive-y and the bartender and patrons are not too nice or too mean.  No frills, though there is a pool table.  Perfect for a stop over on your way to the red line or Andersonville to go somewhere more fun.  Winter months will find me there because it is the closest place to go for me.  Just short of depressing, but doesn't cross the line.  Sometimes that'll do.

33.description: Some of the reviews are so true.  It takes you back to the era of the first Mayor Daley and has that neighborhood bar feel like almost no other.  The bartenders will likely act uninterested in your presence, but if you take the time to stick around they'll warm up.  It's cash only, but really cheap.  You can generally get a shot and a beer for $5.  They also have an interesting selection of beers, some priced higher than others, but still very reasonable compared to most bars.  You should check out this gem if you're in the neighborhood.

43.description: When I moved to Chicago, I had to be introduced to the bar scene.  In some ways, Cunneen's is not part of any "scene."  It's a neighborhood bar, tucked away on the corner of Devon and Newguard that promises a music selection on VINYL and regulated by the bartender.  The prices are totally reasonable for us student-types and it's so rarely crowded that I like hanging out in there.The "regulars" there are neighborhood folk, some of whom have been going there for years--I just heard a story of a woman meeting her husband there--25 years ago! (They were there together).  It's just the kind of scene I like--laid back, space to move and relax, no pretension.I give it five stars really based on my last visit--100% better since the smoking ban.  It's like a different place for the better.  But as Meghan B. said, the bartender really makes the difference.  I concur that the blonde woman can wreck the experience (although last time...she was actually chipper...could it be the smoking change?); every other one I've seen (I think there's 5 total) has been nothing but great.  John's my favorite.If you need a place to go and you just want to chill out...go to Cunneen's.  But not everybody all at once...I'd like to be able to get a comfy seat!

2.description: -Dog friendly -Cash only-Pool tableAwesome bartender, Tommy!  Give this place a shot :)

18.description: Oh god help me, I've moved into an apartment that is a block away from an AWESOME dive bar.Cunneen's is a local treasure. Dimly lit, rarely so packed that you can't get a seat at the bar, free WiFi, a pool table, a great jukebox and bartenders who always remember your name and drink of choice. Not to mention, drinks are on the cheap side of reasonably priced. Plus they carry Rolling Rock. Score!I lurve Cunneen's and suspect it will soon become much like my own livingroom.  =)

41.description: Cuneen's has an extra special quality. I wouldn't call it a dive. It's kind of like the Jimmy's Woodlawn Tap of the North. You are just as likely to run into philosophy grad students discussing Chomsky or Rorty or whoever the heck it is they discuss these days as you are some old dude from the neighborhood talking about his bursitis. Tons of record albums. The kind of place where they keep a dictionary behind the bar next to the baseball bat...just in case.

4.description: Small dive bar with affordable drafts and a clean yet nostalgic vibe. Interior straight out of the 70s/80s one of a style of Chicago neighborhood bar that seems to be ever more elusive these days

6.description: This place is great! Pure dive bar - great neighborhood bar! Pool and good selection of beers. Cash only but it is worth it for the Daley clock. Odd mix of patrons but that is Rogers Park. Awesome bartenders and they pick the music!

22.description: Oh god help me, I've moved into an apartment that is a block away from an AWESOME dive bar.Cunneen's is a local treasure. Dimly lit, rarely so packed that you can't get a seat at the bar, free WiFi, a pool table, a great jukebox and bartenders who always remember your name and drink of choice. Not to mention, drinks are on the cheap side of reasonably priced. Plus they carry Rolling Rock. Score!I lurve Cunneen's and suspect it will soon become much like my own livingroom.  =)

15.description: Not really up my alley. The owner was nice however as she played some vinyl tunes while i watched a bit of the Blackhawks game. Sounds like a lot of people enjoy it here at night...but don't go during the day to watch a game.

20.description: When I walked in, I thought I'd stumbled into the Alibi Room from "Shameless", and I mean that in the greatest way possible. It was a cool DIIIIIIIVE (which oddly enough still has a phone booth!) but then the hipsters came out. oooh, the hipsters. Nothin's worse than hipsters than drunk hipsters at night wearing sunglasses. We had to high tail it out of there after it was taken over but damn, it was worth checking out again!

36.description: spent a night there with my husband where we watched the whole eric clapton tribute concert on PBS with the bartender.  spent a new years there with friends and felt blessed that they are so kind and did not kick us out when one of our party stood on their bar pews.  i love cuneen's because i can walk there from my house, get a berghoff dark for cheap on tap, sit at a church pew and drink, play pool, and sit and read comics while i pee since they are posted on the back of the stall door.  nevermind that the stall door is hitting your knee as you pee.  :)  this place is a clean and friendly dive and a great RP/edgewater place to duck into on a quiet afternoon or night.

14.description: Its a Cozy little place and great serviceThe pool table is a bit cramped up , almost took out a guy's beer mug with my cue !

3.description: A real good and chill spot to meet friends or study.  Drinks are delicious, sandwiches are great too, and worth all the price! I don't get how anyone can rate this place less than five stars.  Shout out to the barista, David! He's a real nice guy and knows his stuff!

1.description: Great ambience. Reminds me of my home in Albuquerque New Mexico. Loved the friendly service from the baristas. Expertly crafted definitely coming back again to get some quality work done!

2.description: Can't believe some as simple as a sandwich can be soooo tasty !! The person behind the counter is always friendly and super nice ! I'll bring my friends and family !!!

5.description: Nice, chill, neighborhood spot.  The service is good and a very clean environment.  I came here to work on my computer and drink some tea.  Definitely will be back!

0.description: This place is so cute.  It's decorated wonderfully.  There is the perfect amount of seating and the music is quite enough that you could have a conversation or study.  I had the Cocolatte and it was spectacular.  My mom finished her Nutella Latte in record time because she didn't want me to ask for a sip. Sooo good.  The food was great too.  Just normal sandwiches, but made really well. The barista was extremely friendly and made us feel right at home.

4.description: Ordered a few sandwiches here and have tried their mango smoothie and Oreo milkshake-all incredibly delicious. The staff there are very friendly and keen on reaching out to the community and foster a communal atmosphere here. It's a cozy place with lots of seating and free wifi. Will definitely keep stopping by here!

1.description: Worst experience ever I took my daughters here on a Saturday morning told them exactly what my daughters wanted and paid for it. One wanted sengelese twist & the other wanted Havana twists. I paid them $380 for both girls. Both girls wanted streaks as well. I was so pissed when I picked my daughter's up. The Havana twist looked more like medium or large sengelese twist & instead of them putting streaks in my other daughters they put a whole section of blond directly in the top of her head. Not to mention their braids started coming down after 2 days. I took my kids back to rectify the problem they fixed the big section of blond but they still didn't use enough glue. I'm constantly fixing braids that I paid to have professionally done. My other daughter still never got the twists that she wanted. They are very unprofessional. My advice to people who wanna get their hair done by these unprofessional people is. You'll be wasting time & money. Check out the photo of my daughter supposedly Havana Twist vs. What they are supposed to look like

0.description: I had a misunderstanding with her while I was getting my hair and I was upset when I left. But a couple days later she called me on the phone because she realized that I was upset. She offered to redo whatever I didn't like. I very much appreciated that. No one has ever offered to do that for me before. I will be going back to her.

attributes.Hair Types Specialized In: African-American Hair, Asian Hair, Curly Hair, Extensions, Kids' Hair

0.description: Very helpful sale rep reasonable price for phone all plans tax n fee included nice no contract yea

3.description: Sorry Qaato but thumbs down for your Ayamashe 01-19-2012. I bought 2 plates of this dish yesterday, one for my co-worker and one for me; but  you guys disappointed me big time. I recommended their special Ayamashe to many Ghanaians but oh Lord! It was so nasty, it tasted bland. Honestly, the dish didn't taste like the good ol dish i'm used to buying. It was not worth the money, i may go there for their Jollof  rice and Okro dishes but not for the Ayamashe. Never again!  My three stars are for Buki's customer service, Buki is the owners daughter; she is very friendly and she makes you want to come back.

1.description: Today our school has an culture event. My African friend brought rices and meat from this restaurant. That is very very very great taste. I will go to this restaurant by myself in future.

2.description: Okay this restaurant has the best Nigerian food in Chicago hands down. The Egusi and pounded yam here is so delicious that it will have you coming back for more. This restaurant passes with flying colors on the food. Why they get 2 stars from me is because they have unbelievably (jaw-dropping) poor customer service. The slim short cashier from the time you enter acts like you are her enemy. She is extremely rude and she acts like she is doing you a favor by serving you food that you are paying her for. When taking your order over the phone, the tone she uses is appalling. When signing the credit card receipt, she roughly throws the pen in your direction and barks sign here. I was so offended by this behavior that I stopped patronizing this place. The food is fantastic no doubt about this but the customer service is too poor and substandard it is a joke to be labelled restaurant. All is not lost, they  should retrain their staff with the realization that they are running a customer pleasing business with customers who can easily patronize other eateries in the neighborhood. In fact they should go to the Jamaican restaurant good to go which is around the corner from them and learn how to treat customers in a friendly pleasant way. Thats where I now buy my dinner.

5.description: Had an excellent lunch there (goat stew of some sort) with very kind service. Will go again.

6.description: Super good.  I have lived in West Africa, and this place knows their egusi (with goat) meal.  Yeah, the decor is not so great, but whatever, if you want awesome West African at a good price, this is the place.  I've even brought friends who've never had West African and they also loved it.

7.description: Yes! I went here for the pepper pot soup because I have a cold. I used to go to a few different Nigerian places on Broadway, Devon, Morse and my all time favorite was a lunch truck downtown. When ordering pepper pot soup I have been refused before because it is too spicy for Americans and I have quite a story about the first time I tried it. Since this is yelp, I will just briefly mention that I started seeing stars and collapsed and went into a hallucinatory state and woke up soaking wet in my own sweat.  I had gotten it for a cold then as well, and perhaps over did it with the loss of sensation after the first bite. Ohh, I feel so good when I eat this soup, I am sure it kills the germs, why else would it clear all traces of congestion so rapidly? Yes you will sweat and your nose will run and you will cough and then waves of warm pleasure will wash over you. The broth also has readily available proteins to manufacture antibodies, after a blissful nap you will awaken feeling so much better. Of course I was so happy to discover Qaato a few blocks from my house. They make the soup to order from scratch so call ahead as it takes at least 45 minutes.  That means you can customize your soup which they did for me. I did ask for very spicy. She seemed amused, I thought I would need to sign a waiver to get the soup but a verbal agreement was all she required that I eat this at my own risk. She doesn't know me. I do miss my old friend on Morse, who made the soup that had me collapsed and hallucinating. This soup wasn't as spicy, but it's understandable, it's not something you want to be handing out to strangers, could be used as a murder weapon.  They also Americanize it a bit, with tons of meat. Next time I will order extra broth, since meat is not appetizing with a cold. I can tell she does what she promises in the menu and selects the finest ingredients for her restaurant. I will enjoy the meat when I get my appetite back. But the broth is lovely with hand picked spices. Now  I am about to savor the last swallow of soup and slip into a hot bath, it is almost a welcome occasion to catch a cold now and then....

0.description: Very good food. I'm a longtime customer but the problem with the restaurant is that the health dept. Is always suspending thier license. They've moved a couple of times and have gotten their license suspended.  Makes ya wonderCustomer service can be better, it's very stressful when placing an order over the phone.  Use fresh meat, not meat that has been frozen for too long.Other than the food is really good, well seasoned and tasty!

4.description: Edited on 10/9, as I recommended the wrong soup on the original review. (You probably want to order the egusi soup and not the ogbono, which has a stringy and slippery consistency that wasn't appetizing for the uninitiated.) Egusi is the way to go, and ewedu is pretty yummy as well.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This place is easy to miss, as it's sandwiched between a few nondescript storefronts on Clark. But it's well worth a stop for flavorful and spicy Nigerian food.I generally stick with the fish soups (stews, really) - egusi, with a rich sauce of ground mango seeds, shrimp, & spinach or greens, is one of the greatest things I've ever tasted. Their 'soups' are eaten with pounded yam or yari - they have several kinds, and will let you sample ones you're curious about.If and only if you have a cold, try the peppersoup. And bring lots of tissues. It's a shallow bowl of insanely spicy broth with fish or meat that will clear you up in no time. There's another similar soup they make a couple days a week, according to a cabby i spoke to there, that's even spicier, also for those with colds only.Not somewhere you want to go for any semblance of atmosphere, and service is slow, but so well worth the wait. And the waitstaff are pleased to answer questions if you're unfamiliar with the cuisine. Dishes are all under $10.

58.description: Sunday brunch is back. Well we never caught it before and tried it out today. For $15 there was two kinds of bread: one which was like cornbread in terms of form and consistency, and the other was injera of course.After that, about nine different dishes ranging from vegetables, grains, legumes, and meat dishes. There is also some green salad offered too. It was nice to try once for the sampling of multiple dishes, but probably for how much we eat (the two of us and our toddler), we'd probably get more value out of ordering off the menu.

56.description: I am in love with Ethiopian Diamond  (both restaurants)! I really wish they would put the Sunday brunch buffet back again! The owner is always so kind and courteous and makes a point to come around and speak to you if you are in her establishment. She makes me feel like family and comfortable every time! :-)

29.description: The best of Chicago's Ethiopian food comes to the North side. The steak tibs and a veggie platter can easily serve a party of 3.  All of which is yummy...I have to pace myself because you could eat non-stop then wind up in some Injera coma.  Slow down, enjoy it, have the coffee service when you're done.

42.description: This location has become my favorite over the original one on Broadway simply because the service is faster and there is ample parking.Have never had a bad meal here and more importantly, the leftovers are just as good the next day unlike some other restaurants we have dined at.  The flavors are amazing but more importantly, the dishes have distinct flavors and not everything is hot, so you don't feel like everything tastes the same.

23.description: Absolutely love this place and love the delicious food. Chicken doro tibs wat (spicy) is my super favorite dish. One dish comes with chicken (meat, sea food whichever you order), a vegetable side dish, salad and injera. One dish is big enough for two people. From the appetizers I like sambusa's (their version of Indian samosas), and Qategna (spicy). The service is decent and they also have live music certain days (weekends). This is a must go place. Also they eat their food with hands (just like south Asians) not with silverware.

47.description: Same top Ethiopian food as the original location, but this one has a buffet on Sundays.  Many vegan items on menu and buffet, and anything veg is cooked in vegetable oil and contain no eggs, butter, milk or honey.

8.description: Food is excellent, but there doesn't seem to be a correlation between how much your order and what appears on the shared plate. We ordered two vegetarian samplers and the food we received was identical to the single vegetarian sampler on our friend's plate. Server assured us that he added twice as much- but I as a grown adult I am pretty adept at evaluating a serving of lentils. C'mon dude. I ended up dropping like $30 dollars for a child's serving of veggies. Server was salty about dividing the bill three ways (there were six of us), then split it up unevenly. All in all- not a good look. Smells great in there though.

31.description: I went here with a large group.  The food was ok and everyone had a good time.  They of course have the injera bread and the usual is to eat with your fingers and share that way.  Our group did prefer to use small plates and be able to cleanly take a portion and then use  fork and/or fingers rather than dipping back into food on the main trays. Just a "western" hygienic preference our group had.They easily accomodated to that.  Service was friendly but given the size of our group and the check, we rarely sa a wit person and had to work to flag them down to order more or get refills on beverages etcStreet parking - can be hard to find.  Bathrooms are bare and not the best.I would not bring "kids" unless they like this cuisine, and even so this is probably not a "kid friendly" place.

34.description: Hmmm. I read the Yelp and we arrived to an empty restaurant. Got seated and noticed it was hot in there. I said something to the server and suddenly I felt air. They had pointed their fan in our direction. Huh. Really one of the hottest days of the year and a woman said their second AC unit was acting up. We asked for and didn't get any menu direction. I mean we were really new at this and the server read the titles of the food but didn't explain them. So that was kinda odd and not helpful. The food was nice and fresh. He got the seafood combo thing and I got the vegetarian combo thing and we enjoyed eating it because we are adventurers. But. The check was around $40 bucks and when we got to thinking about what we got for $40 bucks-like probably 10 dollars worth of actual food items-potatoes/lentils/carrots etc. We were kinda collectively underwhelmed. Bummer.

16.description: So good!  Went here last night with friends.  The food was much fresher than other restaurants with our favorite being the gomen and quota.  Also, their honey wine is some of the best in Chicago!  Please be careful and call ahead... Although is says that they close at 2:00 am, we went on a Saturday night and they closed at 11:00.

13.description: If I could give this place 6 stars I def would. The food is so great and fresh! The injera's have that perfect tanginess and thankfully aren't cold like other Ethopian restaurants in town (it's room temp). The vegetarian options are delicious and can satisfy every palate-- the ones who like the mild spices (try the yellow lentil and potato side) or the ones who like the spicy dishes (the chickpea and the red lentils were my favorite). The desserts are excellent too. Not sure of the name, but they have a pastry that is filled with dry fruits and has the perfect amount of sweetness. You've gotta try this! The food is extremely tasty and I have no complaints here. The one thing that beat the food was the hospitality! I have never been to a restaurant in Chicago that has shown such kindness, thoughtfulness and genuine niceness. We had a baby with us and he was hungry. On our request, the server got us injera's and mild yellow lentils for the baby within 5 minutes of us sitting down. She even suggested what kids usually like on the menu. To top it off, they didn't even charge us for the little fellow's food! She would also take the time to explain our dishes and desserts. I will definitely be back to this place. It exceeded my expectations for sure. I hope more restaurants can learn hospitality from this place.

11.description: Excellent food with live jazz with JB & Friends on the weekend!  We love their energy and knowledge of jazz. They play Easy Living for us...romantic!

39.description: Great food, great service.  I got the mildly spiced chicken and my coworker got one of the beefs.  The food came quickly and the server was spot-on with refills.  I like this place much more than the Ethiopian restaurant in Charlotte.

37.description: My boyfriend and I stopped in for lunch yesterday, and were distressed to discover that there's a $5 fee to share a plate, including the combos that received great reviews here, and that there are specific dishes that are not allowed to be shared. The $5 sharing fee applies if at least 80% of the party hasn't ordered an entree - which means that if there's just two of you, you're going to be paying $5 extra. This unfortunately means that Ethiopian Diamond just isn't an affordable lunch choice.I'm giving 3 stars because the menu looks delicious, and my boyfriend had a previous positive experience, and we're likely to go back.

0.description: I stopped in on 12/14/2015.GREAT SERVICE and the Food was VERY TASTY.Would certainly eat at this location more often if it was a part of United MileagePlus Dining program like the other location is.I believe you just have to go here: rewardsnetwork.comScroll to the bottom of the page.

38.description: Delivery service has crooked drivers.  They charge a higher price.  Then the manager, "Yita" says they are closed and does not let you get your money back.  Complete scam.  Would not give any info on the owner.  Go to addis abeeba, the Abyssinian on broadway or RAS Dashen for honest people who take pride in their product and are honest.

51.description: I usually don't order delivery, but desperate times calls for desperate measures. I had two important final exams coming up, so I sequestered myself in the library for essentially the entire weekend to study. It would've been too much of a hassle to go home and cook, so I decided to get delivery from this place since I had an odd craving for Ethiopian food. The delivery guy was a champ - they said that he would be here at 9:40PM and I got a call from him at that exact minute. I had him deliver to campus, I have shitty phone service that keeps dropping calls, and our campus is huge, so I really appreciated his efforts to find me.Apparently I hadn't thought my choice of cuisine through thoroughly, because I forgot that Ethiopian food is supposed to be eaten with your bare hands. I ended up eating my plate at a table in one of our school cafes, while groups of engineering students shot me weird glances every once in awhile. They were probably thinking, wow final exams must really be getting to her, she has lost all sense of proper etiquette. The food itself was decent. I ordered the Yebeg Alicha, which is some sort of lamb dish that came with a side salad and stewed curry potatoes, with injera. The lamb was supposed to be bone-in, but mine came in boneless cubes, so I'm not sure that I got what I ordered since it didn't match the description on the menu. Overall though I would like to try eating at the establishment itself instead of as delivery - which is not as good because the food has been sitting in a Styrofoam box for 20 minutes already, and because I look awfully strange trying to eat this in public.

27.description: Oh how I love thee Ethiopian Diamond! Food is always fast and fresh.  My only complaint is when it gets smokey during the coffee ceremony, I think.  Makes me run for the hills.  Other than that, just right - especially to go!

32.description: Who can explain the varying reviews for this place?  I can, I can!  There's a pattern here, many of the Yelpers who didn't like it, are actually reviewing Ethiopian food, or the way Ethiopians serve their food, or typical Ethiopian service.  Lots of the Yelpers with good reviews say, like I do, this is the best Ethiopian restaurant in Chicago.  That's saying a lot, because there are quite a few very good Ethiopian restaurants.  All of them are slightly inconsistent in quality. In my experience, they're all kind of funny about how they charge for entrees, splitting up single orders, there's really no way to get a good variety without also ordering more food than you or your group can finish.  You have to embrace eating the way they do, with the right hand, sharing, with too much food. Eating out is celebration, celebration requires sharing and abundance. They like the way they do things, they're not ashamed (unlike a lot of us South Asians, who try to hide from Westerners that we too eat with the right hand) and their ideas about service are a little different than what's common in mainstream American restaurants.  Ethiopians just don't like to rush dinner, and food should be provided in luxurious quantity, there shouldn't be just enough, there should be too much.  They're not really being stingy when they try to discourage two people from sharing a one person meal, it's just not really appropriate from their perspective.       If you already know you like Ethiopian food, it's not just me, you can see here that lots of us think that this is the best Ethiopian cuisine in a town in spite of some serious competition.  If you're not familiar with the food, there's a trick to ordering the food.  Don't try to order a la carte, you want to maximize your choices by getting one of their combination platters, sized for the number of people in your group, the larger the group, the more variety you can get.  You want as many different stews ( something wat) and vegetables (something alecha) as are allowed by the combinations.  The meal then comes out on a large platter, on injera (the spongy bread staple), with more injera stacked up on the side.  The eldest gets to go first.    The injera is your utensil, use only your right fingers, scoop up the food with the injera (like South Asians do with rice, West Africans do with fufu), and push it all into your mouth with your thumb.  It's easier than it sounds, but like everything else, you get better with practice. Once they see that you're trying to do it right, then the waitstaff will be more helpful, but they're not inclined to give a lot of instructions as they don't like to assume total ignorance.  Ethiopians don't like being loud, Americans who are being direct and straightforward can sometimes be seen as confrontational in Ethiopian eyes.  Dignity and mutual respect are very important to them.  The more intrusive, brash waiter-waitress behavior we think of as good service in mainstream American restaurants is a little disrespectful in Ethiopian culture, they show respect by being quiet, low-key, unobtrusive.  You shouldn't misinterpret that to mean that they are disinterested in their customers.  Many of the non-Ethiopian customers are regulars, or already familiar with the way things are done, just like Chinese restaurateurs don't usually give chopstick lessons or coach people how to order rice and an appropriate mix of Chinese dishes.       Try the honey-Tej wine, it's an acquired taste, but it's traditional and I think it balances out the spicy food well.  If you like spicy hot food, tell them, they have a nice red hot sauce that they don't offer usually unless you ask. Finish with coffee, Ethiopian coffee is definitely not to be rushed, smell the aroma first, then sip.  I've found that Ethiopians are almost ritualistic in the way that they enjoy, share and imbibe coffee, it's a special shared event.

54.description: This is one of the best Ethiopian restaurants in the city.  It's family-run and they are so helpful in helping you choose what to eat.  The restaurant and the bathrooms are extremely clean! We are a family with two young children and the atmosphere is very comfortable and contemporary.  We enjoy the live music on Saturdays!

48.description: This place is a must for some seafood..  We be back!

44.description: My first visit to this place was awesome and there on many more.  The food is delicious and staff is awesome. One of the best part going to this place is the experience of communal eating. Food is served in one plate with all options you ordered and you eat as one happy family. They have a lot of vegan items on menu and everything is fantastic. One dish i absolutely love is Red lentils.Highly recommended to go and eat at this place. I had little trouble locating it first time as they dont have a lit up sign.

24.description: Good food, nice atmosphere. Very friendly. Vegetarian daughter loved it, I eat meat and I enjoyed it to!Oh, they had live music! J.B. & Friends Jazz Trio! Nice people! No cover!

7.description: Absolutely love this place and love the delicious food. Chicken doro tibs wat (spicy) is my super favorite dish. One dish comes with chicken (meat, sea food whichever you order), a vegetable side dish, salad and injera. One dish is big enough for two people. From the appetizers I like sambusa's (their version of Indian samosas), and Qategna (spicy). The service is decent and they also have live music certain days (weekends). This is a must go place. Also they eat their food with hands (just like south Asians) not with silverware.

49.description: Hey! Hey!  We have a winnahTook my family here for the oldest's 30th.  The app's were terrific.  For my main course I had beef cut into squares sauteed in garlic and olive oil.  Most excellent!Things wrong:  My son's girlfriend ordered iced tea.  She was brought hot tea.  When it is 90 plus degrees outside this makes a difference.  It took them about a half an hour to bring her iced tea.   hmmm....As I have read, they did not roast the beans at the table.  But the coffee ceremony was very cool.And as always, the martini's were good.  Could have been stronger tho!

40.description: Interesting beer list....very good Ethiopian food.

53.description: UPDATE: The meat quality has drastically improved. Still uses styrofoam, but that's not enough to dock a star.This review is NOT about the total Ethiopian Diamond experience.  Ethiopian Diamond is the BEST Ethiopian place in Chicago and I highly recommend it.This review is only about two things in particular:- The quality of the chicken leaves something to be desired.  The flavor of the sauce in the chicken dishes are all amazing, but the actual meat quality is sub-par.  There is often cartilage and/or the flavor of the actual meat is just "off".  They are obviously not using the best cuts of meat; considering that the dishes are pricey, this is not acceptable.  It's not cheap to eat this food, so the quality should be top-notch.- They use styrofoam for carry-out.  I've suggested plastic or tin to them numerous times, but they keep on using styrofoam.  Why they cannot use recyclable containers is beyond me.  Besides the fact that styrofoam is bad for the environment, it also contaminates the flavor of the food.  By the time you get it home, the bottom layer of injera tastes like styrofoam.  I always immediately transfer the food to a plate when I get it home, to avoid it sitting on the styrofoam for too long, but it still always soaks a little of the styrofoam flavor.I still give all the vegetarian food and in-restaurant dining 5 stars.  Overall, it's still the best Ethiopian food in Chicago, if not some of the best food anywhere.  I still highly recommend Ethiopian Diamond, but I had to comment on these two things because they have become an issue for me.

30.description: One of my 13 year old daughter's favorite places. We just had her birthday party there and the staff was very accommodating. The food was excellent as well and all enjoyed the opportunity for a shared meal. The girls enjoyed that it's OK to eat with your hands. Music on Saturday night makes it even more fun.

46.description: My first visit here was yesterday evening and everything I had was as delicious as the other location on Broadway, where I have dined at least 100 times during the past 5 years.Check out my photo and support this locally-owned business.

1.description: Flipping Fantastic! The food, the service, and the whole experience is first rate. I love the sambusas, yemisir wat (spicy lentils), duba wat (spicy pumpkin stew), and shimbra asa (chickpea dumplings). Super vegetarian friendly, and if you are eating with meat-types and don't want your lentils touching their selections, ask for the veggie dishes to be plated separately, and they will. Excellent service all around. They 100% want you to be happy.Tip: Don't drink a ton of water. The injera (spongy bread) expands on the inside and by the time you get home, you'll feel like you have a basketball in your belly. That's a mistake you only make once. If you are the kind of person who drinks multiple glasses of water with dinner, hold back on the injera.They have a jazz combo on weekends. The music is good and their personality is even better. You feel like you are eating at the home of a musical family. It's BYOB and my only "complaint" would be the $10 corkage fee per bottle. I wish it were lower, even $5 seems more reasonable. If you are bringing a $10-15 bottle of wine, you may as well just order from their bar. If you are fancypants and want your fine vintages, I guess that $10 won't matter.I keep forgetting to buy their berbere spice blend when I'm there. Maybe next time.

55.description: I was introduced to Ethiopian food from a former co-worker in 2003. I have been hooked ever since. The restaurant on broadway was my home. I went so much for carry out and dining that the owners knew me from coming in so much. I was really excited that one opened up in my neighborhood. The food is the best. The flavors are rich and spicy. The service is always so good when I go. I have never had a bad experience here or at the location on broadway. I have been to other Ethiopian restaurants and Ethiopian Diamond is my favorite.

9.description: I've only been here once, so don't take my review too seriously. I ate the dorro wot chicken (I'm sure I spelled that wrong) and drank some kind of African coffee. Both were excellent. The size of the plate could feed two of me. And they were not stingy about the volume of coffee. It was close to 24 ounces, if I remember correctly. My server was really nice, but I can't remember her name.Oh well, take yo ass in here and get some of this good food. It won't cost you that much.

26.description: I've eaten here twice and it's the only place where I've had Ethiopian food because it's halal. Anyway, I think I'm just not crazy about Ethiopian food (I didn't even know what it was like till about a year ago), I just went because my pretty friend gets a craving for it sometimes. I dislike the bread because of it's grey dottish appearance and texture -- to me it looks like a sponge dipped in concrete (before hardening).However, I did enjoy the chicken (doro wat), which they give you plenty of and the lava cake was okay. It is a nice place to have food,  and the people are nice too. If you enjoy Ethiopian food,  you should definitely give this place a try.

25.description: Amazing food. The only reason I didn't give it five stars is that the wait staff is not the friendliest.

12.description: I have been going to Ethiopian Diamond 1 & 2 for years! Best Ethiopian cuisine I have ever eaten. Love the Tibs Watt (spicy) & Doro Tibs. Fresh, delicious Injera. Ask for red lentil as a side. It is wonderful!On Fridays and Saturdays they have live bands. We heard J.B.& Friends Jazz Trio this evening and they were awesome! The band leader James Bottoms is a great guy.Love this place.One of the restaurants I miss most in Chicago!!We visit whenever we are in town.We really need a good Ethiopian restaurant in south Florida!!!!

59.description: I ate here when it was Harambee (spelling?) and was disappointed, so I was apprehensive to try it again, but I love Ethiopian Diamond on Broadway so much that I decided to give this place a try.  My review is based on having it delivered only, I have never eaten at the restaurant so I can't comment on the service.  The food is absolultely delicious.  I was surprised that they give you a veggie side with the meat entree because normally you have to order a meat entree and veggie entree if you want a balanced meal.  I also like the fact that you can order veggies a la carte for about $3 or $4.  That's a great idea and you get enough food with this option that it really could be a whole meal!  Overall, you get a lot of tasty food delivered to your home while it's still hot!

21.description: Have been coming here for years and have never been disappointed. The staff is always friendly and their bartender always gives a friendly pour.  Two of my personal favorites are the rare beef cubes and the chickpea stuffed pastry appetizer.  If you are feeling adventurous try the bit and vegetarian sampler. After a few times you will get a better idea of what you like. Oh, and their homemade hot sauce it a perfect blend of flavor and heat.

17.description: We eat here for lunch or dinner whenever we visit Chicago. In comparison to our favorite Ethiopian restaurant, Ghenet Brooklyn, this place is #2 for great food, fresh injera, and reasonable portions. Their tibs are fantastic, too.

10.description: Simply awful. I went to the restaurant at about 5pm on a Thursday. I ordered take out. Both entrees were incredibly disappointing: tasteless, reheated, old, nearly spoiled. I have eaten food from this restaurant and the one on Broadway regularly for years. Good news: this was the first time I've had such an awful experience. Bad news: management reneged on their promise to refund my money. I get that these can be challenging economic times so management may be tempted to stretch batches of food to make as much money as possible. In this case, the result was more dumpster dive than authentic Ethiopian dining. I can't, in good conscience, recommend this restaurant to any paying customer.

5.description: I had a chance to have Ethiopian food almost after 5 years. This was my first visit to Ethiopian diamond and it was definitely a pleasant one! Food - We got the lentil sambussa, spinach sambussa and also potato and carrot sambussa. For the entree we got Asa wat and vegetarian sampler.
