Saturday morning we walked up from our sessy Super 8 in the mood for some tamales! I'm so glad I found out about this restaurant from Yelp, because these were the best tamales I've ever had. We got the basket of 6 tamales and shared: two chicken with red sauce, two pork with green sauce and two frijoles y queso which turned out to be our favorite from the bunch. The tamale is infused with the amazing jalapeno flavor and the cheese taste was wonderful, too. They were a little spicy but I love hotter food so I can't be very objective. I thought it was interesting that there wasn't any sauce offered on the tables for the tamales, but then I realized that I had just mowed through three of them without needing a drop of sauce. I hate to say it, but usually the tamales I eat in my hometown (Ann Arbor/Ypsilanti) are so dry and tasteless that swimming in sauce is pretty much the only way they'll get down the gullet. Ok, and the flan? AMAZING. Thick as cheesecake and flavored through with the delicious caramel, burnt-sugar taste that all flan should be endowed with... It wasn't eggy or "refrigerator tasting" at all, if you know what I mean. I get a little protective when it comes to flan, because, well, I've had a lot, and this was honestly the best flan we've ever had. Mmmm, Tamales lo Mejor de Guerrero, how I wish I were closer.

46.description: A good place to for tamales.  The price has gone up a bit since the previous reviews to $1.25 a tamale or 10 for $12... it is quite a bargain.  I found the spicy sauce indeed rather spicy and the mild sauce rather flavorful.  When I went all they had was chicken and pork and were sold out of the others types but I am looking forward to going back.   I suggest take-out as the seating area is rather sparse and sterile.  I had some communication difficulties when I went there and hope my next visit will be easier.  A good place to go for a quick and easy tamale fix.

1.description: The tamale was really crumbly and cold. She microwaved the tamales to heat them up. The place was clean but I would not go back there again.

9.description: Tamales and enchiladas are what they're known for, but they also serve menudo and pozole on the weekends.We tried the tamales (pork with red salsa is the best, in our opinion) and the pozoles (red and green), and we loved the pozoles!  But it was our first experience with pozole.  It is a relatively healthy tasting soup with a thin broth (red, green, and white offer different flavors), some shreds of pork, hominy (similar in taste to white rice and soft, but as large as popcorn), and cabbage.  They give you the following fixin's for your own customization: dried oregano, raw onions, limes, red pepper flakes, tostadas, fresh avocados, and chicharrones!  I've never thrown avocado or chicharrones into soup, but they are damn good in a pozole!  Their tamales were large and actually pretty good, but I've tasted better (just wish I knew the name of that place!).  Pozoles are $6/bowl, and tamales are $1.50/each or 6 for $7.  A good sized meal is probably 1 tamale and 1 pozole, which will be $10 after tax and tip.  A small horchata is only $1.50, and it's heavy on the cinnamon - yum!Street parking is easy, and service was great.  We had a really friendly, young waiter (in his 20s, perhaps a son or relative of the owner) who was cracking jokes with us.  We'll definitely be back!(Something kind of funky to note: they charge tip on top of tax!  Sketchy!)

26.description: We first started liking these tamales when they were being sold off a cart  next to the McDonald's parking lot. Unlike McDonald's, they're homemade and thus not always exactly the same day to day, so maybe the couple of people who hated them caught them on a bad day, or got old ones or something. Some days the fillings are spicier, or smokier, or more generous than others. I'm really glad they started offering the Oaxacan tamales. I'll also put in a plug for their pozole. I think it's only served on weekend mornings and probably best ordered to eat there, because they serve it with so many side goodies.

25.description: Im mexican. So im always a bit critical of the mexican food that I buy.  These Tamales are awesum . They are big and tasty for a great price.. I also get the chapmurrado there which is always great. Since I live close to the place .. My family and I go there often and I am never dissapointed. I feel like Im in mexico. The women there are also very polite. So Im am definately a faithful customer

12.description: The best tamales anywhere. Nothing fancy, just great food. Get a mix of a dozen and share with friends. They will thank you. Try the drinks and soups as well. Everything is top notch authentic goodness.

21.description: I am Mexican, and therefore, I know what a tamal (or as Americans call it, tamale) is supposed to taste like.  I ventured in here with my sister on a Wednesday evening.  The place was pretty empty during dinner time. We were welcomed by a lady at the counter, and another one was in the back making tamales.  This is pretty much a basic mom and pop store.  It is a hole in the wall with the menu on the wall and just a very basic layout.  Alas, I was excited about the fact that the main product in this place was tamales.  However, they do offer sides such as rice, beans, enchiladas, and things such as pozole on the weekends.  I proceeded to order a bean and cheese tamal, a chicken with red sauce tamal, and a pork in red sauce tamal (can you tell I enjoy red sauce? :P...) Alas, the tamales were ok.  Nothing bad, nothing good either.  It was just alright.  First of all, I was dissapointed at the fact that the masa part of the tamale was not a little more moist.  Also, places in Mexico with great tamales wrap them in a banana leaf to give them more flavor and moisture.  This place warps them in a corn husk.  Also, the fillings weren't too generous (though this is understandable, as the average tamal price is $1.25 or 6 for $6.00).  The bean and cheese tamal had virtually no cheese in it.  Also, if you plan to eat here, you probably wont get the best service.  Our tameles were served on a super tiny plate, and we didn't even get a cup of ice with our soda.  Also, they didn't give us sauce when we ate them there.  Your best bet (and cheapest one) is to grab an order of 6 to go.  Overall, this is a pretty "meh" place if you're Mexican.  Though for a dollar a tamale, it's not bad.

17.description: I come to this tamale heaven on Clark about three to four times a month. It's close to my house, tasty, and inexpensive. I routinely order the red and green pork tamales. I've laso had the red chicken, green chicken, cheese and jalepeno, cheese and frijoles, pineapple, and strawberry. All are tasty. Today we ordered 6 pork verde, 6 pork roja, and pazole. The pazole is EXCELLENT but only available on the weekends. Get there early. If they run out of your favorite tamales you will feel disappointed and deprived but can always go for your second favorite such asthe chicken roja. We order them by the dozen to freeze for a quick and delicious meal any time.

10.description: How have I not tried this place before?Very simple Menu with special items on the weekend. The tamales are the star here.

5.description: Go early, usually choices are limited after lunch. I order them by the dozen , chicken , pork, bean and cheese. Some for dinner and freeze the rest. Preferably in the green sauce. Family business, making good food at great prices, that everyone will enjoy.

3.description: I love this place. Go there on the weekends to get the Mole or the Pozole. The Mole comes on outrageously tender chicken legs and is accompanied by rice or plain tamales. The red mole is fantastic, and the green mole is tart and spicy and so, so, so good. The Pozole comes with all these fixins. As a gringo, I'm really not sure what I'm SUPPOSED to do, but I have fun experimenting with different levels of oregano, lime juice, onions, and pork rinds (sorry... my computer doesn't know how to spell chicharones)I love the pineapple tamales and the rice con leche for desert. I love it all. AND everyone there is super duper nice.

35.description: I discovered tamales while rooming with Mr. N one summer. The tamale guy (are there more than one?) would come by the bars in Roscoe Village and I would be pretty hungry. They were skinny little things that needed lots of salsa. I wasn't too eager to buy them unless absolutely starving. The second time I came across tamales was at the Abbey Pub stand at Intonation Festival. Theirs was a delicious tamale filled with veggies with a side of spicy salsa to boot. This was when I fell in love. Since then, I pretty much order tamales whenever I see them, which sadly isn't very often. So clearly, when I walked by this place on my way to El Famous Burrito, I made a mental note to come back and try it. A store that ONLY sells tamales? How could I not? Despite consuming too many tacos, we stopped in to get some carry out tamales. They were really cheap (6 tamales for 6 dollars plus tax) and you get them really quickly. There are several varieties (pork - mild or hot, chicken - mild or hot, cheese and bean, cheese and jalapeno, strawberry and pineapple). Ended up picking up all of the savory tamales and ate them a few hours later.The actual masa part of the tamale is great. They're wrapped in corn husks and aren't dry. Yay! As for the fillings, the spicy chicken was delicious - moist dark meat with a fiery red sauce. Both pork tamales were exceptionally salty. I'm not sure if this was a one-time thing, but I'll probably try these again. I don't give up on foods with pork that easily. Both the cheese tamales were good too, but I just really prefer food with heat (i.e. spicy chicken). I will be back. In fact, I'm thinking of going this week. I was kicking myself for not getting the sweet tamales and then read that they taste like Twinkies? I must go back to there. But seriously, I absolutely love places like this. The lady at the counter just looked like she knew what to do in the kitchen and I'm sure there are multiple versions of her making these delectable creations back in the kitchen. That thought makes me happy. Food crafted with care, passion, and know-how = love. And in this case, I love TLMDG!

19.description: Sometimes for breakfast the thought of another McMuffin is just too much too bear. Thankfully in Chiago we have options. Tamels Lo Mejo de Guerrero has a fair variety of tamales for a good price.For breakfast for example, I myself prefer the pineapple or strawberry varieities they have. My friends however are more hard core and go straight away for the green pork or green chicken. Those with a bit more delicate stomaches go for the red.Work has even brought in the other varieites, the bean and cheese for example, and they've all gone quick with no complaints. This seems to be one of the things tamales, like pizza, are great for. A good amount of food for a decent price with some  variety to it.Prices are fair and is a more you buy the more you save.The food, in my experience, which has always been take out mind you, is quickly prepared, and if you call ahead, even quicker, handed off to you as soon as you walk in. The only negative thing I can say is that they need to print up new menus. When I was last there they only had an old one on the table with new prices incicating some changes. Most small, but some, like a side of avacado which used to cost $1 went up to $3.North side inhabitants looking for some tamales freshly made could do far worse then seek out Tamales Lo Mejor de Guerrero.

28.description: For me, and my family, these were the most authentic "streets of Mexico" tamales that we've had in Chicago. It absolutely reminded me of waking up early in Mexico City on Saturdays or Sundays and heading out to the market to pick a few dozen tamales up for breakfast.Inexpensive? You bet... phenomenal pricing. And if you're there on the weekend, make sure to order the Pozole (Mexican soup/stew).Muy, muy bueno.

45.description: While the prices have gone up a tick or two, it's still a tasty spot to stop by and grab a sack for subsequent snacking or Mexi-mealing. The earlier you arrive, the better, as the variety apparently declines as the day proceeds and your fellow tamale junkies clear them out. I'm very fond of the spicy meaty ones, but have nothing but nice things to say about the cheese-, bean-, and pepper-driven alternatives.

33.description: I had been on a quest for good tamales in Chicago. I'd eaten at various restaurants in Pilsen, and wasn't all that pleased. Then, while in a Mexican Culture class at UNAM, I had some delicious tamales. Turns out they were from Tamales lo Mejor de Guerrero. They're so good! I've had the Oaxacenos (which are my favorite) the red tamales, green tamales, and the sweet tamales. All were great. I don't know that I'd order the sweet ones again, but I have and will be back for the others! They freeze really well too! The restaurant atmosphere is nothing special, but I always get mine to go and take them home for dinner.

43.description: I have tried many a tamale in my life and these are the best I have ever had.  I was so excited to know that I could get them at a different time besides 5am by the McDonald's.  I'm not sure if they even do that in the mornings anymore.  Anyway try them if you haven't!  They rock!

2.description: This place has been on my "to go" list for YEARS (sad, I know) and I finally got to go last weekend. I really enjoyed the food. I tried a green tamale, a triangular tamale in mole sauce and the pozole. Everything was really good! It's a really cute place -small and every seat was taken. Mostly Hispanic folks, which is one of my measures of a good Latino restaurant; if locals are eating there, you know the food must be good and authentic! Service was good too. It seemed that there was one waiter working the room but he did a fantastic job getting to everyone and following up in a timely way! We will be back! Nothing like some good pozole on a cold, winter day!

18.description: Ya' know, this north-of-Devon stretch of Clark Street ought to be named as the Latin equivalent of Greek Town.  There are so many places, Mexican, Peruvian, specific spots specializing in tamales, like this place, Quesadillas, Burritos, seafood, Cuban sandwiches at La Unica (OK, so its not on Clark St.). But last weekend, the only time it's served, I came for the Green Pozole, and copped a couple of tamales, too.I had a chicken tamal with red sauce, a pork tamal with green sauce, and the Green Pozole, which had hominy and shredded pork, and was accompanied by onions, large slices of avocado, and pork rinds. Both the tamales and the soup were seasoned for heat as if someone had done a market survey on me personally for flavor and spice. It was just so good, I know that this pozole will be one of my favorite "destination dishes." Especially after the big cold door closes on Chicago in November. I would also love to try and make it, but for $10.00 for a bowl and two tamales, fuggedaboutit! I'm driving up here.I should say, too, the service was very sweet and gracious. It's one of those places where you can take your high school Spanish for a test drive and they will be both appreciative and amused.Oops...almost forgot: get the Orchata ,too!

41.description: I kind of hate to write this review, in part because it was probably an off day or time and also because the lady (owner?) was so delightful and dear - especially after I told her about all the rave reviews on Yelp...However, on this particular day (at 4pm on a weekday afternoon - the place empty) I came home with 12 really really awful tamales (we actually did throw them out - and I never do that! I always try to "doctor" things that need a little help...)We tried 3 different kinds: Chicken, Pork, and Cheese with Beans - all were soggy tasteless disasters. The heavy, flavorless  mesa dough only made the barely detectable, flavorless fillings even worse...Also NO sauces etc were included in the bag (we have them at home so that would have been OK) - if there was anything worth salvaging. Plain and simple: they were simply awful and basically inedible.I can't believe that my fellow Yelpers could be so wrong nor that this sweet lady could be selling such a lousy product - so we will be giving them a second chance. But I just hope this isn't a case where the price might be right - but the food is an egregious failure.

4.description: Amazing authentic tamales! Clean, cozy, comfortable family-run specialty restaurant with sit down or super quick carry out services. Try the homemade green (spicy) and red (mild) salsa for some nice flavor variation.

6.description: All the tamales from here are good ! I was surprised to know that this place sells tamales so close to home instead of having to drive 30 minutes for dry tamales from a cart in Chicago . The green ones are the best .

22.description: You want authentic Mexican street food without all the hype and crazy prices? You want to support a fabulous local mom and pop family business instead of the big chains? You want the best tamales ever?(which is cleverly what the name means?) Read on! While I have lived in Rogers Park for 25 plus years, the tamales have always disappointed me...where were the beans? the fruit? the chicken? THE FRESHNESS????You see, I remember years ago living in Pilsen, and then in Humboldt Park, where there was such an interesting array of street food, especially on weekends and the variety was incredible. Rogers Park just wasn't doing it for me with stale pork only tamales. Yuch!Then, one day we found the women outside the old McDonalds  on Clark and Pratt. I noticed the line was always long, and that they would usually sell out by 6:30 am. Clearly, this was da place. Amazingly FRESH and tasty tamales. with all the variations. We started to go regularly at 5:30 or 6am every Saturday morning. (OK, I'm a weirdo and get up early!). I remember my excitement when they told me they would soon open a store on Clark because then, I would be able to get there and eat at a more reasonable hour. It's been a great couple of years. The also serve 2 hot drinks, champurado, (corn and chocolate)and avena (sweet oatmeal) for breakfast, which is filling and warming especially in winter. These are the Mexican and better versions of Carnation instant breakfast! With all the tamale sampling I am surprised that no one has mentioned the ayacas! They are tamales of a  a different region (Oaxaca) wrapped in banana leaves. They are larger and have mole sauce in the chicken or pork mixture....ohhhhh so good!!Most places do either or, this place has both. They also serve menudo and posole on the weekends with all the trimmings. This place is also friendly and local, and FRESH FRESH FRESH!!!Go try it for yourself.

15.description: The Oaxaqueño tamal is fantastic

20.description: My review isn't so much for the physical restaurant because I've never actually eaten there, but for my birthday my wife ordered a ton of tamales for my party and they were AWESOME.  There were chicken tamales, and pork tamales, and jalapeno and cheese tamales and I went to town.  They were all delicious.Sadly, the leftovers (which froze quite well) have now been consumed.Big fan.  Big, big fan!

36.description: So before heading out of town for the weekend, late last year, i was given a mission. I was told in exchange for having a place to crash I must bring the finest tamales I could find for my hosts. Said hosts had been going through a particular rough case of tamale withdrawal, living in North Central Indiana apparently doesn't help one find quality Mexican food. With a little bit of research under my belt, I ventured on to the El.  After a short and very pleasant walk from the El stop, I found it!There wasn't anyone dining in and the menu was deceptively simple. After a moments study, I stepped up to the counter and asked for two spicy pork tacos.Yeah, the menu has six types of tamales with a few variations and this quarter Mexican asks for tacos and becomes a Mexican't , Mom would be so proud. I sat down with two spicy pork tamales and a side of shame. What I noticed while I sat there was the brisk carryout business. In the ten minutes it took me to enjoy my tamales and ponder my next meal, six people came in and walked out with at least a dozen tamales.  Having fed my own appetite momentarily, I returned to the counter, order three dozen tamales for my friends. Not wanting to leave just quite yet, I decided I better sample two other tamales. These two were just as good as the first pair (even without the side of shame). The masa was a good back drop to the filling. The filling, whether it was pork or chicken,  was just right, in amount and seasoning. My third and final trip to the counter was in the name of science. I choose the two sweet tamales, and once again, I enjoyed every bite. If you or your friends need a tamale fix, head to Tamales Lo Mejor de Guerrero. My hosts had nothing but good things to report back about the tamales I took them.  I felt bad about the scent of 3 dozen, still warm tamales lofting through the air on the El ride home.

14.description: I totally agree with Alex R's review. The tamales were ok for the price, but a tad dry and lacking in filling. The bean and cheese had no cheese and 8 (counted them) beans inside.The pozole was very good and the portion was generous. Lots of chicken and hominy. Yummy.The service was nothing to write home about. We were the only seated customers and got very little attention once the food was delivered to the table.I would come back for the pozole and the tamales as long as I got take out so I could put some sauce on it.  Based on the foot traffic in and out of the place, it seems popular.

0.description: This place reopened a few months back, and some serious changes have been made. Gone is the armored bunker register and "staff only" hard liquor section. Selection has been narrowed way down to beer, hard liquor, and some snacks, which has really helped focus the place. Beer selection is really good if you're looking for mid-range craft brew (Bell's, Lagunitas, etc) with a good selection of local (Badubrau) and out of town (Abita) faves. 6 packs run around 10 bucks. If you're looking for top self, go to Taste, but if mid range or lower is what you crave, this is the spot.

1.description: This was my first time in the store and I was greeted with friendliness and professionalism. I went to this location because they had a hard to find shoe that my son wanted. I called her over the phone,  she confirmed that she had them and held them for me until I got there. She even does special orders and delivery is available!  What shoe store do you know that will deliver your shoes to you?! I liked her customer service so I even ordered a pair of shoes for myself.

0.description: A really great, locally owned business (Athlete's Foot offers franchises) by a really nice woman.  Her prices are great, she's very friendly and helpful.  FYI, the majority of her stock is running shoes, which sets her apart from all the other gym shoe stores around here.  I bought a pair of Asics Evolution 5s for $75, and they are over $105 online.....It's great to be able to patronize a local business and actually still pay a competitive price.

1.description: It's a nice little place. They've applied for a liquor license & plan to sell beer and wine. Hopefully they will! They have a decent selection for the small size of the store. Prices are ok (just like any other little store it's cheaper to go to Dominick's).

0.description: Wonderful little corner store right outside of the Lunt stop.They have so many snacks and other assorted necessities. (There's even a mini deli in the back, with a few meat and cheese options). Their prices are reasonable, and they are friendly.

3.description: I am white and people told me the braids would never hold. But I still wanted them so I  went and got a full head of long braids with extensions, They look fantastic and I get complements virtually every day on how good they look, Bah is super nice. There was absolutely nothing negative I could say, Everything was perfect!

1.description: My braids come out okay. What I don't like about this shop is the owner is pretty rude and don't care about your hair. Her name is Bah. I kept telling not to braid my edges tight and she kept doing it. Then she wanted to talk about me in her language and get an attitude.I don't understand nothing I asked her was difficult but she really got an attitude about it. I won't be going to her again. You are being paid for a service and if you don't like braiding women's hair for a living quit simple! I can tell she hates what she does. Like I told her if any of my edges come out I will be suing her. And it's funny how the next girl who got in her chair told her the same thing about her edges not to be tight...but the owner wanted to Huff and puff about my  request. I will not go to her again!

2.description: I didn't want to give them a five because nobody is perfect. I usually go south to get my hair done but I didn't feel like traveling. I googled shops and came across this one. After reading the reviews I called and she took me right in. I love my hair and the reviews were right on point. The only thing is you have to tell them exactly how you want it. Other than that I am satisfied. The people were nice and welcoming. The shop could use a makeover but hey everything has flaws. I highly recommend this shop if you want great service. They take their time and do a neat job.

0.description: I was here just yesterday and it was a great experience. This was my.first visit but the other 2 women being serviced were regulars. The braids look to great and they actually listened when I asked them not to braid my hairline too tightly. I woke up this morning with no pain at all. The shop is not fancy but it is comfortable and everyone seems to be welcome.to be themselves and relax. I think u have found my person.

4.description: I got some French braids on the sides with Senegalese twists in the middle and they look great. She was very nice and worked very quickly. My only complaint is that we started an hour late but it took less time than I expected.

3.description: I just visited Kreative Soul at its new location in Rogers Park, 7109 N Glenwood in the Artists' District.  It's a great space with funky decorations.  I felt like it's a New York loft in the Village, a true escape!  I bought a beautiful necklace and bracelet.  You really need to set up an appointment for a personal viewing of one of a kind pieces!

1.description: This place has some of the most beautiful and original jewelry I've seen. They're all hand made and not pricey. The owner is friendly and the shop has a cool, hippie atmosphere with a eclectic twist. I am SO glad this shop popped up in my neighborhood.

2.description: LOVE, LOVE, LOVE this place.  I traveled from the burbs to this store at the specific recommendation of a friend.  I was not disappointed.  These are high quality, unique, meaningful pieces.  Just wearing one necklace or pair of earrings elevates your attire to a whole new level.  I went crazy (and over budget) and left with SEVEN PIECES.  I have already signed up for a consultation with Madame Pilar for 2 other pieces that I want her to make.  It is CRAZY to me that I can pick my stone and treatment and have personalized jewelry made.  I love it!  Aside from the self-designed jewelry, her ready to wear pieces that are in the store are also phenomenal.  She makes bags and clothes too!  And teaches you how to head wrap.  Now I will say...the pieces are reasonably priced, but not cheap.  Whatever the cost, it's worth it!  I'll be back here as often as possible.

0.description: I always get compliments whenever I wear Pilar's pieces. They are one of a kind pieces and you will never see yourself. Whenever I visit Kreative Soul I end up buying 2 or more pieces. What a talented artists and warm/friendly person.

29.description: Love this place!  The prices are extremely reasonable and the staff knowledgeable and friendly.  I learn a lot about wine when I go to their tastings- I consider myself to be fairly observant as far a flavors go, but they are able to point out interesting subtle things about their wines and the tastings they put on have taught me a lot about wine and helped me to appreciate and understand what I am tasting.  They have amazing hand made chocolates and various specialty food, some of which is made by people from Roger's Park.  I appreciate their commitment to our community and the charm they add to Jarvis square cannot be measured.  I always meet someone interesting at the tastings they have.  And who has ever heard of a FREE wine tasting?  They are so generous.  I hope everyone goes there because its a great asset to our neighborhood!  Also, I love the couples who own it and think its absolutely heart-warming that they opened a dream place like this and glad they chose my neighborhood to bless with their charming, inspired wine shop.  Hooray for Taste!

42.description: (THIS IS REALLY 4 1/2 stars....why can't we do halves on yelp!!?!)This place is amazing. I wandered in here with my husband after placing an order at Luzzat (you should read that review, too ;) ) and used our 15 minute wait to look around at Taste.The selection is smaller than say, a Binny's, but the staff here are so friendly and love to talk wine and food. They also have a great selection of specialty foods (think imported cheese and meat, jarred fruits and unusual cookies and things). I know I'll be back if for nothing else than my favorite Louisiana beer, Abita!

23.description: Fantastic wine shop! Taste has a great selection of wine, beers and more and the staff is extremely knowledgable. The chesse and meat selection is of stuff you won't find at your local market and possibly even Whole Foods. Also, love Debbies cupcakes that change monthly. Taste is a perfect addition to Jarvis Square

47.description: The wine selection is great and the prices are very reasonable.  The cheese selection isn't that wide but the quality is  much better than anywhere else and the prices are, again, great.  But, my favorite routine is to 1) stop by Taste for a six pack of either a) Sleeman (tasty, tasty Canadian ale) or b) Old Speckled Hen (tasty, tasty English ale) and then 2) take my ale across the street to Luzzat (hole in the wall but heavenly curry house) for a perfect meal.  I can't think of a better way to spend an evening or $20.  If you haven't been over to this area lately (Jarvis El stop aka Jarvis Square), you really need to stop by.  This really is one of the best kept secrets of Chicago.  I just moved to the neighborhood from Wicker Park and, although I'm clearly biased, I have to say that I really, really love my new neighborhood.  Not missing Wicker Park at all.  Taste is the biggest reason why.  Enjoy!

8.description: Taste Food & Wine is an excellent local wine shop, and dare I say destination for alcohol enthusiast! The selection is small compared to most wine shops but it varies all the time and the customer service has always been good when we've gone to load up on the grape drink. Go friday night for a wine tasting then stumble over to jarvis grill or Poutin Stil for another drink or roast beef. The Jarvis Stop Triangle rocks!

31.description: Wonderful place! I stopped by here last night for a free wine tasting. The shop has a great selection of wine from all over including an excellent craft beer section. They have some cheeses, meats, and British candies as well, so that made me very happy. Wonderful service, one of the co-owners was there and very friendly and helpful. If I lived up on the North side this would be my go-to place for wine and beer. Prices were reasonable.

34.description: I absolutely love this place.  You'll find some incredible buys on wines that taste ten-times the price.  Not kidding.  Explore some unknown grapes and be surprised.  Beer selection is amazing also.  I've been studying (drinking too) wines for 25 years from all over the world's wine countries.  This is it.Owners, Steve and his wife, Linda - the best!   Debbie makes incredible delights - chocolates and other sugary delights.   Her hubby Jaimie will turn you onto some amazing wines with an expert opinion.  The other owners are awesome as well.  I fell in love with the place and begged them to hire me!   (But I work corporate, so I couldn't really fulfill that fantasy.)  And if you're not sure about wines - don't worry!  They're so helpful, fully knowledgeable, friendly.  You won't be disappointed - GO THERE. GO NOW.

16.description: Great and extensive selection of craft beers.

13.description: Super friendly staff and a great selection of wines at affordable prices, what more can you ask for? Chocolate that's what. They have that too! Made by one of women in the shop I believe. Stopped when when I was dining at the Indian place across the street, found a nice, light red to accompany my meal. Not really near me, but if I'm in the neighborhood, I'll definitely stop in.

11.description: LOVE TASTE! I am not a huge drinker but I like a good glass of wine now and then. The atmosphere is so chillaxed yet upscale. Clean and well organized. Ans I love that they sell some food items (not their main business I kind of think they do it to also support some local chocolate-makers) the treats are very yummy but they don;t hold a large inventory of treats so go early :) They are very knowledgeable about their spirits and have free tastings i believe 2 days a week (Fridays and Mondays?) Love this place and the restaurant across (Luzzat) and beside them (Grupo di Amici) are very good as well.

39.description: Friendly folks here.  I'm not much of a wine aficionado, but I've poked around their food and beer wares.  One time I got a bought a European-style picnic lunch of bread, salami, cheese, and beer.  The brie was metallic and sticky, but the salami was very good.  They sell Bennison's baguettes here, and as much as I like their pastries, the bread is not my favorite.  Another time I got a Kerrygold Red Leicester cheese, a relative bargain at $5.25.  One of the ladies in the shop remarked that Leicester (UK) was her hometown, and how she thought that it was funny that Kerrygold, an Irish company, produced a cheese named after an English town.Another time I was perusing the beers and got into a discussion with one of the main guys in the shop.  I ended up with a brown ale from Flossmoor Station Brewery, somewhere downstate.  The guy spoke so highly of their IPA that I was inspired to return for it a few weeks later.  He was right--it was very good.  Perhaps not $10-for-a-22-ounce-bottle excellent, but definitely worth trying the one time.  In fact, I may try to visit their brewpub sometime when I'm feeling like a weekend road trip.As others have mentioned, they hold frequent wine tastings and really seem to make an effort to cultivate relationships with their customers.  They are always beyond pleasant, even though I've only visited five or six times.

37.description: CUTE. Nice unique selection -- even had Korean plum wines.

0.description: For me, the key to a good wine shop is the staff.  I generally visit Taste to pick up gifts for hosts before a dinner party, and they have never steered me wrong.  There's a good range of prices and types of wine from all over the world.The tastings are great, too!

38.description: Free tastings on Mondays and Fridays. Friendly staff. Decent prices. What's not to like? Oh wait, how about a full selection of Unibrou beer? Perhaps very good, decently priced wine? Sweeten the deal for ya?A much needed respite from most liquor stores in the rogers park area. And the best part, you walk in thinking your buying one bottle of wine, and walk out with an arm full of groceries, a case of REALLY good beer, and 4 bottles of wine because it all looked so damn good.

51.description: An excellent addition to the neighborhood!This shop has a great selection of wine and beer, cheeses, olives, parma and serrano ham and all that tasty stuff (hence the name, I suppose).  There are some English and Canadian items you can't find elsewhere (they have Sleeman IPA and Chambly... mmmmm).  Eric is very cool and knows the neighborhood well, as he's a local resident.  He's French, too, so you know he's got good baguettes.  They stock Bennison's, probably the best show in town.It's a veritable United Nations in this joint!  I met Jamie today and he's great, too... Being from the UK, he's brought some great items to the neighborhood (Hob Nobs! Branston Pickle! Old Speckled Hen!) that you can't just find anywhere in Chicago! Taste offers Monday and Friday night wine tastings!  Hot vegetable soup was available today and hot chili was on the menu last time I was there... I'm not sure if they serve it every day. For what it's worth, I live in Ukrainian Village and I've been here 5 times in the last 2 months because I've been working with some clients in Rogers Park.  We've got plenty of wine and gourmet stores that are a lot closer but none seem to offer the personality of this great place.

27.description: I'm so glad to see such high ratings for this friendly and cheery neighborhood wine shop.  Their staff is friendly and knowledgable about the wines, although they seem to have more knowledge of the reds than the whites.  In addition, they have creative, fresh baked cupcakes by a local baker everyday--different day, different cupcake. They have free wine tastings every Monday and Friday from 6pm-8pm.  It's a delightful idea for a fun, free date or get together with friends!

32.description: Not only does this place have a nice wine and beer selection but they carry a variety of imported British foods...which makes my husband extremely happy as it's nice for expats like him to find the occasional comforts from home.  The owner is a very nice British lady herself and when my husband goes him always offers him a cup of tea.  It's a great little niche in the RP.

54.description: ***Update 01/03/08*****Now you can find a good selection of cheese, bread (from Benson's), fresh-sealed pasta, cured meats, and homemade soup and sandwiches.  (apparently the chef is from Alsace, btw) Wine tastings are free, range from 3 to 8 selections, and are also held on Fridays from 6-8, which is ideal for a pre-night out drink.Someone is always on hand to answer questions and they'll even look into special ordering for you.************************After months of waiting, Taste is finally open!  And just a 1/2 block from the Jarvis stop on the Red Line!For a small shop, they carry a decent selection of wines spanning the world, as well as price points.  You can spend $6 or $7 for a bottle, or upwards of $20.  Cheese is also for sale, both hard and soft--I was very tempted to buy some Stilton but resisted.  Some take away food (paninis, deli salads, baked goods and the like) are available as are olives, olive oil, bread, and pretty much everything you would need for a last minute wine party.Tastings are going to be on Monday's starting at 6 or 6:30. (I will provide an update regarding the tastings as soon as I go to one)Two issues I have: one, the interior is a bit dark.  It may be nice for a candlelit evening, but on a sunny day, it felt a bit claustrophobic.  Two, I had expected more grocery items, such as Provenance offers.  While they offer enough for an at-home tasting or party, there really isn't enough here to put together a gourmet meal.  I don't mean that they should start carrying lamb and game hens, just ingredients to complement those items.  Maybe this isn't their focus, or maybe it will happen as they grow.  Who knows?Regardless, I look forward to purchasing wine here often--the trips to Evanston have been rather inconvenient.

48.description: I'm really happy this place is here; along with one or two other places, you can now buy a good bottle of wine in Rogers Park.  They do tastings and seem to specialize in small-grower wines; quite a few good Australians to be had.  The paninis and other specialty food items are a plus.

44.description: Popped in here after dinner last night and couldn't have been happier!  They were doing a small free tasting of South African wines, and we got to sample three lovely little numbers, two of which we ended up buying because the flavors were so compelling and the prices so fair.This is a tiny little shop, but with regular tastings, super friendly staff/owners, and the well-chosen offerings, I'm sure we'll be back.

24.description: Since everything is closed on Monday, we decided to head to Taste for their complimentary Monday wine tasting.  I admit, I'm not very familiar with the neighborhood but I was excited to discover such a cute wine shop.As soon as we went in, the gentleman behind the bar got us started trying six wines.  He was very knowledgeable and really took the time to go into detail about each wine.On top of the informative tasting, I was pleasantly surprised to find that they offer an assortment of cheeses to enjoy with your wine order.  They also have a good beer selection.  Everything was so reasonably priced AND they had my beloved Crunchie bar!!!  Taste is the only place I've seen one in the US so it automatically earned a soft spot in my heart.

7.description: This is an excellent wine shop! Even if it is a little small, good things come in small packages! It's the perfect spot if you're looking for something that you've never tried before.The staff is also very cordial and they have a good selection of overseas chocolate. This is the very definition of a hidden gem.

49.description: I stopped by tonight to pick up some wine for a party we're having tomorrow.  We timed our trip tonight to coincide with the free tasting so we could taste before selecting our wines.  All three of the wines we tasted were excellent and very reasonably priced!I'm not much of a wine connoisseur, but I know what I like...I don't remember the second bottle, but we tasted:avilawine.com/content.fs… - Avila Cabernet Sauvignon.  We bought this bottle for our "reasonably priced wine tasting contest" because it was less than $15.  Very good, smooth, does not taste too dry.kenswineguide.com/wine.p… - very good.  drier than the first bottle, but still quite smooth.

40.description: You don't get better than this place.  I am so thankful they've opened up in RoPa.  A fantastic selection that goes above and beyond wine.  The fact they keep bangers, rashers, and black pudding in stock makes me love the place.  The food selection in there, while small, is great and not out of reach.As for the wine, it's damn good.  You can get a $10 bottle and a $50 and both will be awesome.  If you have a question on specific bottle or a general one on wine, the staff are great at helping out without any pretension.  The spirits and beer selection are a little weak but it also isn't exactly their thing, so I forgive them.Overall, when you need a bottle, some cheese, or the makings for a Irish breakfast that won't break your bank, this is the place to go.

53.description: My husband and I went in for a tasting and the place as poppin'.  It was lovely.  Wonderful atmosphere and fantastic selection. Great price points.  Bought some cheese, and was able to pick out a great Malbec.

30.description: This is the epitome of what a neighborhood wine shop should be; quaint, reasonably priced, staffed with friendly knowledgeable people, and fostering their interaction with the community.I guess my only complaint would be the somewhat limited selection, but what are you gonna do? It's not Binny's, its a local shop just down the street, and actually they have a surprisingly diverse selection for such a small place. On my most recent trip I noticed they have significantly increased the beers they stock much to my pleasant surprise. We're not talking 6ers of miller lite in a place like this but Kwak, Fin du Monde, yes please! I'm gonna have to start coming here far more often to get my rare beer fix without having to travel.The staff is really the icing on the cake here, very friendly, very knowledgeable, more than happy to talk wine with you all day. One of the owners in particular - Jamie(?) seems to have tried every wine in the place, I've repeatedly blindly purchased on his recommendations alone and have never been steered wrong.I just wish I drank more wine at home so I had an excuse to go more often!

46.description: I am THRILLED that Taste is right around the corner from my house.  Being a total beer snob these days, these folks really know how to dip into my wallet.  Any store that stocks a full selection of Unibroue bottles (La Fin du Monde, Maudite, Don de Dieu, etc.) and has regular wine tastings is 5 star in my book.  Plus, everyone working here seems to truly love good wine, good food, and good spirits.  A place for the happy drunkard!

1.description: Very quaint neighbor hood wine store. Has unique wine, beer and sparking wines that you can't find at other wine and spirit stores. A few times a week they have wine tastings. Good social gathering place. Staff is very knowledgeable on whats on the shelves.

9.description: Walking in the area with a friend and we stumbled upon Taste...and it was closed. We did a couple of other things and then circled back...open, yes! Nice wine shop in the midst of a few other local establishments. Very cute place, they have cork boards made from old wine corks and I thought that was a pretty good idea, I might steal it (the idea). They have a nice selection of wine and beer, some from local breweries. Definitely worth a stop in. Support local business, buy a bottle or two while you're there! :)

26.description: Walking in the area with a friend and we stumbled upon Taste...and it was closed. We did a couple of other things and then circled back...open, yes! Nice wine shop in the midst of a few other local establishments. Very cute place, they have cork boards made from old wine corks and I thought that was a pretty good idea, I might steal it (the idea). They have a nice selection of wine and beer, some from local breweries. Definitely worth a stop in. Support local business, buy a bottle or two while you're there! :)

25.description: Fantastic wine shop with great buys and wine in all price ranges. We love this place :)

12.description: I'm so glad to see such high ratings for this friendly and cheery neighborhood wine shop.  Their staff is friendly and knowledgable about the wines, although they seem to have more knowledge of the reds than the whites.  In addition, they have creative, fresh baked cupcakes by a local baker everyday--different day, different cupcake. They have free wine tastings every Monday and Friday from 6pm-8pm.  It's a delightful idea for a fun, free date or get together with friends!

21.description: Taste Food & Wine adds a touch of class to Rogers Park.  The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable, it's easy to get to, and the selection of wines is immense!This is a great place to go for free wine tasting Mon & Fri; on average they have about 4 wines to try.  I only wish they'd bring back the Nutella paninis :-(  Other than that, this is a GREAT spot!  Cheers!!

17.description: This is the epitome of what a neighborhood wine shop should be; quaint, reasonably priced, staffed with friendly knowledgeable people, and fostering their interaction with the community.I guess my only complaint would be the somewhat limited selection, but what are you gonna do? It's not Binny's, its a local shop just down the street, and actually they have a surprisingly diverse selection for such a small place. On my most recent trip I noticed they have significantly increased the beers they stock much to my pleasant surprise. We're not talking 6ers of miller lite in a place like this but Kwak, Fin du Monde, yes please! I'm gonna have to start coming here far more often to get my rare beer fix without having to travel.The staff is really the icing on the cake here, very friendly, very knowledgeable, more than happy to talk wine with you all day. One of the owners in particular - Jamie(?) seems to have tried every wine in the place, I've repeatedly blindly purchased on his recommendations alone and have never been steered wrong.I just wish I drank more wine at home so I had an excuse to go more often!

10.description: Great wine suggestions and great prices.  Just a fun place to buy good beverages.

5.description: Well curated wine store, especially given its small size.Wine tastings are, I think twice a week, and headed by a very knowledgeable staff member who pours generously.Prices are reasonable. I enjoy the deli section and the British sweets and talking to the staff. The staff are wonderful people.A gem in the neighbourhood!

3.description: Small with an interesting selection of beer, wine and spirits. I'll be back!!

35.description: This store is such a gem to find in Rogers Park. The people are amazingly friendly and welcoming. The wines and beers and foods are so rich and delicious that it becomes hard to choose what to actually take home. My first visit to the store was at a beer sampling and it was an excellent way to get an idea about the huge amount of variety that the store offers. I hope that Rogers Park will remain home to this business for a long time to come.

19.description: Fantastic wine shop! Taste has a great selection of wine, beers and more and the staff is extremely knowledgable. The chesse and meat selection is of stuff you won't find at your local market and possibly even Whole Foods. Also, love Debbies cupcakes that change monthly. Taste is a perfect addition to Jarvis Square

28.description: Great to have a place like this in the neighborhood.Great selection of wine and friendly helpful staff.Only complaint was we bought a cupcake and it was dry.

45.description: I've meant to go here for so long, honestly I have.  Fortunately, the foreign blond and I ran out of wine one afternoon this past weekend, and I was dispatched to remedy the situation as quickly as possible.So I traveled the few blocks north to Jarvis and, frankly, had a hard time making it out of there. I had a wonderful conversation with the owner (one of the owners?) about some of our favorite wines and ultimately managed to come home with half a dozen very interesting bottles, four of which were in the $10-12 range!The experience was capped off with a selection of very nice cheeses that rounded out our evening nicely.This is a killer addition to Rogers Park.  And isn't it nice to find wine in our neighborhood that doesn't come in idividual paper bags?

33.description: This place is awesome, very european feeling. My friend and I were looking for a place to have a drink and a light snack and we wandered in to this wonderful shop, we each bought a bottle of wine for under 12 dollars and were able to sit and enjoy it at a booth in the place with a nice wedge of cheese and some delicious fennel crackers and after indulged in some beautiful little chocolate treats.  The owners were carving pumpkins outside and it made for a very nice sunday afternoon.

43.description: A lovely little wine shoppe, with a nice spread of moderately-priced wines, some beers and ciders, and various tasty nibblies. (Prosciutto? Roasted figs? Cornichons? Oh my, yes.) The wines themselves don't favor any one geographical location overmuch, and tend to lean towards a pleasantly high quaffability quotient instead of veering towards either pole of self-pickling (musty snobbery on one end, and "get me loaded up on that box o'vino" on the other). It's also a fun regular spot to visit for its Monday and Friday tastings, a reflection of a place where the staff is helpful, engaged, friendly, not pushy, and likes hearing about a fellow wine drinker's explorations of various vintages. In short, another wee wonder in Rogers Park that's delightful for more reasons than its being within walking distance.

2.description: Since everything is closed on Monday, we decided to head to Taste for their complimentary Monday wine tasting.  I admit, I'm not very familiar with the neighborhood but I was excited to discover such a cute wine shop.As soon as we went in, the gentleman behind the bar got us started trying six wines.  He was very knowledgeable and really took the time to go into detail about each wine.On top of the informative tasting, I was pleasantly surprised to find that they offer an assortment of cheeses to enjoy with your wine order.  They also have a good beer selection.  Everything was so reasonably priced AND they had my beloved Crunchie bar!!!  Taste is the only place I've seen one in the US so it automatically earned a soft spot in my heart.

18.description: Went in to get free crunchie bar with yelp check in offer worked no prob even though I couldn't show her the offer as my phone died! Nice lady!

41.description: Adorable, fancy, wonderful selection! I am so happy to have this place in RoPa!  Great selection of wines and very customer service friendly.As soon as my spot opens across the street I have a feeling I may be going there daily for my medicinal shot of wine! HE HE!!!!!!!xoxox

52.description: Finally...I spent months peeking in the windows and when they finally opened I was thrilled. I still am thrilled. Taste has a smallish selection of wines, but they are a good variety of well chosen wines in a reasonable price range. They range from $8 and up.I have bought some great cheeses and they have a few deli selections that look good, but I have not yet tried them.  I have been in at leat once a week since they opened, and have always been treated really well. Super nice folks and I am so happy that I don't have to buy a last minute bottle of mediocre  wine at Dominicks anymore or trudge all the way to Andersonville. I do love my neighborhood.

50.description: What do you get when a bunch of Europeans invade Rogers Park and open a wine and gourmet food shop?  Answer: Taste..This cute little wine and food shop is in an unexpected area.Wine-wise, they have a pretty decent selection of inexpensive wines.  (walked out with several sub-$10 bottles that were quite good).  Fancy deli meats.  Cheeses.   Bennison's baguettes.  English and other European specialty food items.They have an eating area as well for you to enjoy your food on the spot if you want... Apparently they have good chili and corn bread they serve.They frequently host wine tastings... (like. almost every weeknight I think?).... And they have various other events.It's also right next to the Jarvis Red line if you're nearby the red line.

4.description: Taste is the best! Great wine selection, knowledgeable staff, and complimentary wine tastings on Mondays and Fridays! Love it!

6.description: Friendly folks here.  I'm not much of a wine aficionado, but I've poked around their food and beer wares.  One time I got a bought a European-style picnic lunch of bread, salami, cheese, and beer.  The brie was metallic and sticky, but the salami was very good.  They sell Bennison's baguettes here, and as much as I like their pastries, the bread is not my favorite.  Another time I got a Kerrygold Red Leicester cheese, a relative bargain at $5.25.  One of the ladies in the shop remarked that Leicester (UK) was her hometown, and how she thought that it was funny that Kerrygold, an Irish company, produced a cheese named after an English town.Another time I was perusing the beers and got into a discussion with one of the main guys in the shop.  I ended up with a brown ale from Flossmoor Station Brewery, somewhere downstate.  The guy spoke so highly of their IPA that I was inspired to return for it a few weeks later.  He was right--it was very good.  Perhaps not $10-for-a-22-ounce-bottle excellent, but definitely worth trying the one time.  In fact, I may try to visit their brewpub sometime when I'm feeling like a weekend road trip.As others have mentioned, they hold frequent wine tastings and really seem to make an effort to cultivate relationships with their customers.  They are always beyond pleasant, even though I've only visited five or six times.

22.description: Great neighborhood place. Always stocked with a wide variety of wine, beer and other spirits. The staff if very helpful but never overbearing. Their recent addition of local craft beers has us coming back even more often than before. The wine tastings are great- always with a selection of wines from around the globe and very friendly and educated staff (the blonde whose name I can't remember is excellent!!) Oh- and did I mention that their cupcakes are great too? The frequent buyer program gets you a gift certificate after so many purchases too- always a bonus!! Definitely a great place. Very happy to live nearby!

15.description: Wonderful place! I stopped by here last night for a free wine tasting. The shop has a great selection of wine from all over including an excellent craft beer section. They have some cheeses, meats, and British candies as well, so that made me very happy. Wonderful service, one of the co-owners was there and very friendly and helpful. If I lived up on the North side this would be my go-to place for wine and beer. Prices were reasonable.

20.description: I'm giving Taste 5 stars for so many reasons!  Let's begin. Great selection of wines with a good variety.  Everything is reasonably priced.  I'm more of a high-end beer lover and they always have something I want or want to try.  Also, they have a beer of the month club.  They support the local community and local art community (I've purchased a couple lovely wine bags as gifts from a local artist here).  As a resident of Rogers Park, I really like to see that.  We need more businesses like this.  The staff is really helpful and always nice.  And last but nowhere near the least, the owner (I believe) makes these yummy handmade chocolates that are amazing.  Every time there is a new one, I have a little ritual to taste it.  I highly recommend this little establishment.

36.description: You know that saying "It's small but packs a punch", Taste located across from Luzzat (best Indian anywhere), was just a surprise as Luzzat! It is a very small shop but has all kinds of things and a great wine selection. With wine tasting every single day and over 75 different wines from all regions you will always find the perfect bottle! Pricing ranges from $8 to $50. Not a wine person check out their selection of imported beers. Not as diverse but still a nice selection. I recommend trying the Unibroue Trois Pistoles - Canada or Boddingtons - England. Not a beer person either well they do have gin & vodka (USA only) or maybe a dessert wine. What?!? You don't want anything to drink at well fine then you should check out their Meat and Cheese Deli (didn't see that coming did you). I can't even begin to tell you all that they have in here, Italian Mountain with Truffle cheese, canned Tuna from Spain, pastas, and Irish bangers & BACON!! But wait there is more!! Teas, condiments, Truffle oil, chips/crackers, and regular (imports that is) beverages. Almost forgot the sweets, cookies, cupcakes, and all kinds of candies. See what did I tell you, quite a surprise. If you're a wine lover I suggest checking out their wine-of-the-month club. $35 a month for 2 bottles isn't to bad deal. I say pick up a bottle or two and head over to Luzzat.

14.description: You know that saying "It's small but packs a punch", Taste located across from Luzzat (best Indian anywhere), was just a surprise as Luzzat! It is a very small shop but has all kinds of things and a great wine selection. With wine tasting every single day and over 75 different wines from all regions you will always find the perfect bottle! Pricing ranges from $8 to $50. Not a wine person check out their selection of imported beers. Not as diverse but still a nice selection. I recommend trying the Unibroue Trois Pistoles - Canada or Boddingtons - England. Not a beer person either well they do have gin & vodka (USA only) or maybe a dessert wine. What?!? You don't want anything to drink at well fine then you should check out their Meat and Cheese Deli (didn't see that coming did you). I can't even begin to tell you all that they have in here, Italian Mountain with Truffle cheese, canned Tuna from Spain, pastas, and Irish bangers & BACON!! But wait there is more!! Teas, condiments, Truffle oil, chips/crackers, and regular (imports that is) beverages. Almost forgot the sweets, cookies, cupcakes, and all kinds of candies. See what did I tell you, quite a surprise. If you're a wine lover I suggest checking out their wine-of-the-month club. $35 a month for 2 bottles isn't to bad deal. I say pick up a bottle or two and head over to Luzzat.

3.description: They have an amazing selection of craft beer and decent whiskey too. They're incredibly nice and you can request anything they don't have and he'll get it for you! 6-packs are a bit pricey ($10.99) but not bad at all. And where else would I find my favorite obscure watermelon beer? Amazing!

1.description: So happened to be in the area looking for a place to buy drinks for a party and stumbled across this place.   First off, love the name.  However you'll find more than beer and wine there.  They have a pretty top notch liquor selection and if you're a bourbon or tequila lover then you certainly won't be disappointed.  The store is relatively new, very clean, very bright and the staff is friendly.  There's even a list by the counter where they're taking customer suggestions.  I'll pretend as though I didn't see some dorks request for bacon flavored vodka...All and all a good experience and the prices are pretty solid as well.  Some things better than others.  I'll be back for sure.

2.description: Great place, great selection and they deliver! I was really impressed and they are very friendly.

5.description: Best liquor store for the Rogers Park Sheridan Road set. Fantastic beer selection, and a more than respectable choice of Scotch whiskys to keep one occupied. Customer service is great, and they'll take suggestions for items they don't have that you may want.

6.description: I am so excited this place opened around the corner from me. It's great.  There is a huge selection of beer and wine. I was really impressed with the beer selection. They have a ton of craft beers, as well as the regular brews. The best part is they let you mix and match your own six packs from a cooler with single craft beers.

7.description: Finally a clean, well merchandised wine store that has a great selection and genuine, thoughtful customer service.

0.description: Excellent selection of craft beer. The wide variety of wine would benefit from having the kind of reviews that some other purveyors offer...but the staff is great. So happy they are here!

4.description: Pros:Great craft beer selection--best in Rogers Park by far. They frequently get their hands on hard-to-find beers that almost no one else has (for example, a few months ago they had Dark Horse Plead the 5th in stock for a couple of *weeks*). And they are pretty good about updating their current inventory on Beer Menus, which is very helpful for those of us chasing our white whale craft beers around town.Their prices on beer are quite fair, and occasionally a great deal (for example, they sell Off Color Apex Predator for $7.99).Most of their extensive beer stock is already refrigerated.The staff is friendly, polite, and helpful.Cons:Several times I have cracked open a popular craft beer that was purchased from here only to realize that the beer is well past the printed "Enjoy by" date. I guess I need to do a better job of making sure to check the date before purchasing--Caveat Emptor, after all--but this can be annoying, and it seems a little disrespectful of their craft beer customers (for whom quality is kinda important).The store reeks of what I believe is incense. It's strong--so strong that the plastic bags that they put your beer in reeks of the perfume smell when you get home. I honestly can't comprehend why a store that sells everything in bottles and cans would need incense. Overall:If Hops and Grapes would make sure that all the beer they sell is fresh--and also get rid of the incense--I would gladly give the store a 5 star rating.

1.description: Take you back  in time.if you like unique  and strange  things.this is the place.Really nice it's a different  world once you come and visit shopping  is amazing!

9.description: Lost Eras must have lost their minds. I should have known better when I bought a wig that was clearly marked $16.99 on the mannequin and the price was instantly marked up to $20 at the register. We protested the instant mark up but their explanation was "oh.. yea. that price is wrong"When we returned our costumes, which were stained and definitely not the cleanest when we borrowed them, they charged us an extra $5 cleaning fee for each item. Are you kidding? We are talking about dingy, used clothes here. The stains were definitely there before we rented them and we had no way to argue against their "photographic" memory. Even if they weren't, who cares the clothes are so dirty how could anyone tell. And shouldn't they be washing the clothes every time someone rents anyway? shady.Save your money and go to Goodwill where you can buy vinage clothing and actually keep them. $20 is way too much to rent clothes and then be charged a $5 fee on top of that.

23.description: This place is total bad ass! Check out the basement! (if you don't get too scared) You can dig for days.Costumes are great and Charlotte the owner is very helpful. I go there and rent a lot of things for our photoshoots and she has always been very helpful. Some things are a bit pricey but they price isn't set in stone.Just ask the staff.oxooxox

5.description: I have lived in the area for years on years, but I have never stopped in. I was talking a walk once with a friend, and we wanted to stop in. And wow, this place is truly  a hidden gem. You could spend hours on hours in this store looking at costumes and antique items. My favorite is the jewelry. One of the managers told me that a lot of it is old because they get it from estate sales. Even I can tell by the quality and design that they are a bit older. My friend got a beautiful, layered pearl necklace. I got one of those 90s beaded bracelets and necklaces. The jewelry itself has a great variety. Not cheap- but it is quality. I will definetely be returning once I save up a bit more. Go with a friend and just explore :) We were there for about an our and still did not see the entire place. There is a basement FYI. Cannot wait to go back soon.

25.description: I never seem to wake up in the morning and say "I'm going to go to Lost Eras," but sometimes, on Saturday afternoons I sorta just end up there.  The place is crammed to the gills with antiques, costumes and old shit that you'll never use, but want none the less.Last time I was there, they had a CD rack full of 90's alternative rock.Be sure to head down to the basement.  If you can, be sure to be on some heavy psychedelics, because the floors and ceilings are uneven and I'm sure that would be sorta trippy.  Speaking of ceilings, if you're tall, watch your head down there.Basically, everything is over priced, but don't be afraid to haggle.  They will work with you.  Especially if you actually know how to haggle.  I've never paid asking price there.An added bonus is that if you're there on a Saturday afternoon, sometimes you'll hear a stoner rock band practice upstairs.

12.description: I went there for Tea Cups and walked out with a lot than just a couple tea cups. They have just about anything you could think of!

21.description: Man, the only time I DON'T go in there is on Halloween.  The best reason to shop at secondhand stores is to feel like you've found lost treasure, something no one else in the world knows exists.  Around Halloween, it's messy, crowded, and with one register, it's no fun.  Plus, the owners are VERY comfortable with haggling, but around Halloween, it's just too crazy.  The first floor is an overwhelming array of furniture, costume jewelry, houseware and costumes.  For the most part, skip that stuff, unless you are really dying for a vintage armoire.  The store has been in the family for something like 50 years, and they really don't know what's there.The secret to this place is...The basement.  I'm not even going to talk about it.  But the basement is the best undiscovered thrift store in Chicago.  Don't go alone; it is incredibly creepy, but come to Rogers Park JUST to check out the weirdest fucking basement you have ever seen.  And don't be a sissy--haggle.

16.description: Eleven months out of the year, this is a dumpy junk shop.  I walk past here sometimes on my way to the Howard CTA station, and I almost never see anyone inside.However, during October, it becomes a treasure trove of costumes, props, and accessories.  Selection dries up pretty severely as Halloween approaches, so shop early and take advantage of their "reserve" policy to hold your costume until the needed time.In 2005, I completed a classy modern-day Satan costume with a red-satin-lined cloak which was surprisingly high-quality and less filthy than it could have been (this passes for a compliment).  Halloween 2006 was brilliant thanks in large part to a last-minute costume that I cobbled together at Lost Eras--a Highland warrior with kilt, sash, boots, sword, etc.  Apparently many, many women want to ask what is under a man's kilt.  This can lead to lots of interesting coversations (and more!).  I had to return that costume a day late thanks to work committments, but the girl working the counter (not the owner, who is a notorious stickler) didn't charge me a late fee.

17.description: Very well-kept secret. After eating an Italian beef at RPP (Roger's Park Pizzeria), walk on over to search for some giant easter bunny heads, wedding dresses, viking costumes, and FANCY HATS. I scored a cashmere and fox fur sweater here, in PERFECT condition, for $65. It's so luscious and sexy. Mmmm.

10.description: I have never been inside Lost Eras until today and when I went inside it looked so disorganized and stuff was just left everywhere. But I guess that's what you expect when you go into a store that's in a semi-bad neighborhood. there were 3 pairs of shoes i wanted to get which were $3 each and i told the lady I only had $5 and she was like, "oh".  I really wanted the other shoes........................................P.S: Also, will someone please tell the store owner not to leave furniture ( for sale ) outside the store? Especially by the bus stop. So annoying.

11.description: I've been going to Lost Eras for the past four years with my two teenagers for their costumes and other goods that one can find with available time in the store.My favorite is everything found in the"Basement" we did not see any ghosts yet my daughter who is very intuitive did sense the vibe of the building.I highly recommend telling your friends Lost Eras is for me a great real Chicago type of place in a great part of the city. The Pabs

26.description: "Lost Eras" is a combination of a costume shop, a thrift store, and an antiques shop. The store is pretty disorganized, but if you've got a good amount of time, browsing it will be delightful. The first floor has some organization, with furniture and various knick knacks spread around at the front with jewelry. Most Halloween/theater costumes are further back on the first floor. There is a pretty good selection of the usual...flappers, pirates, princesses, etc. My first time here, I found a few 80s dresses and ended up buying one for a party. The basement has more general, vintage clothes along with all sorts of weird junk - old, creepy-looking dolls, rusty machines, a unicycle, old travel trunks and suitcases, etc. In my second time here, I found an awesome 70s dress in the basement while my friend got matching 70s-themed plaid pants and a tie. I also found a vintage coat that I would totally wear on a regular basis, and I plan on going back to buy it later. It's easily a coat that I would probably otherwise buy at some hip, vintage Web site for $50 and up, but it is probably super cheap at "Lost Eras."I say "probably" because pricing is one of the downsides to this store. A lot of the items do not have price tags, and it seems that the only person qualified to price them is the woman who owns "Lost Eras." When, for example, I tried buying items from a young man behind the counter during my second trip here, I was told that I'd have to wait for the owner to come back. Maybe that usually doesn't happen, but it was still slightly inconvenient.Also, since the store is disorganized, you can end up spending hours browsing the items while being distracted by everything else. Sure, i came in looking for 70s clothing, but wait...are those swords over there? On my second trip, my friend was mesmerized by the collection of bunny suits in the basement. (By the way, if you're interested, you can rent those bunny suits on a daily rate.) And it took me a long time to find my 70s gear; the clothing racks in the basement are tough to sort through. Still, overall, this store rocks compared to the other thrift/costume shops I've been to in Chicago. I've always found "Ragstock" to be just alright, and I actually went to "Brown Elephant" on Clark right after my second trip to "Lost Eras." For all the hype that I've heard about "Brown Elephant," I was just not very impressed after spending almost two hours at "Lost Eras." "Brown Elephant" seems to sell mostly just regular, just resold old GAP clothes. Boring.   Finding a parking meter around "Lost Eras" seems pretty easy. They also buy costumes. Go give this store some love.

27.description: Lost eras is a funky, eclectic place where you can find a little bit of everything - costumes, antiques, rings, masks - very cool.  If you need a unique costume for Halloween, this is the place (but make sure you call ahead - they run out of the most popular costumes quickly).To me, this store represents the tough, diverse nature of my hood - the reason why east RP won't be taken over by hipsters and bobos looking for that "urban feel".

0.description: This place is amazing!!! Such a hidden gem. Could be there for hours! The basement was filled with old nic nacs. Organized for the most part!

20.description: "I want to go to there"one of my good friends lives in chicago, and you know, i love her and all, but i am plotting a return visit *cover your ears cheryl* just to go to this fantastic vintage store. I scored a 1950's Oscar de la Renta dress for 50 bucks! INSANE. I cannot wait to return to chicago and spend some quality time at Lost Eras...i mean, catching up with old friends.

19.description: "I want to go to there"one of my good friends lives in chicago, and you know, i love her and all, but i am plotting a return visit *cover your ears cheryl* just to go to this fantastic vintage store. I scored a 1950's Oscar de la Renta dress for 50 bucks! INSANE. I cannot wait to return to chicago and spend some quality time at Lost Eras...i mean, catching up with old friends.

2.description: I got a great costume from here: a seventies outfit for an office party. It looks authentic, and they have plenty of choices in costumes, from almost any decade. Plus the staff was very helpful in deciding on the right look.  I'll definitely be back.

18.description: I seriously could get lost in here for days... or eras I suppose. They ended up selling the cabinet that I wanted but that's what I get for waiting to see if it will go down or not. One recommendation is to swing by the basement... it is creepy especially when they have the guy down there doing repairs (I can't help but think of every horror movie ever created especially house of a thousand corpses, if you've seen the movie you know what I'm talking about) and head down there with at least one friend... preferably a big strong guy (points if he's cute)

13.description: By Far the BEST place in Chicago for a DIY Halloween Costume.  Large store and basement with everything from astronaut to scuba diver gear available.  Almost any piece of clothing is available for renting so you don't get stuck with something you will only wear once forever.

4.description: Fantastic place to find all sorts of strange costumes and unique antiques.

24.description: Eleven months out of the year, this is a dumpy junk shop.  I walk past here sometimes on my way to the Howard CTA station, and I almost never see anyone inside.However, during October, it becomes a treasure trove of costumes, props, and accessories.  Selection dries up pretty severely as Halloween approaches, so shop early and take advantage of their "reserve" policy to hold your costume until the needed time.In 2005, I completed a classy modern-day Satan costume with a red-satin-lined cloak which was surprisingly high-quality and less filthy than it could have been (this passes for a compliment).  Halloween 2006 was brilliant thanks in large part to a last-minute costume that I cobbled together at Lost Eras--a Highland warrior with kilt, sash, boots, sword, etc.  Apparently many, many women want to ask what is under a man's kilt.  This can lead to lots of interesting coversations (and more!).  I had to return that costume a day late thanks to work committments, but the girl working the counter (not the owner, who is a notorious stickler) didn't charge me a late fee.

6.description: A fan of used clothing stores, costumes, and cool junk, this is one of my favorite hidden treasures. Hidden, because it is on a part of Howard Street you may not normally stroll along when out window shopping. I've been ducking in for years around Halloween to construct my costume, picking and choosing from racks and racks of old and odd clothes in the basement, or to wander the impressive selection of costumes for rent--animals, medieval, sports, you name it, they probably have it. Looking for theater props? Loads of vintage items in the basement. I also purchased a red wood, claw foot dresser from the used/antique furniture side in 2005, which is still in my bedroom.Lots of awesome and weird stuff.  If anyone lived in Andersonville when it was cool and remembers George's Junk Shop . . . like that, but with costumes.

22.description: So much fun and not just for Halloween. I mosied past on my way somewhere else I love brick a brack but didnt tease myself by goiong in because I knew in that area the proces would be out of my league. Well on my return trip I couldnt help but ti stop in pretend like I could affors to shop there I help my head high and walked in like I had a million bucks so many sculptures and jewelry and stuff I could buy. I crossed my fingers and hoped I could treat myself to the brass disk link chain I had in my hand. When I got to the counter the sweet lady said "is that all for you"  "yes" I replied with the five dollars in my hand(they only take cash) hoping she didnt say it was more than that. "How about a couple bucks" "oh please take the whole five" " oh dont worry about it you'll need your change"...I put my necklace on even thought it didnt match my out fit thinkng about the perfect  earrings I had at home to match it...and sure enough I needed my change when I passed my car I noticed my meter had expired and I wasnt done shopping...
