Using our first bites as a gauge, Badou adapted our entire meal to our liking, improvising in the kitchen to make dishes more spicy, sour or sweet; throughout the meal, Badou and his wife continued to check we were satisfied with the spice level.As in Senegal, where a predominantly Muslim population eschews pork, Badou relies on chicken, lamb and fish; taking advantage of Senegal's primary crops, Badou incorporates peanuts, sweet potatoes and black-eyed peas, often stewed with bold spices and served over white rice or couscous. (In one article posted online and displayed on the restaurant's wall, Badou's menu is described as "Senegalese soul food," which seems appropriate to a Girl Raised in the South--GRITS--like me.)Although I'd take any of Badou's recommendations, I'd be sure to order mafe, a thick peanut butter-based stew with fat chunks of chicken and yam. Less than 24 hours later, I was already craving another bowl!

11.description: Thank you, that was interesting AND delicious food! I stood there and watched them make my food, super fresh! We ordered the Pastels (chicken with tomatoes and onions in a pastry), yum; very flavorful. We went with the Infamous PB stew, this was amazing. The depth of flavor and "weird" combo of PB and heat are wonderful. My hubby ordered the Thiou Curry Chicken with rice, this was a familiar dish, comfort food at its finest. We will definitely be back. I won't come starving next time... it was such a tease watching and waiting for all that goodness. Thanks again! Ps... go cubs

39.description: This was an amazing meal. The food and experience was perfect. The owner Badou came out and walked us through the options, so perfectly that we NEVER even saw A MENU. He recommended and we just got swept away. There was no meal that I wouldn't recommend. We live a distance from here but we will be back and often. Thanks for the food. Service was "family like" just bring more wine. Come to hangout. They are open late and will "American up" an appetizer with a Senegalese spin. Go there and enjoy.

37.description: Ate there just last night. Absolutely delicious dinner and wonderful service. We were a party of five and were treated like family. We simply left the ordering to the owner and his wife and were rewarded with a wonderful dinner for an extremely fair price. The portions were very generous and the heat was dialed up or down as to our preferences. We will be back soon, can't wait to introduce it to more family and friends.

0.description: My Badou dining experience echoes all of the outstanding qualities that the avalanche of 5-star reviewers identify. For example, in response to questions about the extensive menu, the server invited Badou himself to our table. It felt like sitting in the dining room at the house of good friend, who  asked about our preferences, listened carefully to our responses, and recommended with great care several spot-on food options that he then expertly cooked. My dining companion and I were allowed, even encouraged, to linger over our food. We engaged in great conversation that is next to impossible in most restaurants due to constant unnecessary intrusions of "can I get that out of the way for you?" and other mindless interruptions. This was just one more way that Badou treated us like family --- and our truly distinctive and outstanding food was prepared with at least as much love as back home.I live near the Loop, but will be taking friends to Badou very soon. It's worth the trip!PS: vegetarians: there is a good selection of vegetarian selections on the menu, plus other dishes can be prepared with out meat upon request.

38.description: The tragedy of Badou's Senegalese restaurant is that it's unassuming facade hidden in a small strip mall makes it easy to overlook. And if you, like many others, have passed it by perhaps not even knowing it's there, then the tragedy is yours because Badou's restaurant is hands down some of the best food I've had in either Chicago or New York. Delicious, dynamic with flavors, and quality ingredients, Badou makes food that's as warming to the taste as it is to the heart. This is a place that's special, different, and well worth the trip to hunt it down.

51.description: Phenomenal food! Badou even came out to meet us in person. Highly recommend this place.

27.description: Thank you, that was interesting AND delicious food! I stood there and watched them make my food, super fresh! We ordered the Pastels (chicken with tomatoes and onions in a pastry), yum; very flavorful. We went with the Infamous PB stew, this was amazing. The depth of flavor and "weird" combo of PB and heat are wonderful. My hubby ordered the Thiou Curry Chicken with rice, this was a familiar dish, comfort food at its finest. We will definitely be back. I won't come starving next time... it was such a tease watching and waiting for all that goodness. Thanks again! Ps... go cubs

32.description: Authentic, great tasting, customer service is excellent! Bring cash for orders under $10. The food is very spicy, even if you order mild. So good, we will be eating here again!

54.description: In a never-ending quest to try ethnic eats off the beaten path, I went to Badou with two friends on a Saturday night. Although the restaurant, situated in a barren strip mall, lacks ambiance, Badou's food has more than enough flavor to compensate! (WOW.)Almost immediately after we were seated, Badou himself pulled up a chair and described the dishes already underway in the kitchen. Ignoring the menu, we agreed on a few things that would give us a complementary but contrasting taste of Senegal. (He said he would be happy to make anything else from scratch, but if you place a custom order, you'll be waiting for a few hours. Feel free to BYOB and/or board games!)Soon Badou brought out three pastels, addictive little chicken empanadas. Using our first bites as a gauge, Badou adapted our entire meal to our liking, improvising in the kitchen to make dishes more spicy, sour or sweet; throughout the meal, Badou and his wife continued to check we were satisfied with the spice level.As in Senegal, where a predominantly Muslim population eschews pork, Badou relies on chicken, lamb and fish; taking advantage of Senegal's primary crops, Badou incorporates peanuts, sweet potatoes and black-eyed peas, often stewed with bold spices and served over white rice or couscous. (In one article posted online and displayed on the restaurant's wall, Badou's menu is described as "Senegalese soul food," which seems appropriate to a Girl Raised in the South--GRITS--like me.)Although I'd take any of Badou's recommendations, I'd be sure to order mafe, a thick peanut butter-based stew with fat chunks of chicken and yam. Less than 24 hours later, I was already craving another bowl!

48.description: I recently dined at this quaint establishment nestled in an unassuming strip mall.  Had I not known where I was headed it would be missed, and sadly so.  The decor evokes a simple homage to Senegal while not distracting from the real reason of being there.  I had the joy of meeting the owner/chef that day.  We chatted about his progression to this part of the country from his homeland and I have to be honest that even before tasting the future dishes, I could tell that he would be cooking with his soul.  I trusted his judgment on some courses to bring out for me and my parents and it didn't dissapoint.  We started with an appetizer of pastels, flaky pastries purses filled with ground chicken and a concoction of perfect spices.  Badou was mindful on our various heat levels and customized them to our desires.  This lead to a new dish of a take on an okra stew.  Hearty and flavorful with a delectable balance.  This progressed into a rich peanut based entree, a sauce that smothered perfectly roasted chicken pieces infused with chunks of sweet potatoe and carrots.  Finally he refreshed our palates with a seemingly simple dish consisting of rice, chicken, lime, and carmelized onions.  Simple but extraordinary.  In the end he finished our meal with beautifully cooked plantains that rounded out the entire experience.  I can't wait to go back.  I am a fan of food being an experience and savoring a chefs artistic creations over time.  This is not a thing to rush.  I highly recommend this place to all I can.

44.description: What a wonderful neighborhood gem. It's a family restaurant and the food and service reflect their passion for their culture. It's a BYOB, which I like. The atmosphere is ultra casual but the food is top class!

24.description: When we walked in a little before 5 pm on a Wednesday evening, there was no one else dining. The chef/owner greeted us right away, and when we asked him for recommendations, he was friendly and excited to share his favorites. He really sold the food and made connections to our tastes. He even went into how he prepared the dishes and why he recommended them this way. You could really feel the hospitality and passion behind his cooking.We had the hibiscus cocktail and the pineapple ginger cocktail. They do not have alcohol, but we didn't mind, haha. The hibiscus was floral but very smooth and slightly sweet. The pineapple ginger drink was sweet and definitely gingery, not too sweet, and had some spicy surprises with a hint of anise. The drinks complemented the spices in our food.We had the chicken Pastels, cooked in tomato and onion and wrapped in a pastry crust. That crust though! Flaky, crispy, moist--in other words, perfect. The chicken was moist and has a slightly sweet taste from the tomato but a nice blend of spices and onions that made it a unique taste profile. They kind of reminded me of empanadas, but with an nicer crust and more filling! We also had the plantains. They were some of the best I have had because they were caramelized, sweet, hot, and melted in your mouth.Being a fan of Thai peanut sauces, I ordered the Mafe after he recommended it because it was a spicy peanut sauce with chicken, potatoes, and carrots served over rice. The spices were really quite unique. It was almost a floral, spicy, nuttiness that was addictive. Slightly sweet, spicy, and oh so savory. The heat wasn't like a burn your tongue hot, but the spices definitely gave it a slow burn of yummy flavor! Just typing about it has my mouth watering again.The other entree we had was the Senegalese National Dish with the king fish. This plate was a big portion of savory rice, spiced veggies, and a big portion of flaky fish stuffed with herbs. The fish is cooked with bones in, so beware. I am not sure how I feel about having to pick bones out of a fish, but my girlfriend did not mind and enjoyed her dish. She even had leftovers. The food was excellent, but what really makes me want to go back, besides trying more dishes, is how passionate and genuine the chef was. When we let him know that we enjoyed our meals and that we heard good things on Yelp, he shared how he was listening to feedback about how sometimes the wait for food is too long. He asked for our feedback (we didn't feel it took too long, but we were the only ones there), and he thanked us. Overall, the chef embodies the soul food experience, and shares his passion in a warm and welcoming way.

7.description: No-one probably knows what Senegalese food is, or in fact where Senegal is located.This shouldn't be stopping you from coming in and trying out food from this Western African country.Senegalese has it's own style of food (it does cross borders and tribes to nearby regions) that's quite different from the more popular African food people are used to like Ethiopian or Moroccan.The national rice dish is a good starting point. It's basically hammered rice soaked in spices (think tamarind) and topped off with veggies and comes with fish. It's good, it's not like anything you'd imagine it to be, and it's worth trying.There are other dishes that you can pick that are legit as well. The peanut butter chicken is fairly good with a peanut butter/ketchup like taste.Samosas are fresh, made on the spot and delicious.Owner is super nice and friendly, and he's the cook. It does, as has been mentioned take some time to get the food, so don't come here if you are in a hurry.

49.description: Wonderful surprise in Chicago. 8 of us went yo dine at Badou from Oak Park. it was quite a drive but once there we were welcomed as if it was our home. We dined family style with plenty of food to go around. The pastel and mafa are fantastic and rice was cooked perfectly. highly recommended!

40.description: I've tried Badou twice. Once dining in, and once for delivery. I've enjoyed everything I've eaten both times. The food is a nice change from my usual fare. It's tasty and has that 'fresh & homemade' feel. It can be a bit on the slow side. I haven't found that to be a problem, but if you're starving and must eat NOW, then you may want to save Badou for another day.The staff are some of the friendliest I've encountered in Chicago. I'll definitely be back.

53.description: Wow what a hidden surprise. A group of us shared a meal in this terrific unassuming spot that I am so glad that we adventured out to discover. Written up in the cheap eats 2014 of Chicago magazine so we thought to give it a try. Everything was made to order. The flavors were both exotic and delicious. Incredible combination of flavors with every dish. Everything was fresh and the variety of the unique chicken dish with peanut sauce, fish with jasmine rice with so many secret ingredients and another dish with Carmelized onions and limes was a gourmet feast. I definitely want to come back. Byob and very casual. Love to support this authentic restaurant. Definitely a find.

30.description: It was amazing! Everything was prepared with great attention to flavor and was very tasty. We went in a group of 10 people and every dish was cooked and timed well for 4 courses. And Badou and his wife are super friendly and nice. And they have free parking! A very enjoyable evening!

46.description: Man, we had a blast at Badou's last night. Our friend had her birthday dinner here, and Badou pulled out all the stops. It also happened to be Senegalese Independence Day, so there was a ton of celebrating and delicious food. It was my first time eating Senegalese food, so I had to try a little bit of everything. The chicken pastels were super tasty, the fish was awesome, but the maafe totally stole the show for me. Badou and his wife Paula were the most gracious hosts, and we really felt their genuine pleasure in sharing a great meal with friends. I love cooking, and for me, the best thing is to make a ton of kick-ass food for a group of friends. I feel like Badou is a kindred spirit, and we will definitely be coming back here for more fun tasty times!

1.description: My friend and I came here for dinner last weekend because we were feeling adventurous. I had no idea what Senegalese food was like before my visit here and was pretty blown away by how delicious everything was. Badou is a small restaurant, with maybe about 20 seats (generous estimate), but it was pretty empty when we came so there wasn't a wait. The restaurant is run by a very nice couple, so it was cool that we were supporting the Rogers Park community!We ordered the jerk chicken (the special of the night) and the national Senegalese dish, which was fish. We were asked if we wanted a whole fish or just pieces, and the chef recommended getting the whole fish because the spices would be more prominent. We also got chicken pastels to start and I tried their ginger cocktail.Verdict? Excellent on all fronts. The chicken pastels were kind of like empanadas and the crust was super flaky. The filling was really flavorful too. The jerk chicken was the best jerk chicken I've ever had. It wasn't dry and the sauce for it was AMAZING (but definitely packs quite a bit of heat, so ask for it on the side if you're not the biggest fan of spicy food). The fish had this crazy crunchy crust and was doused in this really great veggie sauce. I felt like the crust was a little too crunchy for me, but my friend was a big fan. All the sides were really yummy as well - loved the rice, the veggies, the fried plantains... no complaints!The ginger cocktail was interesting. I'm a big fan of ginger and I couldn't decide if I liked it or not, but if you're into ginger ale or ginger tea, it's worth trying. The flavor combination is definitely unique!We each paid about $18 for the meal and we had leftovers, which I thought was very good for the quality and amount of food. I definitely want to come back!

55.description: Went with a group of 14 for a birthday dinner. I called ahead, and Badou said he would put together a meal, including some off-menu items. Having been there before, I trusted it would be great, and it sure was. Empanadas, chicken pasteles, mafe, djollof rice and fish, lamb shank, all excellent. Badou is the most gracious, affable host as well, and everyone had a great time. If you have time to savor the experience, it's well worth it for food made fresh and with care.

9.description: When we walked in a little before 5 pm on a Wednesday evening, there was no one else dining. The chef/owner greeted us right away, and when we asked him for recommendations, he was friendly and excited to share his favorites. He really sold the food and made connections to our tastes. He even went into how he prepared the dishes and why he recommended them this way. You could really feel the hospitality and passion behind his cooking.We had the hibiscus cocktail and the pineapple ginger cocktail. They do not have alcohol, but we didn't mind, haha. The hibiscus was floral but very smooth and slightly sweet. The pineapple ginger drink was sweet and definitely gingery, not too sweet, and had some spicy surprises with a hint of anise. The drinks complemented the spices in our food.We had the chicken Pastels, cooked in tomato and onion and wrapped in a pastry crust. That crust though! Flaky, crispy, moist--in other words, perfect. The chicken was moist and has a slightly sweet taste from the tomato but a nice blend of spices and onions that made it a unique taste profile. They kind of reminded me of empanadas, but with an nicer crust and more filling! We also had the plantains. They were some of the best I have had because they were caramelized, sweet, hot, and melted in your mouth.Being a fan of Thai peanut sauces, I ordered the Mafe after he recommended it because it was a spicy peanut sauce with chicken, potatoes, and carrots served over rice. The spices were really quite unique. It was almost a floral, spicy, nuttiness that was addictive. Slightly sweet, spicy, and oh so savory. The heat wasn't like a burn your tongue hot, but the spices definitely gave it a slow burn of yummy flavor! Just typing about it has my mouth watering again.The other entree we had was the Senegalese National Dish with the king fish. This plate was a big portion of savory rice, spiced veggies, and a big portion of flaky fish stuffed with herbs. The fish is cooked with bones in, so beware. I am not sure how I feel about having to pick bones out of a fish, but my girlfriend did not mind and enjoyed her dish. She even had leftovers. The food was excellent, but what really makes me want to go back, besides trying more dishes, is how passionate and genuine the chef was. When we let him know that we enjoyed our meals and that we heard good things on Yelp, he shared how he was listening to feedback about how sometimes the wait for food is too long. He asked for our feedback (we didn't feel it took too long, but we were the only ones there), and he thanked us. Overall, the chef embodies the soul food experience, and shares his passion in a warm and welcoming way.

26.description: Went in tonight for take out. Ordered The veggie pastel appetizer while my son and I waited. They were freaking amazing! Had to have another order to take home. All vegetarian meal, the veggie curry was really really great! Tons of fresh veggies including Brussel Spouts (my fav) all cooked perfectly...four dishes in total all of them unique flavors and excellent! Badou is a great guy and a welcoming chef! Who knew Senegalese food could be SO good!? Highly reco the food!

25.description: Delicious food.  Make a reservation before you come here to dine in.  There were 3 other parties of 5-12 people who were there when we got there and still there when we left.  It is small with very few tables.  Don't expect anything fancy.  The bissap - hibiscus drink was delicious.  It tastes like a blue corn drink I had in Peru but with a citrus after taste.  We had the yassar guinar which was cooked well but the very lemon flavor was too acidic to fit our flavor palette.  The thiebou was zesty and spicy and it was delicious.  The fish was pan fried perfectly.  Next time we will come back with friends to try more dishes.

12.description: One of those hole-in-the-wall places you go to not for the ambiance and pretentious crowd but for good, wholesome, native food. Used a Groupon to dine and were greeted as we walked in. It helped that we arrived before the rush and were able to chat with the owner, Badou who you can tell puts his heart in his cooking. He was amiable, generous and had a child-like enthusiasm towards his dishes which you don't get to see often. We had whole fired tilapia and lamb entrees along with their version of empanadas that did not disappoint.I think people need to visit places like this more often especially in neighborhoods that are not typically on your list of places to dine in. Forget the setup or how cleaner the tables could be, but just enjoy the food and the warm hospitality.

59.description: The food was delicious, BUT the delivery was terrible. It took more than 75 minutes to arrive because the driver couldn't find our building and called us for directions, then he had difficulty following what we were telling him. He eventually found our building but somehow couldn't find the main gate for the courtyard - we were looking at it out our window and never saw him. He insisted we come outside and meet him at his car, which was at the building next door.

21.description: Had peanut dish, onion chicken dish, barbecue  dish and plantains. Staff was so friendly. Great family friendly environment. Excellent service and food! Coming back.

17.description: My roommate and I finally decided to try this restaurant since it was down the street from us and it was one of the best decisions I've made. This was the first time I've ever tried Senegalese food and I will definitely be going back to try it again. The restaurant itself is a hole-in-the wall type located in a small plaza on Howard. The inside has a lot of traditional Senegalese art hanging and displayed. Inside the light was a bit dim where we sat near the window so I would say I wish it was a bit brighter. Onto the food, we had the fataya as appetizers and the chicken mafe and thiebou djen as our main entrees. They were all very delicious - the fataya was a tad more spicy than I expected but very well flavored; the chicken mafe was a bit more peanut buttery than I would have liked but I think we didn't mix it too well with the rice; and lastly the thiebou djen was cooked perfectly with the right amount of crispyness. They were all very well-proportioned meals and we had enough for leftovers the next day. I also really enjoyed the chef/owner coming and sitting down with all his customers and when he took his time with us he told us about his cooking techniques. He explained how he's been trying out new cooking methods to minimize the amount of oil needed which was fascinating.I would highly recommend anyone who's interested in trying Senegalese food to come to Badou and try them out.

10.description: favorite new restaurant in Rodgers Park! Badou and Paula are amazing. food is incredible, service (complimentary bottled water) and atmosphere were wonderful. we'll definitely be back - again & again.

5.description: I once saw one of those TV shows feature this place and at the time I had never tried Senegalese cuisine. I was able to try Yassa in Bronzeville not too long ago so I had even more motivation to try this place even though its quite the hike to Rogers Park. Me and my buddy came over on a chilly Tues nite to see what was up here. Its a small mom and pop joint with a little strip mall area with maybe less than 10 tables. The African art/pictures on the wall was nice...they even sell some pieces. The owner whose name is Badou walked us through the menu and let us know what the most popular dishes were. He recommended that we start out with the chicken and beef pastels. The pastels are very similar to empanadas and are just as good. The chicken tasted just a bit better than the beef, but both were very good. The tomato and onion sauce that comes with it makes it even better. In terms of entree, he told us we couldn't go wrong with the Chicken Yassa or the Chicken Maffe. We decided that we would split both dishes. The Yassa was the best of the 2 as it was chicken infused with lime and caramelized onions...awesome flavor and couldn't put the fork down. The Meffe was good also which is chicken cooked with creamy peanut butter sauce. This dish was very rich and tasty. We ordered both dishes hot, but probably should have gone with mild LOL...love the spice though! Not very expensive place and as I mentioned its a small mom and pop joint. Definitely worth the trip to Rogers Park

3.description: If you want something with flavor, this restaurant is the BEST. Mr. Badou is also treats every customer like family. The first time I went in there I was overwhelmed with the taste of the jerk chicken and the empanadas. This place is very low-key but VERY good. The portions are huge so go there hungry.

35.description: The food at this place is the closest to authentic Senegalese food that I enjoyed during my Peace Corps Service there, the kind I remember from the patrone places in Dakar.  I was there for a fellow RPCV's birthday, which coincidentally was on Senegalese independence day, and the party was awesome.  Badou was an incredibly gracious host, and the food was amazing!The only drawbacks are its relative distance from the El, and that it is situated in a strip mall.Word of advice to people who want the real Senegalese food: call Badou in advance and tell him what dish you want, and that you want it cooked authentically, because (out of necessity) he has to cater his food to the Toubabs (less spice, etc).

19.description: This place would be the best choice when you are in mood of "I'd like to try something different today". Food is healthy and exotic. The place is small but clean and well decorated. People who work there are very friendly. I'd like to take my vegetarian friends to this place. Probably the best casual restaurant around Howard area considered the price and the taste. Some people mentions that the service is slow, I agree with It but the time we were dining was also around 3 o'clock. Good food deserves to wait anyway. I heard microwave noise too but I don't see it as a problem at all. I often make food by myself with raw food. It is pretty common to use microwave to melt butter & prepare fresh veggies, heat up rice. Don't think using microwave is necessarily a sign of unfresh /old food.

28.description: Never have my expectations and my actual experience been more different than at Badou. I'm a big fan of ethnic foods so I've wanted to try this place for a while but there's no way I can sugarcoat my experience, everything was horrible.Our first indication that we shouldn't eat here was the number of people in the cooking area that didn't belong there. I'm talking about random people from the neighborhood walking through the door and having conversations with the people cooking right beside where the food is being prepared. This may be okay when you are serving family and guests in your own home, but it is not acceptable when you are serving paying customers in a "restaurant." It's a sanitation issue plain and simple. There was no consideration given to this at Badou.Our second indication that we weren't going to be getting the meal we expected was the number of times we heard the MICROWAVE. I thought this was supposed to be authentic and fresh food? I'm not sure exactly what was being microwaved but I guarantee that the rice on both dishes was, and that couldn't have been all because it was being used constantly.Next was the service. To say that it was lacking would be a gigantic compliment. There is no excuse for how long we had to wait to order , how long we waited for our food to come, and how long we were held hostage after we had had enough and just wanted to pay our bill and leave.It was 15 minutes from the time we were "seated" to the time someone came and talked to us. The woman that finally came to take our order had just walked in from outside and luckily asked us if someone had helped us yet while she was walking towards the back. No one had said a word to us up until this point except Badou himself who had seen my wife looking at a picture of the lobster on Yelp and promptly told her "we don't have that today" and walked away. We put in our order for chicken coconut soup, chicken pastel appetizer, chicken made, and thiebou djen, all of which were discussed with the "waitress" and came recommended. 10 minutes later, the waitress comes back and tells us that they ran out of coconut milk so we can't have the soup... okay...Another 10 minutes goes by and the waitress comes out again and asks us if we want to have the beef fataya as an appetizer instead of our chicken pastel because it's already made. At this point I was becoming skeptical because I had been sitting and listening to the microwave go off over and over so I knew she was trying to just give us whatever they had in the back, so I declined thinking that the appetizer that we ordered surely must be close to being finished by now. I was wrong!We continued to wait, listening to the sounds of the microwave humming and beeping for another 20 minutes before we got anything to eat. If you're keeping track, we have already been at Badou for an hour and had ordered our food over 45 minutes ago.The food:Chicken mafe - This came out first, before our appetizer because there was a "delay" with our appetizer. I suspect the delay was that it was the only thing that didn't come out of the microwave but we didn't care at this point, we were just very hungry. The sauce was a mildly spicy peanut sauce that was pretty good. What ruined the dish was the chicken. It was unseasoned, unmarinated chicken that was either boiled or microwaved and then simply chopped up and mixed in with the sauce. It was chewy, tough and tasteless. The white rice that came with the dish was microwaved as well.Chicken Pastel appetizer - This came after we had gotten our first entree, so 45 minutes for our appetizer to arrive. This was the best part of our meal. The crust was flaky and the chicken was shredded and flavored well. I wish this was all we had ordered.Thiebou Djen - Where do I start? Hmm let's see.. how about the fact that this entree didn't come out until we were already finished with all of our other food. How about that when the waitress described it to us she said it was tilapia, and in all the pictures in Yelp we've seen tilapia, but after we were done eating it and we were asked how we liked it, I said it was pretty good to be polite and the waitress said "good because it's usually made with tilapia but this is catfish. I don't like it this way but I'm glad you liked it." ARE YOU KIDDING ME??? You subbed the fish out of my dish without even saying anything to me? Don't you realize that some people eat tilapia but don't eat catfish for religious reasons (bottom feeders), or that some people just don't want to order catfish? Once again the rice was microwaved and burned... whateverAt this point, my wife was very irritated so she went to wait in the car because she had had enough and I asked for the check. ANOTHER 20 minutes goes by and we still can't leave because I haven't been able to pay for my horrible meal yet. I had to ask to pay 3x before we could finally get the hell out of there.This was the worst dining experience I've ever had.

45.description: This restaurant is a hidden gem. You will not find better tasting or more authentic Senegalese food anywhere in the city. Period. If you're missing that authentic West African flavor, are looking to expand your food horizons, or are in search of new vegetarian options, you can't go wrong with Badou's.The menu has good variety, everything is beyond delicious, and the service puts it over the top. Calling it "service," really doesn't do this place justice. When you walk in, you are warmly greeted by Badou, the owner, and he walks you through the menu options. After sampling some of the dishes, I ended up having Maafe (spicy peanut and veggie sauce over jasmine rice) and my friend the Yassa (chicken with caramelized onion sauce) and they were both incredible, the perfect blend of savory and spice. The portions are sizable but to my surprise I ended up finishing the whole thing because it was so delicious.Badou's warm welcome and personal touch really puts it over the top. You can tell he pours his heart and soul into every dish. Check this place out, you just don't find this kind of restaurants every day.

33.description: PARKING!! My favorite part!Pastels ... fried pies by any name ... empaneras, samosas, pastels ... love the spicy filling, and extra chili paste (or chili paste onion chutney) ... perfectly flakey crusts! Mafe - chicken and yams in a rich spicy peanut sauce. Mellow warmth with a great spice flavor. Warmer as you continue eating.  Almost wanted bread to mop the player. Thiou Curry - nice yellow curry with a little edge of ginger (especially along with the ginger/pineapple cocktail - also good if you really like strong ginger flavors).Bbq Lamb (dibi?) - tender little shanks cooked to order with a lightly spiced coating on a bed of rice and grilled onions.So gloriously full and spice endorphins flowing! Very friendly and helpful staff! Will definitely return and order delivery! Lots of variety and they say more to come soon on redoing the menus!

43.description: I tried this place after getting a Groupon, and I was very pleased with the experience. The food was delicious, especially the braised tilapia, and the owner was very friendly. Note:  The "hot" level of spiciness was not too hot, but it had a little bit of a kick.I'll definitely be going back!

2.description: I ordered from this restaurant via GrubHub twice. Both times my food came over an hour after the projected time - over two hours after ordered. The first time I had to call several times to find out what was happening. I was living in Rogers Park (2014-15), very close to the restaurant. Both times, Mr. Badou told me there was an issue with the driver. The second time, (2016) they didn't even deliver my complete order, forgetting my bissap/hibiscus drink. I was at a house less than a mile from the restaurant in Evanston.The food is decent, not my favorite West African in Chicago, but good enough that I tried more than once for acceptable service. Perhaps it'd be 4-5 stars if I went to dine in the restaurant. It seems like Mr. Badou is a great man. Perhaps they should consider nixing their delivery service if it isn't feasible.

I don't like it this way but I'm glad you liked it." ARE YOU KIDDING ME??? You subbed the fish out of my dish without even saying anything to me? Once again the rice was microwaved and burned... whateverAt this point, my wife was very irritated so she went to wait in the car because she had had enough and I asked for the check. ANOTHER 20 minutes goes by and we still can't leave because I haven't been able to pay for my horrible meal yet. I had to ask to pay 3x before we could finally get the hell out of there.This was the worst dining experience I've ever had.

41.description: Delicious BYOB place!I went to celebrate a friend's birthday, and we ate family style with a bunch of dishes that everyone shared. It was my first time eating Senagalese food. I am a vegetarian, and traditionally, a lot if Senagalese dishes are cooked with meat in them and then the meat is removed, so there are a lot of vegetables and yummy sauces with rice (a bit like Thai or Indian food). Badou can accommodate vegetarians! Woo! He made a sweet potato maffe with peanut sauce and carrots that still haunts my dreams, it was so good. And a tasty savory pastry that was sort of like an empanada that was super good. Since I was here for a large event, my friend set up the menu with Badou beforehand and they discussed the fact that she would have some vegetarian friends, so for a regular dinner if you have vegetarians in your party, you might want to call ahead (since most traditional dishes are cooked with meat). But seriously, the vegetarian adaptations I ate were amazing. And my husband eats meat, so he ate like 5 different dishes and LOVED them. The made and the yassa were both huge hits. PS We also had a friend with a peanut allergy, and Badou was so sweet and thorough in accommodating the peanut allergy and the vegetarians (who we're not the same people), so don't let dietary restrictions keep you from this yummy cuisine. Mmmmm....

52.description: After dining at Badou's, I suddenly began to contemplate a move to Chicago just to be nearer to Senegalese food.  Immediately upon entering the restaurant, my mouth began to salivate and the initial smells did not prove misleading.  The food at Badou's is downright delectable and everything I consumed had me craving more.  The mafe had a soulful earthiness and the theibou djen a bright and playful flavor.  I nearly licked the plate.  The atmosphere and service certainly did not disappoint either.  My friend and I were warmly greeted by Paula who provided suggestions according to our tastes and dietary restrictions.  She then conferred with Badou who informed us as to which dishes were top-notch that day.  Once he'd prepared and served our food, Badou came out of the kitchen to inquire about their delectability and how the dishes jived with our individual tastes.  Later, he even provided us with samples of other dishes.Perhaps the most impressive measurement of tastiness of the food was my friend.  A finicky and non-adventuresome eater, she dragged her feet at dining at Badou's.  Upon the first spoonful, she was singling the place's praises.Go here.  You'll love it.  The management and other clientele will treat your warmly and you'll leave with your belly the same way too - - brimming full of unadulterated happiness.

50.description: My boyfriend is from Senegal and is always talking about how much he misses authentic Senegalese cuisine. An Uber driver who is friends with Badou recommended his restaurant and we decided to embark on the short trek from our apartment. Badou's hospitality is refreshing. The care and attention he puts into ever dish is wonderful. Badou greeted us right when we walked into his restaurant. Since I was new to the Senegalese cuisine scene my kind boyfriend and badou made suggestions. I appreciated the array of vegetarian dishes. I ended up getting the veggie Maafe. The portion sizes are quite large. Can you say left overs?! :) The maafe was AMAZING! I am looking forward to tasting other dishes on the menu soon. I would recommend giving Badou a try. Enjoy! :)

4.description: A few weeks ago while going into Evanston, I saw Badou Senegalese Cuisine and thought to myself to make a calendar entry for a visit. After time had passed, I wanted something different to write about in my food blog and Badou Senegalese Cusine came to mind.Bissap. Cury soup. Fataya. Cebbu Djen.One drink I always hanker for during Christmas is sorrel, something that is very popular in Jamaica. I was quite happy to see that there was bissap on the menu, a drink made with hibiscus leaves just like sorrel. And it was just as refreshing. The curry soup was spicy, as I requested, and I swear this would be an idea autumn and winter soup. The fataya were also spicy the way I ordered them and if it were not for me going to a friend's home after leaving the restaurant, I would have ordered some for take-away. The cebbu djen was outstanding. The fish was meaty and seasoned well. Yes, it, too, was spicy. The djolof rice, cabbage, whole carrot, and eggplant would have made a rather tasty vegetarian dish without the fish.For those who like their food to arrive at the table within minutes of ordering, you may not be a happy customer. Clearly food is prepared to order and I like that because I'm assured that it's not being warmed up quickly in a microwave. There is something good about having food prepared to order. Then again, being Jamaican and Ghanaian, I am accustomed to food being served that way. I need to go back in the future to sample some of the other dishes.

6.description: Great food and excellent service. Badou is friendly and took good care of us. Free parking is always a plus.

22.description: I have tried to give this place a chance even though the food can be really good, the customer experience is so bad, it really isn't worth the trouble.  The first time we ate here, we didn't leave until three hours later. The kitchen doesn't seem to be equipped to serve parties of two or more their entrees at the same time. After this experience, I vowed never to dine in again there. The carry out experience is even worse because no matter how much of an advance notice you give on your order, there's a 90% chance it still won't be ready when you get there, then tag another 30 to 45 minutes to your wait, if there are other customers dining in. My most recent carry out experience was too surreal to ever go back again. I called in the order, gave the cook and additional 30 minutes, got there 1 1/2 hours later for pick up, it wasn't ready. I was told the food would be done in 5 minutes, which wasn't true (25 minutes more accurate) I got my food and the fish wasn't prepared the way it is routinely prepared, which added another 45 minutes to the wait. Luckily there were other unsuspecting first time diners there because my incorrectly prepared fish was re-purposed for them. It took almost three hours to get dinner! Finally for the inconvenience, I was offered bottled water. There is another Senegalese restaurant out south. The next time I'm in the mood for Senegalese, I think I would be willing to drive to and possibly risk my life in order to avoid the unprofessionalism at this restaurant.m

15.description: This place was incredible. My friends and I do a dinner of the month club, I think we have tried about 20 restaurants, and we are pretty sure this one wins. We made a reservation for 13 people on Friday night, and they were prepared. They had our menu pre-planned, so we could try and share a handful of the best dishes, and were even super accommodating to the vegetarians in the group. Badou and his wife greeted us and told us about each dish, giving us some choices and making recommendations. The food was excellent. The jerk chicken was incredible, and I highly recommend mafe chicken, cooked in a peanut butter sauce. I think my favorite was the second dish, chicken cooked with a dijon mustard sauce. I have honestly never had anything like it. Everything was truly home cooked, arriving one dish at a time in casserole dishes. It was also super cheap and byob. Perfect experience!

57.description: I love this place! I probably order from them at least once a week. The sauce that goes with the delicious pastel is soooo good! I like both the chicken and veggie pastel. Plantain was great! Mafe and foufou (I don't usually like this but here it was so delicious!)  are tasty. What makes this place special though is the warmth from the owner and workers. I had one delivery show up late, and the next time they brought me a whole seafood rice dish!!! That's quality-- they really know service!

20.description: The food is delicious. I love the mafe, grilled lamb, foufou, and the list goes on. The owners are friendly, and happy to discuss the menu with you of you are not familiar with Senegalese food. This is my new go-to spot! They will make the food to from mild to nose running spicy (how i like it).  This restaraunt is a hidden gem!

36.description: So many vegetarian options, such helpful and friendly service from the chef and our waitress, and such tasty and filling food.The veggie pastel appetizer was stellar: perfectly fried and not too heavy.  I had the vegetarian version of what the menu called the Senegalese national dish (djolof rice), and liked it a lot.  At the end of the meal the chef came out and asked if I eat fish (yes), and cooked up a piece of fish to add to my leftovers I was taking home.  I definitely have warm feelings for this place.

14.description: My husband and I went to Badou after several recommendations. As soon as we entered, we felt very at home. We tried the chicken pastels, which were absolute delicious. I ordered the national Senegalese dish (Cebu djen) and my husband ordered the jerk chicken. Everything was so well spiced and tasted so fresh. We will definitely come back to try more foods off their menu!

1.description: This place is the best place to eat on Morse Ave in Rogers Park!! The food is amazing and the prices are great! ! Be prepared cause cash only but don't let that stop you!! Try the veggie burger! Loaded with toppings and very filling!! Will def be a regular customer from now on!!

9.description: It's a really small food place owned by two brothers. They are so sweet and friendly and make sure to get your order right. The place is a no frills kinda place but the food is superb. I love there gyro cheeseburger.  It is meaty and juicy and ph so delicious

23.description: This is a great place to get a cheap quick meal, they have generous portions and nice guys working the counter. My husband loves the gyros, I like the chicken strips and double cheeseburger. I had a turkey sub here once, which was also pretty good.  It's pretty typical food that you might expect from a deli that serves gyros and cheese burgers, but if that's what you are in the mood for, you shouldn't be disappointed.

25.description: The owners, who work the counter, are very friendly.  I believe they are brothers.  Anyway, the food is fresh, quickly prepared and tastes great !  It is what it is....a place to get something quick to eat.  Good food, nice employees and it's clean and quick.  There are a few tables or you can call in for take out. Try it !

12.description: While this place has tables, it's about 90% likely you're only ordering takeout from this place.With that said, It's as simple as it gets (in a good way).If you're in the Rogers Park area and you're looking for a good sandwich (e.g. italian beef, gyro, sausage, or, surprise surpise, a sub), they won't disappoint with friendly service and decent prices.  Strongly recommend for an easy lunch.

21.description: I lived in Rogers Park for nearly two years, and would average two visits per week. I now live in Evanston, and still visit at least twice per month. The brothers unfortunately have been struggling with business as of late, but have been operating for over 10 years. The brothers sincerely care about their food and service.

16.description: When I noticed that Sub Brothers only had eight reviews on Yelp today I was shocked!  This place has been around forever so how in the world can there only be eight reviews?  Well, I am going to make sure to make the ninth and tell my roomate to make the tenth, because I love this little place!In all honestly, I have only had one thing from Sub Brothers, but I've been there many times!  I just love the traditional turkey sandwich so much that I never have the urge to try anything new.  My roommate, on the other hand, has tried a few different things and she has enjoyed everything that she has ordered.  This place isn't fancy by any means, but it's perfectly simple and always hits my sandwich spot!  It's small, with about three tables inside, but it's so warm and inviting.  There are two guys - brothers, I presume, as they look identical and the name would indicate that to be true -  who are always there working side by side.  They are so nice and adorable I just want to buy sandwiches from them every day just to give them my business.

17.description: When I meet someone from Rogers Park, I always ask the same question - have you been to Sub Brothers? And their answer is always no. This place is soooo good! I don't understand why people haven't tried it! It doesn't look like much from the outside, but It's cheap, it's delicious, and the brothers are super nice. We moved to Evanston 6 months ago and we still stop by every other week. I'm from TX, and whenever I go home to visit, my brother asks me to take a couple of their gyros with me, haha!Everything I've had there is good. The Sub Brother, gyro, Italian beef, and chicken sandwich are my favorites. Oh and they have wings served over a basket of French fries drenched in hot sauce, which is very addicting. It's cash only.Please go! They need your business!

10.description: Ive been going to this place for 8+ years and the food is always good. My favorite item is gyro Sandwich. The two bothers are very nice people and the service is fast.

5.description: So yesterday I was craving some good chicken with mild sauce. Called Krispy Krunchy Chicken just to be fooled. So my boyfriend suggested Sub Brothers, which is around the corner from my house and I must say, it was one of the best food experiences of my life. I ordered the eight wings with fries and man oh man, holy crap, I'm in Pavlov mood right now man. Any who, my food was perfect, the chicken was seasoned perfectly and the fries were AMAZING! My boyfriend had the same with a sub as well. His was the corn-beef and roast beef sub, from his delight it was amazing. Delicious he says. This place is truly a treasure. It's owned by two of the sweetest old men ever and it's clean. Note if you want to eat at this place, it is small with only seats for about eight people. For food this good, you get take out, go home put on some Step Brothers or some Breaking Bad and have a blast of a day.Oh by the way, their sauces are YES. YESSSSSSSS MAKE LOVE TO MY PALETTES.

11.description: Ok, I'm back for my second sandwich this week and on a hunch, I asked what the ham was made of. Well, I found out that, they use turkey ham.  :( They don't sell pork products here. However, the sandwiches are still pretty good. Very nice gentleman that owns the place. I will return.

22.description: this is the perfect place that I like to eat at. It's CHEAP 3.70 for a philly cheese steak cheap. and a tasty one at that. they take their time cooking and preparing your food, which makes me happy. I love the kindness of the two guys working there. and the food is super tasty. I wish the turkey was a bit better quality, but overall, it's a nice place to eat and I'm glad I live nearby!

0.description: One of the best spots in Rogers Park to get a bite!  The brothers are always so nice.  The sandwiches are absolutely amazing!!! They are my right hand restaurant when I need something to eat nearby.  The price point is surprisingly low for how big the sandwiches are.  Diverse menu too; Love all the options.Happy to say I'm a regular here!

20.description: When I meet someone from Rogers Park, I always ask the same question - have you been to Sub Brothers? And their answer is always no. This place is soooo good! I don't understand why people haven't tried it! It doesn't look like much from the outside, but It's cheap, it's delicious, and the brothers are super nice. We moved to Evanston 6 months ago and we still stop by every other week. I'm from TX, and whenever I go home to visit, my brother asks me to take a couple of their gyros with me, haha!Everything I've had there is good. The Sub Brother, gyro, Italian beef, and chicken sandwich are my favorites. Oh and they have wings served over a basket of French fries drenched in hot sauce, which is very addicting. It's cash only.Please go! They need your business!

19.description: Perfect for greasy hamburgers and fries when you are hungover. Does the trick to fix everything that ails you. Plus, you can get canned ginger ale there too.I had their double cheeseburger, and they made it right in front of my eyes. Nothing pre-made and sitting under a warmer here. Also had mozzarella sticks, another one of my hangover cures, and they were pretty good too. My roommate has had their chicken tenders and they are huge! And pretty filling as well, not too shabby for fried chicken.Overall, I don't think I would eat here on an average day, but if I was feeling like some stick to your ribs greasy food this place is perfect.

2.description: Today I was craving a Sub, but not from Subway where the bread ratiooverpowers the meat and then there's like a $2.00 upcharge for extra meat..So, I researched Sub places on Yelp and I came across a place calledSub Brothers, so I decided to check them out.Sub Brothers is a pretty small storefront on Morse, a few doors awayfrom the Red Line Stop and as I entered I was greeted by 2 really niceguys, and yes, the resemblance was uncanny so I'm presuming that's howthe name Sub Brothers came to be.Now, this place does not have a large menu but they have about 10different sub varieties to choose from in either small or large size..A large runs about $5.99 and you can choose what you want on your sub..Well worth this most reasonable price!They also have gyros and burgers, fries etc.. but my advise would be toget yourself a sub from this place.The bread was fresh, no shortage of meat and the taste/quality was really good.The price was right and  the Customer Service was outstanding fromthese 2 really great guys..Also, if you choose to dine in there are only like 5 booths/tables availablefor seating, definitely more of a take-out place!So, if you are in the Rogers Park area you should give Sub Brothers a try..I'm sure glad I did..:)

18.description: I ordered the Bacon Cheese Burger with all the toppings, with fries and a grape soda. Everything tasted excellent, very Old School with some of the toppings under the burger. I had just as much bacon as burger which is excellent. It may have been Turkey bacon or Canadian bacon. After trying all of the small eats near the Morse Red line I decided that this place was worth yelping for-shore =)

13.description: Not really a destination, but a great neighborhood spot. The sandwiches are delicious and cheap. The brothers are so nice and they keep their space clean. They are consistent and do not disappoint. You feel good giving them business and you feel good eating their food.

4.description: Have lived in rogers park for 4 years, and this place is one of my staples. To be fair, I only get 1 thing. It's the philly cheese, fries, and a cup of cheese. Good god that sub is amazing. I don't know what it is, but I tell everyone new to the neighborhood about this place. Plus, the owners are always working, and are some of the friendliest people in rogers park. SUPPORT THIS PLACE!

24.description: Perfect for greasy hamburgers and fries when you are hungover. Does the trick to fix everything that ails you. Plus, you can get canned ginger ale there too.I had their double cheeseburger, and they made it right in front of my eyes. Nothing pre-made and sitting under a warmer here. Also had mozzarella sticks, another one of my hangover cures, and they were pretty good too. My roommate has had their chicken tenders and they are huge! And pretty filling as well, not too shabby for fried chicken.Overall, I don't think I would eat here on an average day, but if I was feeling like some stick to your ribs greasy food this place is perfect.

6.description: I moved back to RP a few months ago and have been working my way through the restaurants. I was in a hurry and decided to drop in here as I had not tried it yet and was pressed for time. I ordered a ham and turkey, which is really turkey ham and turkey, with all the trimmings. The bread is soft and delicious and the contents are generous. I agree with the other poster who said the Subway up here are more bread to contents but this is a very satisfying sammich! I will definitely be going back as the place is spotless, the two older gentlemen behind the counter are exactly that and my order (including onion rings) is simply delicious. It took than about 6 minutes to get my order together and I was on my way.One warning is they are cash only but there are a number of ATM's within a short walk.

15.description: What can I say, I love Sammiches.Sub Brothers makes some mighty fine and tasty Sammiches for a really great price. A large sandwich (footlong) will run you UNDER $6 bucks and a regular (six + inches) under $4 bucks. They do have other items like fried fish, pizza puffs and general stuff you can get anywhere else in the city..but nowhere else will you find a sandwich made with brotherly love like at sub brothers. The bread is a sesame bread and trust me..ask them to warm the bread. Warming the bread definitely changes the flavor of the bread and brings out the toasty-ness of the sesame seeds. All of their sandwiches come with your typical condiments so just make sure to let them know what you like and what you don't, they're very accommodating. The brothers sub often run specials for 2 gyros or 2 hot dogs for about 5 bucks. These specials also include a can of soda and fries. They have all varieties of soda..including grape crush (holler!). It honestly blows my mind to think that the Sub Brothers have not garnered more reviews. The brothers have been in Rogers Park for about 15 years serving these deeerishus Sammiches. I implore you to give the brothers a shot..but have cash with you because they be cash only..ya dig?

7.description: I had the gyro. It was amazing. The brothers are so polite and helpful. Place was clean. I'll be back!!!

8.description: Decent joint for a sub if you're in the area but not worth traveling any great distance. Good bread, meats and veggies on the sub, but very average tasting. Not enough ingredients between the bread. I was there at noon and the place was empty.

3.description: The reviews don't lie, i have couple moths at Rogers Park and I've trying some spots by the area but this place just blow me away. I was greeting by one of the friendly guys he was smiling at the counter(very important). I asked the sub brothers subway, It was soo yummi and it was big and the price was reasonable. Of curse, i will come back.P.S this guys need more bussines

14.description: The owner-operators of Sub Brothers are two kind gentlemen whose resemblance is so striking you'll never question why their joint carries its name.The food is good and hot, the place is clean and bright.  The menu caters to your meat and fries or onion ring cravings.

28.description: Lighthouse Tavern, where have you been all my life? I just recently stumbled into this Rogers Park dive with a friend of mine who lives a mere two blocks away. Why we had never discovered this place before, I do not know.The Lighthouse has been under its current management for 20 years, and it shows. Every poster, banner, or piece of art that has ever hung on the walls is still there, though some have been covered over by other pieces over the years. And all of it has a yellow patina, courtesy of 20 years of Marlboros. There's a lot of old "nautical" stuff -- maps of Lake Michigan, photos of guys in seafaring garb, some carved pieces. More recent additions to the decor include a shitload of sports memorabilia, much of it Sox-based. That's right Southsiders, here's your Rogers Park hangout! On top of that, add a bunch of standard bar kitsch from the 70s and 80s side-by-side with photos of regulars over the years, and you have an idea of the decor.There are two beers on tap, Old Style and Miller Lite. But they're $2.25 a pint, so how can you lose? Frozen pizza are available for 8 bucks, served piping hot from the pizza warmer. The urinal in the men's room doesn't flush, but it is regularly restocked with ice. And the proceedings are overseen by barmaid Eileen and her crusty old husband (?), whose name I didn't get.The Lighthouse is the kind of place that if you didn't know where it was, you wouldn't know it was there. There's no name out front (that I saw), just a lighthouse on a red/maroon awning. But now that you know where it's at, you owe it to yourself to go there.

1.description: Not impressed at all. The Gin and Tonic was weak and the tonic was flat. My wife's beer was good until the mold spore from the tapper ended up in her mouth. It's too bad. They have a great location and the night we were there they had a great little jazz band playing. We stayed for two songs then cut.Based on this experience I will not be trying them again.

9.description: Just moved to the area and decided to stop in for a drink.  The atmosphere was so great that we stayed for multiple rounds.  The bartender got our names and noticed we were out of towners and welcomed us to the neighborhood AND bought us 2 rounds of drinks.  Truly a Cheers type of place, my wife and I will be back here for sure.  The locals recommended many local restaurants and were honestly excited for us to come back.  Loved this place and will for sure be back

29.description: This is located in the same building as Quest Network Services, so I stop in there every once in a while. I've hosted meetup groups of 15 - 30 people and brought them in twice a month from 2008 - 2012, and a good time was had by all!

23.description: Great little place to stop in for drinks,right off the lakefront,people friendly.

5.description: Great place!  Small, cozy feel. Good crowd, and we had a pitcher bought for us on the first visit. Bar tender is a really nice guy.

25.description: Ah... the lighthouse. This place is the most neighborhoody old man dive bar ever. That's a good thing. How do I love thee? I'll count em:1. Cheap drinks- not the greatest beer selection, but you can't have everything.2. Employees- the bartenders are great. They'll remember your drink after your first visit.3. Patrons- Fun mix of people who live in the neighborhood, people who used to live in the 'hood and people who somehow stumbled upon this little Eden of drunkenness. The last group usually has this delighted little smile on their face as they walk in the door.4. Location- it's great having a bar nearby that you can crawl home from. Or walk barefoot if you lose a shoe.Bonus- now that I quit smoking it helps that it no longer has that stale smoke mixed with stale beer aroma. Just stale beer. One caveat- I have noticed the occasional brazen little critter walking on the bar. Hopefully you're not squeamish.

12.description: New management. Better than it used to be. Still a little freaky tho.

21.description: Yeah, this place is pretty cool.  I swear we didn't hear a song recorded any later than 1976 the whole time we were there.  Also the staff was super friendly and the place is cheap.  I like this joint.

16.description: Non douchbag bar is right! Great mix of good people. Bartender is extremely friendly. Love this place. Just the right mix of cool and dive.

17.description: I had been curious about this place since jogging by it in the summertime. Contending with a severe case of cabin fever one winter evening, I finally decided to 'enter the void' and found it to be pleasantly relaxing. The regulars were colorful, friendly and most curious to know what brought me into their universe.  Donald was the most skilled bartender, and I not referring to mixology of course, but at being what all great dive bars require: an unlicensed therapist.

10.description: This bar is great for what it is.  If you are in the neighborhood and want to hang out for a few drinks, you can do it here.  It is small, but not usually that busy.  If you don't know where it is, you will never know it is there, as it is on a dead end street by the lake.  The bartender was friendly and I will definitely come back here to hang out with visiting friends from out of town.

11.description: Need sage advice? Meatballs of wisdom? This is the place. A sampling from last night: "Self pity. That's a room with no doors," attributed, with permission, to Ulysses Scott, one of my favorite regulars at the neighborhood gin mill, The Lighthouse, Chicago. Need guidance? Talk to Scotty.

26.description: I first discovered this hidden gem when living just down the street. Get joint for a ballgame, as they play both Sox and Cubs here. The taps say it all, Old Style and Miller, with the team flair to denote the division within this glorious little dive. Cheap and hospitable, this is a nice place to spend a rainy afternoon or happy hour. Juke is solid, mostly due to compilations by the owners and regulars. I mean how often do you put on The Who's "My Wife" and share a drink with a chap who it may really be his theme song that day?This place should be protected as a landmark. It's the last safe haven to the north.

27.description: If you go here once in your life, make sure it's the day of the Kentucky Derby.  But don't bother unless you're dressed to the nines.

0.description: This is maybe the best bar in the whole world. I walked in a stranger and walked out as a friend.

20.description: Lighthouse Tavern, you harbor some of the creepiest old people ever.  Maybe it's just me, but every time I have set foot in this bar, I have had to watch a very old man make out with a middle aged woman.  Drunk old people making out is not cool.  Not cool at all.This bar is mega-divey.  It really looks like someone's livingroom that they just so happened to put a bar in the middle of it.  The drinks are cheap, but the beer is limited.  Also, make sure to bring cash because they don't take credit cards.  I think the bartenders there are great though.  They do make you feel at home.So if you are looking for a small bar where you can find a relatively strange mix of people that may or may not have mullets and make out with old people, this is your bar!

19.description: Lighthouse Tavern, where have you been all my life? I just recently stumbled into this Rogers Park dive with a friend of mine who lives a mere two blocks away. Why we had never discovered this place before, I do not know.The Lighthouse has been under its current management for 20 years, and it shows. Every poster, banner, or piece of art that has ever hung on the walls is still there, though some have been covered over by other pieces over the years. And all of it has a yellow patina, courtesy of 20 years of Marlboros. There's a lot of old "nautical" stuff -- maps of Lake Michigan, photos of guys in seafaring garb, some carved pieces. More recent additions to the decor include a shitload of sports memorabilia, much of it Sox-based. That's right Southsiders, here's your Rogers Park hangout! On top of that, add a bunch of standard bar kitsch from the 70s and 80s side-by-side with photos of regulars over the years, and you have an idea of the decor.There are two beers on tap, Old Style and Miller Lite. But they're $2.25 a pint, so how can you lose? Frozen pizza are available for 8 bucks, served piping hot from the pizza warmer. The urinal in the men's room doesn't flush, but it is regularly restocked with ice. And the proceedings are overseen by barmaid Eileen and her crusty old husband (?), whose name I didn't get.The Lighthouse is the kind of place that if you didn't know where it was, you wouldn't know it was there. There's no name out front (that I saw), just a lighthouse on a red/maroon awning. But now that you know where it's at, you owe it to yourself to go there.

2.description: Very nice little divey bar in Rogers Park just off Sheridan Rd. and Chase. Seriously, you wouldn't know this place is there unless you were looking for it. Cash only, but there's an ATM inside. Super cheap drinks and a cozy, welcoming vibe. Be sure to go here when the jazz trio is playing: they're the best part!

18.description: Ah... the lighthouse. This place is the most neighborhoody old man dive bar ever. That's a good thing. How do I love thee? I'll count em:1. Cheap drinks- not the greatest beer selection, but you can't have everything.2. Employees- the bartenders are great. They'll remember your drink after your first visit.3. Patrons- Fun mix of people who live in the neighborhood, people who used to live in the 'hood and people who somehow stumbled upon this little Eden of drunkenness. The last group usually has this delighted little smile on their face as they walk in the door.4. Location- it's great having a bar nearby that you can crawl home from. Or walk barefoot if you lose a shoe.Bonus- now that I quit smoking it helps that it no longer has that stale smoke mixed with stale beer aroma. Just stale beer. One caveat- I have noticed the occasional brazen little critter walking on the bar. Hopefully you're not squeamish.

13.description: Divey-est dive bar. I am sort of sure that there isn't even a sign on the awning...  Anyways, it's great and a big mix of ages and friendly people. Just remember to close the door behind you as there is no hydraulic door closure thingamajiggy. :)

4.description: I love this bar! It feels like the Cheers bar.  Everyone is really great and super nice.  It's easy to miss though.  The first time I found this wonderful little gem, I thought it may have been someone's basement bar.  Turn towards the lake,  this place is amazing!

24.description: I love this place, scratch that - I love the people that work and play here. It isn't fancy, they don't have the best selection of beers but they do have great regulars, a pretty good jukebox and it's cheap.

6.description: I'm from downstate. Sometimes I crave a really solid neighborhood bar. The glitz of chicago has it's place, but so does the Lighthouse.This is not a dive. They have craft beers. They have knowledgeable staff. They are nautical and reasonable with prices.There is no food, but you can order in.I reserve a 5th star for lack of parking and only taking cash.Otherwise, this is a laid back, nautical,  neighborhood, homerun.

22.description: There really aren't any taverns left on the north side that can beat the Lighthouse.It's cheap, friendly and the bartenders remember you and what you drink after your first visit.  It's nothing fancy, but it sure is a comfy little dive.  I love it!

15.description: Lighthouse Tavern, you harbor some of the creepiest old people ever.  Maybe it's just me, but every time I have set foot in this bar, I have had to watch a very old man make out with a middle aged woman.  Drunk old people making out is not cool.  Not cool at all.This bar is mega-divey.  It really looks like someone's livingroom that they just so happened to put a bar in the middle of it.  The drinks are cheap, but the beer is limited.  Also, make sure to bring cash because they don't take credit cards.  I think the bartenders there are great though.  They do make you feel at home.So if you are looking for a small bar where you can find a relatively strange mix of people that may or may not have mullets and make out with old people, this is your bar!

7.description: I just moved to the neighborhood in October, and in trying to get the lay of the land, I heard about this bar. None of my friends who lived in the neighborhood had been here, and only half had heard of it, so I decided to scout it out since its only 2 blocks from me.I instantly saw why so few of my friends knew/heard about this place. It's hidden almost down an alley at the back of a building that appears to have no business containing a bar. Shaking off the feeling I may soon be stabbed, I went in....and I'm glad I did.The space is small, but didn't feel crowded. Heavy, HEAVY, nautical theme that's aging, but not so in your face as to detract from the experience. Its obviously a place that caters to regulars, but hey, what RO-PA bar doesn't? Half the place was 40-50 yr old gents watching football while the rest was the local hipster set, who actually seemed to mix ok.The bar is small, but well stocked. A nice mix of mostly German imports and mid level locals were on draft. Bottle beer selection looked ok, and mixed drink options looked respectable. The highlights for me were that the bar tender could actually pull a Guinness pour the way its supposed to be pulled, something that I hadn't found yet since the move. The bartender also randomly ordered a pizza for the whole bar on him, and random patrons actually asked me to have some. How many places have you been of late that do that?Not trying to oversell the place. Its shabby, and super hole in the wall, but in a good way. Like your favorite uncle's basement den you hung out in on holiday's while the adults had there time upstairs....except now there's beer.

8.description: Decent beer selection.  Very small.  If you don't live in the area, you would miss it.  They don't have a big sign at all, so I guess it only caters to local neighbors.

3.description: I like this place. It has the right feel of cozy and welcoming, spacious even though it is small (the giant bar might contribute to that feel) and very friendly bartenders.I discovered this place because they have a piano night every so often with Barrel House Chuck and Robert Harvey playing boogie woogie and blues on keys and they are both excellent. Anytime I'm up here I try to stop in for a drink as they always take care of me and I feel welcome.Big ocean/nautical theme going on if you are into that sort of thing. Almost gave it an East Coast feel. They are kind of tucked away -- you need to know they are at the corner of *that* building in *that* spot. They recently put a sign out to help and I hope that doesn't jar the cozy cheers feel of the place.

14.description: Awesome neighborhood hole in the wall bar. Located in the rear of an apartment building makes it slightly hard to find, but worth looking. I've only been in this establishment for the after work crowd and it was an awesome mix of friendly (and intoxicated) old men. BTW the Tuesday/Wednesday bartender is great, and if your good at math you can easily figure out how long he has worked there.

1.description: I've been searching for a go-to Chinese place for years now. After reading a few reviews, we decided to give this one a go. We were pleasantly surprised. Do not let the less than attractive facade fool you. This place is pretty good. Especially liked the Singapore Noodles. Excellent portion sizes. Obviously a family run operation. The kids were pitching in when I came in for my to-go order. Friendly and polite.

9.description: This place was amazing!! From customer service to amazing food! We were very pleased with this find. We ordered the orange chicken dinner plate and the Mongolian beef dinner plate. The portions are huge! And cheap. Loved it!

23.description: Right down the middle of the road.  If I were taking a customer satisfaction survey, I would reply "Meets Expectations" for just about every facet of the restaurant.Service is exactly what you would expect.  Not too cold, not too warm.  Although, I will say that one time, my food was ready in the promised 15 minutes except that they left the egg roll for the end, which took an additional 7-8 minutes.  Not much in the grand scheme, but poor kitchen management.Prices are tough to beat--$1.95 for small soup, most small main dishes in the $3.75 range.Fried shrimp:  C, too greasy and breadyEgg drop soup:  B+, surprisingly flavorful but not saltyEgg roll:  C, vegetables should be crisperMoo shoo:  C+, again vegetables seem overcookedChicken with snow peas:  B-, fresh vegetables, somewhat blandShrimp fried rice:  B-, tasty but not too heavy or greasy, needs more vegetables

12.description: Great food. Always a good buy. Alot of food in portions.  But most chinese places are. I eat here like once a week and always get something diffrent. I havent been disappointed yet

21.description: cheap and inexpensive. great place for your typical chinese-american food. definitely check it out. in this economy, my place for some quick eats!!!!

16.description: My wife and I were not impressed when Hong Kong Restaurant went under new management.  Overall, the food wasn't as good as before in both taste and quality.  However, today we were craving Chinese food, so we placed a carry out order.  What a difference a few months makes; the food was delicious, ready on time, and service was great!!  We are happy to have our go to Chinese food restaurant back :)

17.description: A group of three of us came and ordered General's chicken, orange chicken, salt and pepper shrimp, broccoli and pea pods, and crab rangoon.  It was a lot of food for not that much money.  Of the entrees, the orange chicken was the best.  It was so very tasty!  The crab rangoon were also excellent, with little pieces of imitation crab meat in a creamy filling.  We will defiantly be back for some more inexpensive, delicious food.

10.description: Good chinese probably the most authentic in the area. Quality is good and service is always nice.

5.description: We'd eaten at Hong Kong Restaurant before as walk-in diners and were really impressed with it, despite the less than exciting store front, but when we ordered in, we were very pleased.  We got the family special for two and ended up with a metric TON of food, all of which was extremely fresh, hot, and tasty.  It's one of the few places we've eaten where the chicken fried rice had large enough chunks of chicken that you could tell what they were.  The only drawback was that the beef dish only had a few pieces of beef, but there was so much of everything that it really didn't matter.  Definitely worth the price (which is also ridiculously low, by the way)!

11.description: This was a ton of food. Came on time and very hot.Here's what I ordered:-shrimp with pea pods-shrimp with cashews -crab langoon-general tsaos -house special chow funThe shrimp was good, I got the half portions, still a lot of food...very hot, fresh and flavorful. The crab rangoons were some of the better rangoons that I have had, I'm very particular about the size and creaminess level of these. general tsaos was crispy and sweet, I got it non spicy. The house chow fun was by far my favorite, yummy noodles with a ton of stuff.Good chinese

22.description: Never again.  I ordered from Hong Kong because I read that they were fast and inexpensive.  Inexpensive, yes, but it has been over an hour and my food is still not here.  They are less than a mile from my house.  I just got a call from the driver.  He told me that he is on his way.  There are better places in Rogers Park, maybe more expensive, but who cares.

0.description: Best Chinese food in Rogers park!!!! Delivery is Prompt, and the food is Always on point!!! Best smoothies I've had in Chicago period. Even better than Joy yee. Yea, I said it!!! If u live in the neighborhood, do yourself a favor, and give it a try!

20.description: I've eaten here twice and both meals were take out. The first meal I had was Sweet and Sour Chicken Dinner combo. The sweet and sour chicken had the sauce poured on it already which in my opinion makes it soggy by the time you get home. Also staplilng the lid down does the same thing b/c it traps all the steam in and makes the dish soggy. The taste was good though.
