Largest mozzarella sticks I've ever seen with a nice light batter!! Was told they make them there!! We had a sausage pizza, which had a great ratio of sauce to cheese - nice crisp crust too!! Had to try the spaghetti & meatballs....huge portion...meat sauce and 2 large meatballs. Not as good as my Grandmother's, but a nice substitute if I need a fix.  Service was friendly, attentive, perfect....even though they had large Northwestern team in for lunch at the same time. Impressive!

41.description: Restaurant is clean and service is good. I used to come here often as a kid with my parents and it had been several years since we had been back due to moving. The food is good, not great. My parents and I agreed the food is not the same as years back. They no longer have their awesome homemade chocolate swirl cookies, and the pasta sauce is just okay. Alfredo was not very tasty. I order pizza here since it is nearby and really enjoy their margarita pizza (it's not a classic margarita pizza--it has pesto). Pizzas are pretty decent!

52.description: Talk about not even trying anymore. This place used to be great but now it's crap. The food is of such low quality that you wonder if they are hiring retired school cafeteria cooks to slop garbage into boxes. We ordered online which is a disappointment because if we were in the restaurant we could have sent it back and refused to pay for what they were trying to pass off as food.Calamari Fritti aka. fried garbage with some calamari and a side of canned marinara. You won't know what it is anyway because of all the oil, which makes everything taste like Jiffy lube was sponsoring the appetizers.Romano Jumbo Tenders Dinner aka Wet chicken dinner at is slightly under cooked and void of flavor. Not to worry, you get you choice of two dipping sauces that are straight from a bottle.Avocado Burger aka A $5.00 burger that they charge double for.Just avoid this disappointment, I don't know if the original owners passed away or sold the business. Maybe a head injury was involved and they just forgot what it takes to have a good restaurant in this city. It's only a matter of time before this place folds.

50.description: Tried Leona's for their Monday special, all pizzas half off after 5pm. They had a new menu since I was last there which looked good and has several items that make me want to go back. The pizza was very good and you definitely can't beat the price. The service is very hit or miss and the wait time for your food is always long even when they're not busy.

4.description: My son is not happy with the new menu. Also food is not as meticulously packed with delivery

6.description: After staying away for over a year, I decided to try Leona's while I was out looking for food following a long day at work.It turns out that the food remains entirely unremarkable and certainly not worth the money.  Looks like I won't be back for a while, despite it being stupidly convenient for me to go to.

22.description: Wow...this place is an absolute joke anymore.  Don't waste your time or money.  We just received a delivery order which was incomplete.  The delivery  driver merely shrugged it off like it wasn't his issue.  When we phoned to get the issue corrected, we were told they could send out the missing items "within an hour" or give a credit toward our next order.  First of all, there will not be a future order.  Second, that is some scan you have working there Leona's...let's take their money then not deliver the goods.  Terrible customer service and food is only mediocre at best anymore.  Used to love this place but this is absolutely the last time.

15.description: We recently visited here for the second time, and we have been pleased with both experiences. The first time we were here, the food was very good, both ordering pasta dishes. The service was good. The last time we were here, we went for Wednesday 5.00 spaghetti dinner, which was awesome! The sauce is great, and you get a huge portion! The service the second time was a little better than the first, I think it had to do with the personality between both servers, they were both nice, but I would prefer our second waitperson if I had to choose. The decor is very Italian, and the overall experience is one that will keep us coming back!

57.description: Years ago service was 4 star and since then servers do not put there all in to there job..until today. Lionel our server was absolutely outstanding. He added such a personal touch to our dinner and made you feel how great it can be to just sit down and relax. Leona ' s you need to recognize Lionel ' s outstanding customer service and have him train all the staff he is your most valuable asset. On the other hand we enjoyed the pizza but the catfish plate was a bit small on the portions :(   We will return to dine "especially if Lionel is our server ".

20.description: Horrible experience. We went there on a Saturday evening and the place was not even that crowded. Service was extremely slow, however. I ordered a baked mac and cheese lasagna for myself and regular mac and cheese for my daughter. We told them repeatedly that we did NOT want any bacon in the pasta. When the pastas arrived mine had bits of bacon in it and my daughter's was loaded with bacon. The waiter apologized and said that he will have them cooked again, and that they would be ready shortly. We waited and waited for half an hour and my daughter (4 year old) ended up eating bread and butter since she was so hungry. While we were eating there were multiple flies flying around our table (be reminded that we were indoors) We were completely disgusted by this. To top it all, at the end of the meal we were overcharged for my daughter's meal (they counted it twice in the check). Suffice it to say that we will not return!!!!

36.description: Dismal experience. Will not return. Service was slow and our waiter did not seem to care about our table.  I had to ask for both water and silverware. It took probably about 10 minutes for the waiter to even come to our table to greet us, and the restaurant was not understaffed--I could see straight into the prep area and several waitstaff were just standing there and shooting the you know what.  Took another 15 to get the water and our first round of drinks.  The food was mediocre...sauce tasted like it was several days old and we all generally felt icky after eating here.   Plus, the prices, given the location and quality of the food and experience, are *ridiculous* for what you get.

14.description: Soggy chopped salad which took 40 minutes to make? No thank you. I'm never coming back here.

28.description: I give Bruno's 4 stars because I am an "irregular" (have been there enough times to know the bartender and patrons, but the regulars are there almost everyday), otherwise, if it's your first time there, I would probably give it 3 stars.  Bruno's is a bar on one side and a package liquor store on the other.  The liquore store is always busy with Loyola students, but the bar is not usually as busy.  You can always count on being in good company and in good service from the bartender.  It is dark and smokey (until now) and has an interesting crowd - a few students, a few alum, a few neighborhood regulars and a few randoms)  I find it particularly amusing to watch the students go past the windows in the fall, when they travel in packs of about 20.  However, Bruno's is just a comfortable, come - as-you-are for a beer kind of place.  They have several TVs and they watch any type of sports possible.  They have a wide variety of beers and mixed drinks, but none of the beers are on tap.  If you want a laid-back evening with some very reasonble drink and beer prices with no attitude, Bruno's is the place. (did I mention that the drinks get stronger as the night gets longer?)   PS - If your bartender is named Marty, he'll take good care of you!

1.description: This is definitely a dive bar, as everyone can attest. There's a blue collar crowd that keeps to themselves. Drinks are cheap, service is quick, and there still manages to be a good beer selection. Stick to beer and you'll be ok.

9.description: All the negative reviews are right (dimly lit, fuckin weird/homeless clientele, cash only [WHAT?!], overpriced, racist). But the worst part?NO BEER ON TAP. WHY THE HELL AM I GOING TO GO TO A BAR WITH NO BEER ON TAP.NO BEER ON TAPNO BEER ON TAP.WHO'S GOING TO GO TO A BAR WITH NO TAP? NOBODY.IF YOU'RE A NOBODY, YOU'RE PROBABLY AT THIS BAR WITH NO BEER ON TAP.

29.description: You would think a bar that is directly across from the Loyola campus would be filled with Loyola students.  This is not the case at Bruno's.  Bruno's is an oasis for those Rogers Park locals who don't want to deal with stupid drunk college kids.  Although, they do have a liquor store attached to the bar that almost never cards.... go figure.

23.description: It's a nice little bar. Sometimes there are too many depressing old men drinking by themselves, but otherwise a nice place to drink.

5.description: This is a half bar and half liquor store!! The bar has never interested me it looks like an older crowd type bar. It's also a very small bar but tends to be empty majority of the time. I'm a regular in liquor store portion which it's ok. They have a decent selection of beer and liquor but they over price things horribly. Due to the fact that it's in a college town with the kids not knowing any better and just trying to score alcohol.

31.description: Slashie.Oh yes.Great selection of cold beers and lotsa liquor.All reasonably priced (if I do say so myself).Oh and the bar side is pretty wonderfully divey. My friend and I, just passing through at the time, vowed to return. Its been a couple weeks and we haven't made it back but I'm postive it will be entertaining.And I'll be sure to update my review like a good little Yelper.

25.description: Martell by the glass.Friendly patrons.You can read if you like.Dangerously close to campus.Damn near perfect, if you ask me.

12.description: It is what it is. I don't get the posts whining about the place, especially from those who should know what Bruno's is (Loyola students, Rogers Park people). There's no specials. Or food. It's an all around decent bar whose bartenders and clientele who are going to change for no one. There's always sports on and it's a laid back place where you can focus on the game or have a conversation with whoever's with you. As a bar, it's not typically on my radar, but if someone wants to go there, it works. The liquor store mainly is a last resort that benefits from its proximity to the el. Prices on average stuff isn't good, but that's what you get for a place that caters to Loyola students (many of which are underage).

21.description: The two most important ingredients of my party life at Loyola were 40s of Big Bear and six packs of Schlitz, dutifully purchased in combination here for $6 on the dot.  Hell, it was so ubiquitous that they even stopped carding me.  Good times!One year after graduating I come back in and there's no Big Bear or Schlitz cans to be found.  The Bill M Loyola Special cannot exist any more and it was like a searing dagger through my heart.  Stunned by the total loss of innocence I look through the cooler and see what actually IS there; the 40 of Mickey's and sixer of High Life, though I guess admirable in their own regard, just don't cut it.  It cost me $7.75 (and a flash of an ID) to find out that Bruno's has moved on without me.  Bummer.

16.description: This place is hardly ever busy and there's a few reasons for it. None of which are all that bad. Numero uno: Bruno, the man, is a bit of a sarcastic asshole.  Which is refreshing, however, it can be entirely frustrating when all you need to know is how much for a Jamo and water. I am not Irish, I know. I'm American. I bleed Lincoln, thanks guy. Numero Dos: the bathrooms may as well not exist. It has best been described as "trying to pee under the stairs in a cramped room at grandmas house." Oh so true. Numero tres: they just slapped a $2 raise on almost all of the booze in the store attached to the bar. WTF? Students are back, I get it, but what about all the loyal alcoholics who have crawled begrudgingly to your humble abode through the cold winter days when no student would have you? You have price penetrated me from behind Bruno, not cool. However, since I live so damn close, I shall be back. The overall atmosphere of the bar is laid back and sometimes it just can't be beat. Plus, you can shoot the shit with professors almost any night of the week which can always be interesting.

17.description: The guys behind the counter are very efficient at being rude and disinterested in doing their job.

10.description: Best bar in Rogers Park.  Great local crowd, and great bartenders.  Great prices for beers and cocktails... old school shot-and-beer type of place.  Neighborhood joints like this are dying out, but these guys keep the local option alive and well.

11.description: The owner Tim is a blatant racist and by going here you are supporting this. Please use your money to patronize a more deserving bar. A friend of mine overheard Bruno call black people "monkeys"  in response to a television ad featuring African Americans.Before ever even hearing this, I went and got a very, very weird vibe from Tim(I am Asian and was with a white girl)- despite him being polite to others. I actually thought it could have been racism at the time, but I brushed it off- until I heard this little ditty. Please don't go here. Also it is just gross and depressing.

26.description: I go here out of necessity.The scripted "Lounge" name painted on the windows always makes me laugh...it's the kind of lounge you'd find in a bowling alley...will peeling floor tiles and an "eclectic mix" in the jukebox.  But the fact of the matter is, it's just freakin' convenient, especially after a night class when you want to continue to debate the merits of Karl Marx and/or Max Weber with your favorite group of nerds...I mean friends.They have a full bar, beer in bottles, and 4 tvs that play a variety of nightly games.  The regulars are welcoming, the bartenders good at what they do, and it's seen many an excellent conversation in my experience.It's cash-only which can be irksome to some, but an ATM is right there in the building...and the women's bathroom is the most awesome shade of hot pink I've seen in a long time.This place just does the job and it seems to revel in its "okay"-ness. The fact of the matter is, they could care less if you come or go.  But when you're there, they take care of ya. That's why I gave it 3 stars and not 4.  I had the feeling that if they knew I'd given it 4, Brunos would be angry.  And I couldn't do that to them.

27.description: Not the kind of place you'd plan a night around, but a perfectly friendly and cozy place for a quick beer before or after someplace else.  No beer on tap, but bottles and other mixed drinks are very fairly priced.  Also, bringing outside food in is no problem, which is great.

0.description: So, this place has been here for decades, but I went here for the first time last weekend, despite also being a former resident of Rogers Park! So, Bruno's waited patiently for me.Was set to order a bottle of Schlitz, as is my M.O. for dive bars, but my charming companion was allll "Bloody Mary!" Okay, I'm susceptible to peer pressure, so Bloody Mary it is!I'm here to tell you (thankfully I lived to tell) that this was the worst Bloody that either of us had ever tasted. I was shocked at how bad it was. I think the mix was old or something, because it looked sorta brownish. Not savory or salty at all, and no garnish whatsoever. We had to ask for olives. And here's a little PSA: When you take the olives out of the jar - preferably with a toothpick, not a knife - don't roll them around in your fingers before you place them on the BAR MAT, before you roll them around some more in your fingers and put them in the drink.I'm not taking off stars for this however, because - my bad - don't get all fancy when you go to a dive bar, just stick to bottled beer. Which I did - and we did both manage to suck down those bad Bloody Marys, so there's that. This place has so much more appeal - just DO NOT order Bloody Marys. Chilled bottles of Schlitz in hand, we spend an hour or so chatting with the bartender (who is fine, but don't order Bloody Marys) a neighborhood resident for a LONG time. This place is great (except for those damn Bloodies). Truly a neighborhood DIVE bar - down to the sets of keys. Keys that belong to people who live in the 'hood in case they get locked out. Super cool idea.  So, go here! Besides those goddamned Bloody Marys the place is pretty clean, and there are many TVs for watching sports, if you're into that sort of thing, and there's a package store in the other half. The place has been here forever, and therefore it is good. But, for the love of dog, just order a Schlitz!

20.description: Love the store portion, the selection is pretty decent. Never been to the bar and to be honest I am too afraid to go to the bar portion; everyone there is over 40. The awkward small talk with the two guys ringing you up is the best, I always wonder which one is Bruno and which one is Tim (or maybe none of them are). Random side note, they hired two new guys recently, a young dude and an old guy, it definitely shocked me seeing the usual guys there.

19.description: So my buddy and I decided we need to try out a new a bar. So why not go down to  probably the only combo bar and liquor store. Seriously it's split right down the friggin middle one half bar and the other a liquor store...it's quite comical  upon first sight....Anyways, I didn't find much for this place to offer other than leaving with a decently priced 6 pack....Most of the depressed patrons seemed to be living the Loyola "dream" and when I say this I mean for the past +30 years...Seriously I am not kidding again....Old dudes wearing their vintage Loyola apparel and getting too fricken hammered....don't expect to find much of a young crowed here...the only person around our age saw was a mid 20 something chick who was eating up what these drunken married men were telling her....oh and the lighting was pretty horrible considering the the bar is dark and you have these intense lights from the liquor store which always blinding a corner of your eye....Honestly one time was enough for me....

2.description: WARNING: THIS IS AN ACTUAL DIVE BARI am not a dive bar person but understand they hold their place in life.I have been here twice in the last five years. Mostly because I have a friend from NYC who likes to come here as a refuge from his mother in law when he is in town and that is when I come here.The beer dont cost much. some cab drivers use this as their refuge. When I was there last 3 weeks ago it looked like Saddam Hussein's look alike's were having a a get together or at least guys that looked quasi related. I approached them and they told me that they are cab drivers from a certain cab co and come here right after their long shift. Now that makes more sense.You should not come here expecting great service or to see that many women show up. You are in the wrong bar for that.This reminds me of a bar that I used to wait at the train station in Hicksville,NY back in the day where everyone was missing at least a few teeth.A person should go here just for posterity

18.description: Great low key place to go for a cold one. I once asked the bartender what beer they had and his reply was "I got a whole store next door, I got whatever you want" which was the best reply.They have free wifi and are accommodating with the sports on tv. Why go out of the neighborhood when Bruno and Tim's will take care of you for much cheaper.

13.description: Place is a hell hole with overpriced booze and terrible selection. Great location though.

4.description: This is a dive bar.  Good place to hang out and get a Pabst or an Old Style before a game at Loyola.

24.description: I loved going to this place when I live in Rogers Park!  It was actually a great place to go on a date after dinner, you could carry on a conversation without shouting, and the obnoxious college student crowd was kept to a minimum.  Calling it a "lounge" is a bit of a stretch, it's just a great dive bar.

6.description: What a crap-hole. The only thing this place has going for it is its proximity to Loyola.

22.description: After finishing our class meeting for my History Junior Colloquium, one of my classmates (the only one within striking distance of my age) asked me to have a drink with her at Bruno's.  I guffawed and confessed that even in my first stint at Loyola I never went to Bruno's.  But, it was close, so we stopped in for a few beers to celebrate.  I ordered us a couple beers and the bartender had a hard time with the total...no biggie.  I tipped him 100% on the round (I figure those guys don't do real well by poor Loyola students) but got no thanks or even a nod out of it.  I ordered another round and only tipped him 50%.  I know, I'm such a cheap bastard, right?After a little while, the bartender ended his shift and the old Rogers Park institution, Tim, the owner of Bruno's, sidled behind the bar to take over.  Linda ordered another round from Tim and brought the beers over to our table.  Tim and the other old men in the place were watching the news on the TVs.  Needless to say, much of the coverage was on the election of Barack Obama.  At one point, Tim piped up, rather loudly, "Well, look at that, Barack's done more work in two days than 99% of the people who voted for him have ever done!"  This got a big laugh out of the regulars.Now, I know that Bruno's is what it is...it's and old man bar plus Cash n' Carry.  The only high-brow conversation in the place was between Linda and I, discussing our grad school plans and the conflicts between different Latin American ethnic groups.  I don't expect much out of Bruno's , but I was floored by Tim's open racism, considering that there were two newcomers in the bar.  I also know that Tim doesn't give a flying f**k what I think, but I just want others to be aware of what kind of guy they're giving their money to by patronizing Bruno's Lounge in Rogers Park.

15.description: After finishing our class meeting for my History Junior Colloquium, one of my classmates (the only one within striking distance of my age) asked me to have a drink with her at Bruno's.  I guffawed and confessed that even in my first stint at Loyola I never went to Bruno's.  But, it was close, so we stopped in for a few beers to celebrate.  I ordered us a couple beers and the bartender had a hard time with the total...no biggie.  I tipped him 100% on the round (I figure those guys don't do real well by poor Loyola students) but got no thanks or even a nod out of it.  I ordered another round and only tipped him 50%.  I know, I'm such a cheap bastard, right?After a little while, the bartender ended his shift and the old Rogers Park institution, Tim, the owner of Bruno's, sidled behind the bar to take over.  Linda ordered another round from Tim and brought the beers over to our table.  Tim and the other old men in the place were watching the news on the TVs.  Needless to say, much of the coverage was on the election of Barack Obama.  At one point, Tim piped up, rather loudly, "Well, look at that, Barack's done more work in two days than 99% of the people who voted for him have ever done!"  This got a big laugh out of the regulars.Now, I know that Bruno's is what it is...it's and old man bar plus Cash n' Carry.  The only high-brow conversation in the place was between Linda and I, discussing our grad school plans and the conflicts between different Latin American ethnic groups.  I don't expect much out of Bruno's , but I was floored by Tim's open racism, considering that there were two newcomers in the bar.  I also know that Tim doesn't give a flying f**k what I think, but I just want others to be aware of what kind of guy they're giving their money to by patronizing Bruno's Lounge in Rogers Park.

7.description: If you're an old, white, crotchety, racist, lowbrow goon, you will LOVE this place.  If you have at least an 8th grade education and all of your teeth, chances are this bar is NOT for you. This place is bad, stay away.

8.description: The bar is over-priced, though the bartender will tell you he can offer you the best prices in the area. He will refuse to tell the you the exact charge until after you have ordered and received your drink. The bar is cash only, dimly-lit, with bad fixtures and a nasty fluorescent liquor store a room over. No walls or doors separate the two. Worst of all, the bartender is super racist. When I was there I heard him call a famous black athlete in a Dr. Pepper ad a "monkey", and said that he and the other "monkeys" were going to start "drinking that shit like they do Hennesey". Disgusting

30.description: Cool lounge. Everybody knows everybody.Bruno is cool too.There's always sports on the TV, if that's what your into.There is also "a community laptop", if your in the know.

3.description: I returned to Chicago and stopped into Bruno's coming from the Loyola "L" stop.  I swear, one old guy was still sitting on the same stool.  I know Tim from St. Ignatius days, but he wasn't in.  I must say, nothing really changed.  Still cash n carry and higher prices than they should be in the package store, due to being across from Loyola U.  Nothing new.  I wonder what the place would become if they sold the bar ... something upscale and more accommodating to having women drop by.  Naw ... never happen.  Why ask why????

14.description: The two most important ingredients of my party life at Loyola were 40s of Big Bear and six packs of Schlitz, dutifully purchased in combination here for $6 on the dot.  Hell, it was so ubiquitous that they even stopped carding me.  Good times!One year after graduating I come back in and there's no Big Bear or Schlitz cans to be found.  The Bill M Loyola Special cannot exist any more and it was like a searing dagger through my heart.  Stunned by the total loss of innocence I look through the cooler and see what actually IS there; the 40 of Mickey's and sixer of High Life, though I guess admirable in their own regard, just don't cut it.  It cost me $7.75 (and a flash of an ID) to find out that Bruno's has moved on without me.  Bummer.

0.description: Evelyn Thompson is a great tour guide.We decided to stay in the Rogers Park area, but she said that she would do South side tours or Polish and Chinese grocery stores depending on what people were interested in. The tour started with the Rogers Park Fruit Market. This market caters to Jamaican/Caribbean clientele. Here we learned about some of the different types of white breads. They were half-leaven bread since when the bread and yeast was first introduced to the Caribbean the yeast did not do so well in the hot and humid conditions. The bread was pretty heavy and dense. The butcher had different cuts of goat for the locals. We tasted some epizote as well as saw some yucca and cactus pears that seemed to be common theme of all the markets. Two things we bought were a sweet lemon and a sour orange to try later at La UnicaSupermercado Chapala was the second stop of the tour. This Mexican grocery store sells fresh produce, memorable guacamole and specialty items such as Mexican sour cream. There is an eating area with about 10 little booths where you can eat some the best carnitas around and roast chicken. They also have a selection of tacos like cabeza tacos. The store was packed when we went in on a Monday morning, it might have been due to the heavy thunderstorm, but people looked pretty happy to be there.The next place was La Unica that has food for all types of Latin cuisine. Some of the unique items I saw were the quince and mango jellies that were sliced and place on crackers with cheese to provide a sweet contrast. Block and cone sugar and chocolate was interesting to see as well as purple corn. People of the Andes make a refreshing drink from purple corn called "chicha morada" which is now recognized as a nutritive powerhouse due to its phenolic content. The interesting thing was the eating area to the side. Walking past the store front, one would never know that it has a restaurant in the back. We took a little break and tried a few foods; yucca (pan fried?) with some picked onions and two types of plantains. The yucca was very starchy and dense. It tasted like a potato, but was a little grainier. I could see how the yucca could make food go a long way because it was filling. We also had a fried sweet yellow plantain that was tender almost creamy. The green plantain was lightly fried and then pounded flat and fried again. It was like a very dense potato chip with just a light hint of sweetness. The sweet lemon and a sour orange we bought from the Rogers Park Fruit Market added a nice amount of acidity to the plantains and cut some of fat. The rest of the menu was pretty varied including Cuban sandwiches and some Peruvian dishes. The next stop was the Devon Market that caters to mainly Eastern Europeans. Here we see a lot of the same fruit and vegetables. They have a wide variety of wines form Eastern European countries such as Romania. The great thing about this market is the freshly baked bread. As you start to approach the bread section, the scent of freshly baked bread begs you to take a look. From what I remember a huge loaf was about $1.59. They also had fresh bread stuffed with cheese, meat, spinach or a combination of the three.Thai Grocery store was next. In the back, they have a place where you can buy freshly fried fish. Other things of note that I saw were Thai eggplant and Luk Chup (fruit-shape desserts made of mung-bean flour with natural coloring). As we were walking out of the store, we saw a stack of the infamous durian. There were quite a few so I wondered who buys this on a regular basis.Middle East Bakery was the next stop. Here we got to see all sorts of interesting grains and lentils. This was the first time I saw red lentils and red rice. We sampled Za'atar which I had only seen on Iron Chef America.  They were many interesting desserts like a jar or nuts filled to the brim with honey and raisin and walnut sausage. Yes, I said sausage. They string raisins and walnuts together and dip it in honey to form multiple layers. Lastly the sample of fresh savory pastries stuff with chicken, broccoli, cheese, olives or a combination of the three was great. I hear that he sells these to Whole Foods. So you can actually buy from the source.The next two stops were Fresh Farms and Patel Bros on Devon. As you walk into each of these store you are bombarded with the scent of spices, it almost knocks you over. They had things that I had never seen like fresh red and white (no blue)  tumeric, black radishes and fresh dates. From looking at the freezer sections, it seems that you can get just about any For $35 you get to have a fun 4 hour tour, learn some new things, enjoy great company and best of all eat and experience new food. To top it off Evelyn drives so this is a great value. I would highly recommend this experience.

28.description: Rice was starting to turn, they still gave it to us, ended up in the trash before I we ate it, waste of $8.  Waiter/Cashier seemed like he could care less about you.  Place was dirty, seating too tight with those big tables. Really thought this place could do better, its Americanized Chinese food, if the food was good, I would have been able to overlook the deficiencies but the food was the worst part, next to the terrible service.  NOT RECOMMENDED

1.description: Food arrived on time with a very pleasant delivery person. The food was hot and pleasant to the eye. Vegetables were fresh tasting, meats, chicken and tofu , tender. But sadly everything was bland. Very, very bland. No hint of spices or ginger, although I do pick up garlic/ onions. Our hunt for good Chinese continues ...........

9.description: This food is incredible!!!  The guy who took our order, John, noticed that we were from North Carolina and from the same hometown. I will definitely go back and the customer service was impeccable!!!

29.description: What a refreshing change over typical delivery Chinese food on Chicago's North Side.  We picked up a menu from Fung's at this summer's Glenwood Ave. Arts Fest, having noted they were quick to be part of this great neighborhood event.   We finally got around to calling them for delivery last night.The short review is fresh ingredients, delicate sauces and far more complex flavors than is the norm.   Very tasty stuff!We tried pot stickers, crab rangoon, egg rolls, vegetable fried rice and a wonderful garden chicken entree, all of which exceeded our expectations.We could actually discern the individual ingredients in each item...quite a jump from a lot of  Chinese delivery, in which the flavors are so thoroughly blended you wonder how long it was simmering before being dished up for delivery.Yes, the price was slightly higher than other neighborhood option; however, the quality was a big step up and the portions certainly ample (looking forward to leftover lunch today).On top of that, delivery was fast, the driver was polite, and the food arrived screaming hot.We will be calling Fun's Mandarin again....give 'em a try!

23.description: Have tried Fung's a couple of times and have always been unimpressed. With other Chinese options close by I do not intend to order from them again.

5.description: We order at least once a week and it's always delicious! The eggplant in garlic sauce is awesome and the shrimp egg foo young is outstanding!

31.description: Been there three times. First time I went in for the grand opening special posted on the door. They said it was a lunch special, too late. I checked the sign on the door and it didn't mention that it was a lunch special, or have any restriction by hour. Nevertheless, I went ahead and ordered dinner.  Food and service were just average.Next time it was late evening. The sign said open, so I walked in to order takeout, they told me they were closed.  The last time I went was at lunchtime. I ordered the special that was still on the front door. They said it was no longer the special, so I walked out. I will never return.  Not a good way for a new restaurant to win friends and customers.

25.description: Does this place even exist? My boyfriend and I have tried ordering for picking up over the phone, and they did not answer. The funny thing was it was 7 pm on a Friday night. The hours on their menu said they were open till 11, but they didn't pick up the phone. Out of curiosity he walked over, and the door was locked so he knocked, and the guy in their shued him away with a confused look on his face. We began to think that maybe the restaurant was a cover for a drug operation.. Maybe we watched too much breaking, bad but come on..We have tried ordering a few times, and no luck. Oh well if a buisness shues you away, maybe its a sign not to eat their food. After reading some of these reviews I am kind of grateful we never spent our money there.

12.description: Average takeout Chinese place. Fast delivery. I got the chicken wings, eggplant and egg foo young. It was OK. Seems to cater more towards the American crowd

21.description: So first I should explain that my rating for tonights meal was a big fat 0! The only reason I gave them 2 stars is because I had eaten there 2 x before and it was ok (chicken almond was decent) but tonight it was so bad.  I ordered chicken wings and they were so old. Similar to when you have leftover chicken from the day before but when you re-heat it the next day it's just gross...at nearly $1 a pop I expect them to be fresh. The dish I had was also really bad, it really didn't have any taste at all, it was a brown sauce but what brown sauce.....I don't know.  I tried to add a few things myself (I ordered carryout) but it just wasn't salvageable.

16.description: I live close by so I decided to give this place a try now that they have reopened. It is worth mentioning that they have recently gone through a change and reopened the location earlier this summer. I am not sure about the review from last year but know going in it is a totally different menu. My order: Simple Chicken Lo Mein with a side of chicken satayThe Chicken Satay:The chicken satay should not be a appetizer as it is big enough to be a meal by itself. There are six skewers in this carton and each skewer has to contain one half of a chicken breast. It is heavy and well stocked. These are not measly in any way and a bit of a surprise. The flavoring is more on the smokey cherry side and the meat is extremely tender. These are perfectly cooked as far as I am concerned. The dipping sauce must be based in a chili oil because it has a definite bite to it that is pleasant but not overpowering. You will definitely notice it when you eat it. Personally I think the sauce could have more peanut flavor but the two still go very well together as the sweet and the spice mingle. The Chicken Lo Mein:Tasty but not overpowering with a generous amount of chicken and a good selection of julienne vegetables. Stir fried flat noodles are always good transporters of sauces and gravies and these do their job wonderfully. The noodles are very tender and hold up well without coming off as overcooked or mushy. They have enough texture so carry the flavor and still be "al dente". The flavoring is definitely chicken and is constant through the whole dish. Despite being stir-fried, it does not come off greasy in any way and is not leaving the stir-fry curse of telltale dropplets of unidentifiable dark oil in the container.I am sure there is better and I am sure there is worse. China Hut has owned this neighborhood for decades so I can see where there would be a tough climb for a startup. I am satisfied with my meal and find it very tasty.

17.description: This place is extraordinarily average. Very friendly service, but the food wasn't worth the price in my opinion. I ordered a sesame chicken combo with an egg roll and hot and sour soup for $10.49. Seemed like a good deal, but the soup tasted like hot salty water and the chicken like unseasoned meat deep fried and dropped into a sugary sauce. The egg roll was decent. My boyfriend ordered fish with Chinese brocoli for $11. He got a good amount of food, but the fish was not fresh at all. Tasted really fishy.

10.description: The first time I tried this place I got it because it was close and thank goodness for that. It was delicious and the delivery was fast

11.description: This is the best chinese restaurant they really care about the customer and i felt valued and its not own by Asian people plus it's real Chinese food.

26.description: I had the recommended sweet potato sushi rolls, which were mediocre at best. A friend had a Chinese dish that he, too, claims was average at best. The server, Jackie (?), was hysterically entertaining. He was incessantly observing our table, and occasionally peeped over the Chinese decor that separated our table from the kitchen. That was hilarious! His head was bopping up and down, and we embarrassingly couldn't resist laughing. He was a nice server... I have more to say about him than I do the food.

27.description: Ordered three dishes: Happy Family, Garden Chicken, Cashew Chicken, and got a free order of Chicken Lo Mein (Lunch size -- but it really was dinner size.)  It came with 2 large rice containers and ONE fortune cookie ONE plastic fork and ONE plastic knife (go figure?) Total bill $35. The ingrdients seemed to be of reasonable quality: Chicken, cashews, sea scallops, shrimp.  The Mandarin Sauce had no oomph, and might just as well be an American brown sauce.  Unfortunately it was on THREE of the dishes (It was on the Lo Mein.)The "garden sauce" (white wine) was nothing special although pleasent enough.This is Americanized  chinese food and we will not try it again. BYOB

35.description: I liked this place. I had the orange chicken lunch special and the crab rangoon. The taste, quality, and portions were all good for the price. My order came out quickly and the service was very good as well. It might be the best American Chinese restaurant in the area even since nearby places don't have dine in areas and seem to use cheaper ingredients than Fung's. Will definitely be back if I'm in the area.

8.description: Good prices and fast service, especially for carry out. Really nice guy working the counter who gave us a discount and offered extra rice with our meal at no charge. Free spring roll with each purchase and 10% off cash sales, definitely worth it.

0.description: On top of being extremely delicious, it has beautiful garnishings that are just not seen anymore in modern dining!Fung's Chinese Mandarin Cuisine is IT! It's the Bomb.That's right. 5 Star Rating: Woohoo! As good as it gets!

I am not sure about the review from last year but know going in it is a totally different menu. Despite being stir-fried, it does not come off greasy in any way and is not leaving the stir-fry curse of telltale dropplets of unidentifiable dark oil in the container.I am sure there is better and I am sure there is worse. China Hut has owned this neighborhood for decades so I can see where there would be a tough climb for a startup. I am satisfied with my meal and find it very tasty.

19.description: Well, I'm forced to update my previous review and adjust the rating down to a 1 star rating.  The last 2 times I've stopped in it has smelled inside of something burning and both times my fried rice had a very strong burnt taste to it.  Today I got the sesame chicken and it actually tasted bad.  It was most unusual tasting chicken I've ever eaten and had a pasty flour taste to it which made it pretty gross tasting.  I ended up throwing away half of my fried rice and half of my sesame chicken since they tasted so bad.I'll probably stop in again at some point in the future to see if they've gotten their act back together, but it won't be anytime soon.  I hate to say it, but my lunch today rates as the worst Chinese food I've ever eaten.If anybody is looking for some Chinese take out I'd recommend they try the Great Wall Chinese Restaurant nearby on Sheridan.  I know that will be my go to place from now on when I'm in this neighborhood.

33.description: This place is yum! I'm really hoping the quality of the food stays up there! 4 stars for great flavor and ingredients.

2.description: This place used to be tolerable, but due to management changes, and hiring new employees who are lazy and have horrible customer service skills. Also the cleanliness of the restaurant is appalling, I many very well be calling the health department due to roaches I've seen. Also they put too much salty sauce and I ordered LoMein which looked more like a soup..... Will NO longer be recommending this place!

34.description: Cool place. Pleasant, clean. Egg drop was good, I tasted the salt thing you guys are talking about, but I liked it. Combo fried rice is a good deal. Gonna go back to try the chef's specialties.

32.description: I've been looking for years for decent a decent Chinese place that will deliver and be consistent. On my list of necessities?1. Chicken that isn't gristly, and seafood that won't make me question if I'll have food poisoning the next day.2. Sauces that taste like what they purport to be. 3. Solid crab rangoon.4. A reasonable price tag.Fungs delivers on all of these. Their crab rangoon are great, the sesame shrimp is awesome, the sweet and sour chicken is decent (although I was a bit surprised by the maraschino cherries...), fried rice is great, and the lemon chicken is lemony but subtle, and super filling. Each dish should leave you with at least a second meal for later.Finally, they're quick and friendly with both delivery and pick up. I've finally found my go-to place for Chinese!

18.description: It's always great a good Chinese restaurant near by, there egg drop soup is great! I've many different dishes here but my favorite dish the Garden Chicken it's light with tons of veggies and chicken. I highly recommend this dish!!

13.description: I came here for the first time with trepidation a couple months ago. The reviews weren't favorable about the staff. I don't know if the staff has changed or there's been an attitude about face but I had a great experience. Not only was the food tasty and fresh, but the guy serving us was super nice and friendly. We had the Crab Rangoon, filled generously with creamy goodness and Empress Chicken, chunky white meat with a good sweet to spicy ratio. So far, my favorite Chinese restaurant in the area.

4.description: I always get the rice bowl.. ginger beef & tofu with white rice.. when they 1st opened they put alot of big ginger strips.. they have since use ? Minced? ginger which is fine with me.. the servings are generous.. I always bring some home.. one day I will order something different.. maybe. : )

24.description: Since I have resided in East Rogers Park I have found or have beenintroduced to some great little places, and Fung's Mandarin Cuisineis at the top of that list!And, my 34 year old son Brian actually introduced me to Fung's and I'm soglad that he did because it has become one of my new favorites!Now, I will admit that my son Brian is very specific about what he ordersfrom Fung's and it is usually their very delicious Combination Beef, Chicken.Shrimp fried rice with no vegetables, because Lord knows my kid still hatesvegetables even at the age of 34..Damn, I was so hoping he'd grow out of that!And, okay, I have been ordering same dish sans vegetables and it's  prettytasty so Brian may be on to something here..For the record, Fung's is mainly a take-out/delivery operation and that worksjust fine for me, I go in pick up the order and take it home, No problems there!And normally I would have pics attached to my review however, for whateverreason I did not think to take a pic of Fung's from the outside and lets getreal here, rice dishes in a pic just look mushy..But, in reality Fung's rice is anything but, it's full of great flavor, and theyare most generous with the meat pieces in their Combo fried rice dish.. Ahhh..Egg Rolls are pretty tasty too!So, in ending. yeah, I know, you all have been waiting for me to end this,Fung's Mandarin Cuisine is another hidden gem I have found since livingin Roger's Park. great quality food, reasonable menu prices, and quickfast delivery!Located on Morse right off the Red Line, Fung's is definitely worth a visitAnother great find in Rogers Park!One of the Best, truly....

6.description: As it says "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" Fungs is the best and they make it your way! The food is excellent and one of my family's favorite places and in fact, it is our favorite place for Mandarin Cuisine. Simply incredible all the time, everytime!!!

22.description: This is the worst Chinese food ever! And look I have had bad Chinese food. But the chicken fried rice we got was raw and the pot stickers were soggy and falling apart oh and on top of that the size of my fist. The service there is sub par. It has no taste and smells very very very uncooked. Like I said raw.

15.description: Since I have resided in East Rogers Park I have found or have beenintroduced to some great little places, and Fung's Mandarin Cuisineis at the top of that list!And, my 34 year old son Brian actually introduced me to Fung's and I'm soglad that he did because it has become one of my new favorites!Now, I will admit that my son Brian is very specific about what he ordersfrom Fung's and it is usually their very delicious Combination Beef, Chicken.Shrimp fried rice with no vegetables, because Lord knows my kid still hatesvegetables even at the age of 34..Damn, I was so hoping he'd grow out of that!And, okay, I have been ordering same dish sans vegetables and it's  prettytasty so Brian may be on to something here..For the record, Fung's is mainly a take-out/delivery operation and that worksjust fine for me, I go in pick up the order and take it home, No problems there!And normally I would have pics attached to my review however, for whateverreason I did not think to take a pic of Fung's from the outside and lets getreal here, rice dishes in a pic just look mushy..But, in reality Fung's rice is anything but, it's full of great flavor, and theyare most generous with the meat pieces in their Combo fried rice dish.. Ahhh..Egg Rolls are pretty tasty too!So, in ending. yeah, I know, you all have been waiting for me to end this,Fung's Mandarin Cuisine is another hidden gem I have found since livingin Roger's Park. great quality food, reasonable menu prices, and quickfast delivery!Located on Morse right off the Red Line, Fung's is definitely worth a visitAnother great find in Rogers Park!One of the Best, truly....

7.description: I have ordered food from Fung's numerous times, but usually order the same two things, veggie egg foo yong, or tofu with vegetables.  Both are excellent. The egg foo yong is not crispy fried, like most places, and the sauce is delicious.  The tofu and vegetables has lots of vegetables and big wedges of stir-fried tofu.  Last night, I tried something different, because it was on the special board - eggplant in garlic sauce, which doesn't sound like much, but was delicious!  The eggplant just melted in your mouth, and the other vegetables, including big chunks of red and green pepper, were cooked just enough. The whole dish was just a really nice flavorful blend, like a vegetarian stew with rice, and not too garlicky. Delicious!  I also want to mention Fung's takeout packaging is the best.

36.description: Do you like awkwardly stereotypical 1970s decorated restaurants? If so, Fung's is your place as they faithfully follow the theme of 1970s "exotic Asian",  down to the register lady (bless her heart for having to wear that to work). As a Chicago transplant coming from a place where being Asian American is considered a "normal" thing, I have gotten use to Asian restaurants here that look like they were decorated by a blind man throwing things at a wall from the China town bazaar but honestly, a costume? Ok, perhaps I am blowing this out of proportion, but I do want to at least mention in this review that I don't exactly find it charming.Alright so my apologies about the criticism above to the restaurant but I do feel that it was necessary. New restaurants need all the help they can manage and I would like to at least leave constructive criticism. So the rating of this review will not be based off because I found the decor awkwardly offensive or that the register person had to wear a stereotypical Asian costume, like all the other things I review, it will be solely on the food.  Like the others reviewing this place have kept an eye out for its opening day and decided to take a stab at eating here. The menu itself is nothing revolutionary, it's the pretty standard sort of American-Chinese food you can find anywhere in the country but the prices are pretty decent in comparison to other places. Not cheap but decent. Average? Anyhow, I ate a steak dish, soup, and their rice dish.The steak was a bit...rubbery but overall not too bad. Much better than I anticipated, had a good balance of salt but the sauce it was covered in...was a bit weak. By no means was it bad but it just didn't really have a defining characteristic of a taste. The soup actually had some good stock flavor rather than a watery bland taste. The wontons inside had a nice beefy bite. The rice...was dry, nothing else to say.Overall, not a horrible experience, I would probably stop by for lunch but ditch the tacky "China girl" costume and then let's talk.

30.description: Well, I'm forced to update my previous review and adjust the rating down to a 1 star rating.  The last 2 times I've stopped in it has smelled inside of something burning and both times my fried rice had a very strong burnt taste to it.  Today I got the sesame chicken and it actually tasted bad.  It was most unusual tasting chicken I've ever eaten and had a pasty flour taste to it which made it pretty gross tasting.  I ended up throwing away half of my fried rice and half of my sesame chicken since they tasted so bad.I'll probably stop in again at some point in the future to see if they've gotten their act back together, but it won't be anytime soon.  I hate to say it, but my lunch today rates as the worst Chinese food I've ever eaten.If anybody is looking for some Chinese take out I'd recommend they try the Great Wall Chinese Restaurant nearby on Sheridan.  I know that will be my go to place from now on when I'm in this neighborhood.

3.description: My boyfriend and I came across the restaurant back from Morse market and saw the 8.99 curry chicken special. The staff is super nice, they offer complimentary tea and fortune cookies! The chicken itself was enough for two people, had a nice amount of veggies and a fairly pleasant taste. We will definitely be back :)

14.description: Arguably one of the best Chinese restaurants in Chicago. I was waiting for it to open and was not disappointed when it did -- an instant favorite of mine and all my friends. High quality cooking at a bargain price. Their orange chicken (one of their specialties) is the best I've found anywhere. Also great: the tofu & vegetables. Even "mundane" things like fried rice and egg fu young are a cut above the ordinary. Just a little storefront, but a very pleasant place, friendly and fast service.

58.description: I had lived in Peru for about 7 months total, and this place brings back all the memories. The food and service here are both amazing. The owner even made a special delivery trip to my apartment when it was snowing heavily one winter night. It was the best! The lomo saltado is awesome, as are the papas rellenas. It is always a treat to eat here!

56.description: I love this place! The food is delicious and the owner is really nice. I always get the dish with steak, eggs, beans, plantains and rice. I order a side of avocado. Everything tastes home cooked and it reminds me of some of the low key Peruvian places in NYC. It's also BYOB which is awesome. I cannot wait to go back!

29.description: Great place! I love eating at  taste of Peru . Friendly atmosphere . Great service tasty food. I will definitely come back.

42.description: Sorry.....this time just 2 stars..  so disappointed. ...used to be good....Special Cebiche....too cooked and seafood almost shreded....was not good at all....Calamari. ...not good... small portions won't  come again...

23.description: So this place is amazing!  My friend is a foodie and had heard that Guy Fieri came here once, and so we decided to go with a huge group of people, I mean like 15 people.  We just dropped in on the doorstep and since it was only 4pm the place was a ghost town.  Fortunate for us, eh?   I have never had Puruvian food before and so I am no expert on the cuisine.  However I can tell you that everything, and I mean everything I tasted was delicious!  We ordered just about everything on the menu and passed it around.  The most disappointing moments were when a plate would arrive in front of you and it would be empty.I cannot remember everything that I ate.  However two dishes that did stand out were the seafood ceviche and the yucca frita.  I have never had such tender seafood ceviche in my life! Try this place!  I highly recommend it.  I know i will be back for sure!  Oh and by the way by the time we finished up with our meal, every single table was full.

47.description: I love Peruvian food, especially since Tanta came to town. But Tanta is expensive, and I wanted to try some more authentic Peruvian food. "Taste of Peru" is the answer!The food here is excellent. We started out with "papas a la huancaina", which is a typical Peruvian appetizer. It consists of boiled potatoes covered in a slightly spicy creamy sauce. We also had the "papa rellena" which is a big sphere concoction filled with chopped steak and raisins.For the main dish we had the "arroz con pollo" which is green rice with chicken (on the bone). The meat falls off the bone and is so flavorful.For dessert they were out of flan, so we split "arroz con leche" and the ice cream (which has a caramel taste to it even though it's based on some fruit).All in all the meal was excellent, service was great (water was refilled often).

8.description: I have ordered several dishes from here and every single one has been nothing but amazing! My favorite is the aji Galina and the Lomo saltado. Their ceviche mixto is probably one of my favorite ceviches! And their portions are huge! Great food and an amazing family that owns it. We love taste of peru!

31.description: The spotty service can be forgiven, because the food is amazing! The ceviche is bright, flavorful, and delicious. Lomo Saltado is excellent. The chicken dish with walnut was a favorite. BYOB and plenty of parking right out front.

34.description: I was afraid at first because I was meeting about 10 people for my birthday and this was a recommendation from a friend so I had no experience with the food, place or location.  I was looking for some place more casual, less foo foo and more character.  Not very expensive and good for a group.  It goes without saying that the food should be good.  Taste of Peru was all that and more.  Yes, it's nothing fancy and you can even say it's considered "a hole-in-the wall" but you should never judge a book by it's cover I was told.  Food was fantastic, affordable and plenty to not leave hungry.  I can't go into the details of all the items we had because we had a lot!  Being BYOB was a plus!  Perfect for a large party and the owner will make sure you feel the love.  Wonderful and charming, we will sure to come back.  Who doesn't love riddles and magic tricks?!?  If you want a nice, quiet evening because you long to be alone, do NOT go here.  If you're like me and my friends, get your butt there now!  What a great way to begin a new year.  Thank you for making me look so good with my friends and giving us one hell of a night!

16.description: My family wanted to get dinner near Evanston and I asked a friend at Northwestern what restaurant we should go to. He immediately said Taste of Peru: great food, parking lot, no reservations needed. This was all we needed and we headed that way!THE WAIT: We got there about 8pm on a Saturday, and it ended up being about a 30 minute wait for the four of us. There's no wait list; the manager recognizes you and just knows the order. One guy also waiting said he'd never had to wait to eat here - it must have just been a particularly busy night! The manager did come out to give us updates (a few tables are just finishing up, we can sit your two groups very soon, etc.).THE SERVICE: Really nice, the manager has a great vibe about him. The table service was very prompt. They are a busy place and know how to get their stuff done!We had already looked through the menu and were ready to order right when we sat down. The food came out very fast! There was also only one dessert available so we didn't get any.Take-out menu p.1: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…APPETIZERS* Papa Rellena (mashed potato stuffed w/ a mixture of seasoned rib eye steak, walnuts, eggs, raisins & olives. $7.50) - 3 starscross-section: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…The potato had a nice crisp on the outside and was soft on the inside. But the filling wasn't very flavorful; I thought it would be a strong mixture of savory and sweet with the raisins. The ribeye meat was very rubbery and hard.* Anticuchos de Carne o Pollo (Peruvian shish kebab marinated w/ Peruvian spices. Choice of beef/chicken, we chose beef. $7.50) - 3 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…This had interesting flavors - very strong on the vinegar. But the texture of the meat was pretty hard.Take-out menu p.2: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…PERUVIAN DISHES* Arroz con Pollo (Peruvian-style chicken & rice. Cooked in cilantro-based sauce. $12.00) - 3.5 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…This had really nice soft rice. The chicken was on the dry side, and overall the dish was pretty salty.SEAFOOD* Arroz con Mariscos (a super mixed seafood dish w/ yellow rice & peruvian spices. $18.00) - 3.5 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…This was like a paella and was pretty good. In retrospect, looking at the price, it wasn't quite worth $18. It had a decent amount of seafood, but just wasn't too amazing.* Jalea al Estilo Peruano (fried-breaded corvina, squid, mussels, octopus, shrimp & scallops. Served w/ corn & sweet onion marinated in lime. $19.95) - 4 starspic: yelp.com/biz_photos/tast…This is a great value b/c it's such a huge pile of seafood! All softly breaded & fried. It's a little heavy in the lime/ vinegar flavors, though. I loved the large white corn kernels.

13.description: So this place is amazing!  My friend is a foodie and had heard that Guy Fieri came here once, and so we decided to go with a huge group of people, I mean like 15 people.  We just dropped in on the doorstep and since it was only 4pm the place was a ghost town.  Fortunate for us, eh?   I have never had Puruvian food before and so I am no expert on the cuisine.  However I can tell you that everything, and I mean everything I tasted was delicious!  We ordered just about everything on the menu and passed it around.  The most disappointing moments were when a plate would arrive in front of you and it would be empty.I cannot remember everything that I ate.  However two dishes that did stand out were the seafood ceviche and the yucca frita.  I have never had such tender seafood ceviche in my life! Try this place!  I highly recommend it.  I know i will be back for sure!  Oh and by the way by the time we finished up with our meal, every single table was full.

11.description: Oh wow. I traveled over 25 miles to Taste the food and can I say I am so not disappointed. I am amazed at the quality of freshness and the thought of over eating is now on my mind. The judo de chiche morado is wonderful. The taste of purple corn I believe infused into a liquid form is quite the taste. I had a ceviche also with some corn also, but not the typical corn, its processed in a very nice tasting way from what the waitress tells me. The taste is awesome throughout the whole experience of all the foods. I do have to admit though that the pricing is a little expensive. I ended up paying $70 for two. It was a little bit out there for what we are but still a good experience. The place is small and very old school with its chatskys of vintage Peruvian artifacts and although some have cobwebs, it still is a nice experience altogether. Go early for sure, as it seems that it can get packed pretty well, and I ended up parking on the street due to the parking lot being shared with other establishments.  Unfortunately the parking lot can get very crowded and the cars are seriously on top of each other so you may get a ding. Something I didn't want to do so I opted for meter parking. All in all, you will have a wonderful experience but like I said earlier, expect to pay for it.  Will I go back? Hmmm, not sure, the food is tasty but the pricing is not attractive.

39.description: Excellent food, comparable to the best other Peruvian restaurants we've eaten at.  Fresh, spicy, personable.  Be sure to note that it's BYOB -- we didn't know that, and wound up running to the liquor store down the block, who have a special Peruvian section priced at twice everything else ... and everything else is crap -- better to bring your own bottle from home, or better yet, a bottle of pisco to mix with the pitcher of virgin pisco(-less) sours you can get here.  Awesome find!

37.description: Taste of Peru has never disappointed. Though I'm a wimp when it comes to spice (their salsa verde is too intense for me) they have plenty of great options for me as a pescetarian. They're often very busy but it's worth a wait. The staff is friendly and my boyfriend claims the food is exactly like what he had while visiting Peru. I plan on taking many friends and family here!

0.description: Taste of Peru is the most authentic Peruvian food you will find in Chicago, and has the best service and ambiance. One of my best friends is from Peru and we are here all the time was she was in the states and she loved it. On some nights they have a small band playing music. You can also bring your own alcohol and even have them make drinks with it for you, like Peruvian chilcanos or Pisco sours. I recommend ordering the avocado appetizer and seafood for your entree.Also, if you order out the service is amazing. I received the wrong item and when I called, the woman who was working brought me the correct dish and gave me a salad free of charge. It was some of the most prompt and personalized service I have received so it is definitely worth it to order out from them.

38.description: Yum. Yum. YUMMMMMMMM! Best place to eat in the northside of Chicago. On Tuesdays-Thursdays, they have live music that starts at 7:00pm and it's an amazing experience every time we visit.

51.description: Delicious food! Nice family who owns and operates the business as well! The place was packed when I went in and they were still attentive and had excellent service. The family was very passionate about Peru's history as well!

27.description: I love this place. It's a little restaurant located in a strip mall with the best food. I wish they delivered to where I love now. Went there for a dinner with the family and the service was good and we had no wait being seated. Many of the Peruvian dishes were delicious, I particularly liked the papa a la Diablo. Can't really go wrong.

32.description: Delicious food, horrible service. And I'm not that picky when it comes to being waited on. Have been there three times now and have ordered the plátanos maduros, and tonight was the first time they actually brought them. Also, they were out of a lot of food. My friend dropped his fork, and the waitress brought us more food before she brought him a new fork. However-the tacu tacu. I get it every time. The rice is to die for. The tamal (chicken) is also really tasty, and different than the Mexican tamales you can get just down the road.5 stars for taste, 2 stars for service!

54.description: This is a really passionately Peruvian hole in the wall place with bunches of quirks, most of them related to the impromptu one man show that the owner seems to perform nightly as he gets a little cozier to his Pisco bottle. We had a 22 person birthday party here on a Saturday night - for a tiny place, they accommodated us very well. Always had the reservation marked when I called to confirm closer to the date and was very flexible when we showed up requesting entire tables be moves into an arrangement more to our satisfaction...and to take on 2 seats we did not RSVP for. BYOB ensures booze is affordably plentiful and there is no corking fee.They did a wonderful job with a wait staff of basically 2 to take our orders - there was an expected delay in some dishes and admittedly some were so delayed 2 in our party just cancelled their entrees because everyone else was almost done eating (Although there was plenty to go around given the huge portions).The Lomo saltado, mixed seafood ceviche and shrimp in tomato sauce were our picks and delicious. Guy Fieri'd combo was another popular delight as were the tamales. Very affordable pricing especially given the portions and seafood load.Midway through dinner I noticed the owner disappear out the door and reemerge minutes later with something under his coat. We didn't have to wait long for what it was when he sent around rounds of a passionfruit pisco drink - a drink he says made his wives (I didn't ask) go "::hubba hubba shimmy dance::". This was followed by a candled alfajore cookie for the birthday boy and round of singing then another frothy pisco concoction with eggwhite and cinnamon. All on the house.Then comes the unadvertised entertainment of the night - the perfectly Peruvian owner's performance of various Peruvian yoyos, toy/games and challenges of patrons to beat him at any of these for the dinner on the house. He is superb and unbeatable but still highly entertaining.The bill was a surprise, seeing the many things they comp'd us, as well as the fact they did accept separate credit cards (a surprise for such an authentic hole in the wall place). We figured out the amount owed by each person ourselves but they processed all payment quickly. Like a true family run place, even as we passed beyond their opening hours, the owner was a welcome host and did not shoo us out, instead helping us keep the Peruvian celebration alive.One of the absolutely best large-dinner experiences I ever had, and executed with minimal hiccups from a very small and homey establishment. Would recommend for anything from a quick bite to a casual dinner to large parties.Come for the food, stay for the Peruvian immersion.

48.description: I discovered this hidden gem because I was missing my favorite Peruvian restaurant in Cali & craving great Peruvian food. Delicious doesn't begin to describe the food. I savored every bite I could, the serving size was large for my small tummy but I look forward to eating every morsel later. I had lomo saltado and aroz mariscos, scrumptious is inadequate to describe both. I highly recommend both and of course the place it self is a must.

44.description: We ordered the Dinner for Two delivered, which turned out to be HUGE and a delicious introduction to Peruvian food. There was a chicken tamale, a large portion of mixed seafood ceviche, papas a la huancaina, and arroz con maristos. The arroz was similar to seafood paella - gently seasoned yellow rice mixed with all manner of seafood, including a cluster of snow crab legs! Everything was delectable, and it arrived at our apartment promptly and well-wrapped.

24.description: A great neighborhood gem! Authentic Peruvian food. Taste was also a stop for Guy Fierri on Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives! Very friendly and attentive service. Plenty of parking too!

7.description: Owner is very sweet! Not sure if you can make reservations, but it's a small space if you have to wait a bit. It is BYOB. Had the papa rellena, it was good but needed a sauce to make it a little more flavorful. The tamales were super good, just didn't have very much chicken to it. The entrees we tried were the lomo saltado which was great and the arroz con mariscos with the green cilantro rice instead of yellow rice. Last thing we tried were the sweet plantains which were good. The portions are big so definitely share or take it for leftovers. There's so many options to choose from so definitely would go back.

49.description: Food was off the chain! Plenty of parking in the lot. Great service. Tried the lomo saltado. The beef was nice and tender with plenty of flavor and the fries were cooked into it which I thought was awesome. It comes with this green hot sauce which I think was called ahe? I could be wrong but it's pretty spicy and flavorful. I haven't met the owner but I've heard he's very friendly and greets all the guests. Check it out and stfu. Peace!

40.description: Best Peruvian food I've ever had. One of the best meals I've ever had. Every time I'm back in Chicago, I'm hitting this place up.

53.description: Excellent food! Great prices! The owner is a really nice and friendly guy, definitely recommend it.

30.description: I've been here a couple of times. During lunch hours it could be pretty quiet, at least from my one time coming here on a Friday. The other times I've cone here on a weekend. Now, I would suggest you call ahead and get a reservation if you're coming during the weekend, especially at night. The place is small and crowded with tables and chairs. But there is enough room to sit comfortable. There is a parking lot and street parking but that parking lot gets full easily. Now the food, it's just good! Damn good! You really taste Peru when you eat here, authentic and very flavorful. Don't forget to grab an Inca Kola, it's a must! The food speaks for itself and you cannot go wrong. They have a ton of seafood options too. Price matches quality, on point! Recommended and will keep coming back

46.description: I have been in this restaurant a couple of times.  I was not impressed by the food the first time. The second time I wanted to give them another chance,  and I was also disappointed. The dishes that I tried were greasy and did  not seem to have the rich flavor that I have come to expect from Peruvian cuisine.  The Aguadito de pollo was too oily and the Lomo saltado had beef that was too tough and also greasy. I tried a chicken dish on my subsequent visit, which was also greasy. For real Peruvian dining,  I would look elsewhere.

1.description: YOU HAVE TO EAT HERE! This is by far one of my favorite restaurants to go to! I always make sure I come straight here when I visit Chicago. We always get the seafood paella and lomo saltado. Both are exceptional and I just can't get myself to try anything else. This place is BYOB (they don't have a cork fee or anything). Grab a nice bottle of wine or some beers and head on over! We tried the regular seafood paella and the cilantro rice seafood paella (we can't decide which one we like more). The paella comes with a huge load of seafood and so flavorful. The lomo saltado is the only way I would eat soggy fries and it's SO flavorful. Verdict: I want to go back right now! I wish there was a Peruvian restaurant this good closer to home. I've tried so many different Peruvian restaurants and they just don't come close to Taste of Peru. Go now!

55.description: This place is such a hidden gem! Was recommended by a friend and I am so glad I tried this place out. Starting from the tamale- the best tamale I've tried, so flavorful! Lomo saltado, seco de carne, and arroz con pollo are all so rich in flavor and delicious! I can't wait to go there again and try some of their soups and other dishes. This place has become my local favorite!

9.description: This is a really passionately Peruvian hole in the wall place with bunches of quirks, most of them related to the impromptu one man show that the owner seems to perform nightly as he gets a little cozier to his Pisco bottle. We had a 22 person birthday party here on a Saturday night - for a tiny place, they accommodated us very well. Always had the reservation marked when I called to confirm closer to the date and was very flexible when we showed up requesting entire tables be moves into an arrangement more to our satisfaction...and to take on 2 seats we did not RSVP for. BYOB ensures booze is affordably plentiful and there is no corking fee.They did a wonderful job with a wait staff of basically 2 to take our orders - there was an expected delay in some dishes and admittedly some were so delayed 2 in our party just cancelled their entrees because everyone else was almost done eating (Although there was plenty to go around given the huge portions).The Lomo saltado, mixed seafood ceviche and shrimp in tomato sauce were our picks and delicious. Guy Fieri'd combo was another popular delight as were the tamales. Very affordable pricing especially given the portions and seafood load.Midway through dinner I noticed the owner disappear out the door and reemerge minutes later with something under his coat. We didn't have to wait long for what it was when he sent around rounds of a passionfruit pisco drink - a drink he says made his wives (I didn't ask) go "::hubba hubba shimmy dance::". This was followed by a candled alfajore cookie for the birthday boy and round of singing then another frothy pisco concoction with eggwhite and cinnamon. All on the house.Then comes the unadvertised entertainment of the night - the perfectly Peruvian owner's performance of various Peruvian yoyos, toy/games and challenges of patrons to beat him at any of these for the dinner on the house. He is superb and unbeatable but still highly entertaining.The bill was a surprise, seeing the many things they comp'd us, as well as the fact they did accept separate credit cards (a surprise for such an authentic hole in the wall place). We figured out the amount owed by each person ourselves but they processed all payment quickly. Like a true family run place, even as we passed beyond their opening hours, the owner was a welcome host and did not shoo us out, instead helping us keep the Peruvian celebration alive.One of the absolutely best large-dinner experiences I ever had, and executed with minimal hiccups from a very small and homey establishment. Would recommend for anything from a quick bite to a casual dinner to large parties.Come for the food, stay for the Peruvian immersion.

26.description: I have heard great things about here so i finally tried it. I got a beef tip dish but swapped out the fries for fried plantains.  It was great. Amazing flavor

25.description: Taste of PerúNo, Perú isn't a person.  It's a country south of Colombia where I get my cocaine and west of Brazil where I get my crack, there's a little geography lesson for you.  Amazing family founded and operated places in the world really make me believe that there is still hope in the world to retain culinary tradition and culture.  Good enough for Guy Fieri, Good enough for meEveryone knows Guy's palette is legit.  For the most part he's on point, no difference here.   Ordered paella ("best in Chicago"), cilantro rice with chicken, seafood soup (Parihuela), stuffed potato (papa rellena), and mama carmen all which were mouth watering, double 'U'-tee-eff type of food.  BYOBBYOB lesson #1 - If a place is BYOB and you didn't have a good time, that's your fault.

12.description: Santi and I were looking for a non-touristy place to eat in Chicago, and came across this Peruvian restaurant on the Yelp app. The L-shaped interior was casual, home-like, and surrounded by colorful photos and cultural artifacts all the along the walls. The servers were happy to see us as we arrived just before closing. There were still plenty of local diners there. Even with the cold draft coming through the door the atmosphere was warm, friendly, and down to earth.The Arroz Con Pollo ($12) came with a large serving of cilantro rice with bulky pieces of bone-in drumsticks and thighs. The rice was stir-fried to perfection, with flavors inspired by a mix of cilantro, garlic, chicken, peas, and other spices embedded. Wonderfully delicious and addictive. Highly recommend it.The Arroz Con Marisco ($18) included plenty of shrimps, mussels, crab legs, scallops, red bell peppers, peas, large clams, and yellow rice. The scores of seafood were visible, fresh, and perfectly executed without them becoming shriveled or overcooked. To extend the flavors, both elements and complexities of the seafood were nicely cooked into the yellow rice. The flavors were not as robust as the previous dish, but a few drizzles of green spicy aji made it worthwhile for us.The complimentary bread was soft and fluffy, and the aji sauce was full-bodied spicy, thick, and out of this world delicious. I've visited plenty of Peruvian restaurants and this is the best aji sauce I've had so far. They were so kind to offer us complimentary homemade Lucuma Ice Cream after we had inquired about it with the server. The dulce de leche combined with a finesse but noticeable butterscotch-like flavor. The texture of the ice cream was thick but lacked creaminess.
