41.description: Would not go back.Weirded out.From the outside, this place looks fun.  I've walked by several times in warmer weather and there were always people sitting out on the patio.  I was hopeful.Came by on a Friday after 10 PM.  MAJOR crowd change from what I had witnessed.  Lots of middle aged single men there for some eye-candy.  An uncomfortable amount.  My friend and I could not finish our drinks enough.Call me a beer/drink snob, but the Smithwick's they had on tap was given to me in a goblet, rather than a pint glass.  THAT was odd.  Took quite awhile to get our drinks ordered as well since we were sitting right at the bar and had to wait for the bartender to stop yapping to her co-worker.The music style was very strange as well.  Went from typical club music to polka.  Yes.  Polka.  We were there for 20 minutes and heard at least 3 polka songs.  I am not being sarcastic or anything, they were playing POLKA inside a "hip and trendy" bar, and it was still September when we were there.No idea what the inspiration is or the desired atmosphere here, but I don't plan on stopping in again.

52.description: Pleased to report that a return trip to Chuckie's resulted in good times, great eats and no stabbings. Yay!It's pretty hard to beat a stiff pour of house red, prosciutto with red sauce pizza and views of the train at night time. When in the neighborhood, you have to stop by. Rogers Park, you're lucky to have a neighborhood space that can class it up while you're dressed down. Cheers.

50.description: I was excited to see this place open, if only to have another business to add density to the Morse Ave streetscape.  It didn't necessarily look like the kind of place I would hang out, so I never stopped by.  Tonight, I met a friend/neighbor for dinner and she suggested it.  I'm glad she did!  We ordered a salad to share, as well as a Bianca pizza which had ham, black olives, mozzarella and artichoke.  I won't say it was the most amazing pizza I've had in my life, but it was pretty darn good.  The presentation was lovely.It was a delicious and affordable weeknight out.  I will clearly go back.  I was surprised that more people didn't stop after work as they were coming off the train.  It is worth a visit, especially on a nice summer evening when you can enjoy the outside seating!

4.description: This place has a beautiful exterior and really appealing ambiance. However, it is dirty, and the service is horrible, which is why it was empty on a Friday night And every time we walk by. The coke was flat and the bartender was outside drinking for over ten minutes at a time leaving the bar completely unattended. He talked on the phone and splashed the grey goose but quickly switched to the cheaper vodka when requested for the expensive vodka. When the patron called him out for it, he literally said the words, "sorry I'm on a phone call." To finish our experience he up charged us for our drinks and didn't itemize our drinks so we wouldn't notice.

6.description: If you're into overpriced watered down drinks, this is the place for you!  The service was really friendly though.  I ordered a vodka orange juice,  the drink came out in a rocks glass with mostly rocks in it and all I tasted was orange juice!  I was slightly upset by this but became LIVID when I saw that I was charged $9 for this tiny glass of ORANGE JUICE!!  Unacceptable, do yourself a favor and just go to the Glenwood around the corner,  Or if you want a trendy cocktail lounge in the area Roger's Park Social around the other corner!

22.description: So, this place looks like a million bucks. The food is solid and the bar well stocked. Why such a low rating? The service is awful. Been there twice in the past few months and both of the servers just didn't want my party to be there. They were rude, short, and very hard to find, especially when it was time to pay the check. We finally gave up and just asked the nearest employee for the bill so we could get out of there. What makes this really sad is that the food and drinks are very solid. The martinis are great, and the food pretty solid. I've yet to try the place for delivery, but I'm really afraid to as I imagine the food will never get to us.

15.description: Horrible experience. I went here with a few friends on a weekday at 4. Walking in, we were the only people in the place, we sat at one of the tables, and waited for the waitress/bartender to come up to us and take our drink order. I ordered an apple martini, my friends ordered a beer and a cider. Our drinks came out quickly, and then the waitress/bartender disappeared. My martini was gross. Not even the slightest taste of anything apple, just vodka. And the glass (or the mixer) was dirty, there were little black pieces of fuzz in my drink. I would have sent it back, but the server was nowhere in sight. So I kind of sipped on it until it grossed me out too much.No one else was inside the bar, and my friends drinks became empty. We were going to order another round, but decided against it because the waitress/bartender was outside for 20 minutes, smoking and chitchatting with other people, while we sat inside with empty glasses. So we decided that because of the service we were receiving it would be better to close the tab rather than order another round of drinks. The waitress/bartender finally comes back inside, and walks behind the bar. My friend asks her for the check as she walks to the bathroom. The waitress/bartender brings the check to the table, and I ask if it's possible for separate checks. She responds with a no, because the other girl asked for one check so she couldn't split them (which wasn't true, my friend said no such thing!). So I walk up to the bar and pay the tab...Never again.

57.description: Great addition to Roger's Park.  I don't live in the area but frequently frequent the Glenwood and came across Chuckie's.  They did a great job with the space - facade is beautiful, interior is great as well.   Staff is friendly and the drinks are made perfect.   One downside is the small interior/layout, but they did a good job with what they had to work with.   Tried a bite of a friends pizza and was impressed but have yet to order it for myself.

20.description: I have been back to Chuckies a couple of times since my first review. Unfortunately nothing has changed. I am still amazed at how awful the service is. The fact that the bar "tenders" are either at the end of the bar ignoring their customers, or cannot be found, or the fact that when you do interact with a bar "tender" they are almost impossible to understand. At this point the owner should have hired some staff who speaks English as a first language. It does not make any sense to have bartenders that the customers cannot effectively communicate with. The music was over the top loud, and the martinis were not as good as they used to be.  Did I mention Chuckies always smells like burnt frozen grocery store pizza? They have a menu, but as far as I know there is no kitchen. When I go to Chuckies I feel as if I am interrupting the staff and they don't want anyone in the bar.  It sucks that this bar is so crappy because there are really not many bars to hangout in Rogers Park

36.description: I can't decide what I hate most about this place: The tacky, neon lighting? The fact that they serve Miller Lites in goblet glasses? The total lack of service? The constant smell of burnt, frozen pizza? The bowl of Lay's potato chips as window dressing? I could go on.UPDATE: And on I go! I walk by Chuckie's almost every morning before dawn and can easily see in the windows. Absolutely disgusting. On a regular basis, the closing server(s) leave dirty dishes and half-eaten food out on the tables and bar. Where they make their pizzas, I often see ingredients left to rot in their containers overnight. The staff/owners clearly have no sense of pride or concept of sanitation. The place is an absolute joke. It's the bar equivalent of a cretin who has no qualms taking a messy shit and then not washing their hands before making your sandwich.

14.description: Pizza is OK.  A bit greesy.  The prices on their beer/mixed drinks are through the roof!  My wife ordered a vodka and coke, it came in a super small glass, filled to the top with ice.  The vodka was a nasty off brand, and the price was $9.00.  No Thanks.  No wonder this place is always empty when I walk by.As the previous review said, the original staff was good. This new staff, nope.  Saturday night, had one guy stand and play music from his laptop, the bartender left at least 4 times out the front door to smoke. Then she went in the back to smoke. When I went to the rest room, it smelled like weed.  I think I got a high just by going to the men's room.  HOW this place stays in business is beyond me.  Saturday night, 1030pm, and empty.

58.description: This used to be one of our favorite restaurants in Chicago. Cheap, clean, and unreasonably tasty food. The only possible drawback is the slow service. You simply get older while waiting for your food to arrive at the table. Then again, the food is so good that you forget everything once you start eating. A small heaven in the middle of an otherwise uninteresting neighborhood.

56.description: This BYOB Indian place is a gem. So far, it's better than anything I have found on Devon and I have dined in as well as ordered out. It's usually pretty busy on the weekends, and the place is small. The service can be VERY SLOW, so if you are in a hurry look elsewhere. If you want to relax with friends or a date over a bottle of wine and have some seriously flavorful and delicious food, highly recommended.

29.description: So this is definitely one of those Rogers Park hidden gems.  You could be forgiven for walking by and not noticing or thinking to stop, but for those in the know, Luzzat is an amazing stop.  This mom and pop shop is worth its weight in gold.  What it lacks in decor and ambience, it makes up for in absolutely amazing food.Get the nan and make sure it's the buttered version.  YUM.  Their samosas are great, the chicken tiki masala is great and so is the chicken vindaloo.And of course adding to all of the winning that's already happening is the fact that it's BYOB.  Also I'd be a fool if I didn't mention the great service.  Top notch establishment.

42.description: I have a bunch of things to say about this place.  I used to live in India, so I have to put that in context.1.  The people are from Hyderabad, which is in the middle of the country.  Therefore, they are cooking a lot of different dishes in different styles.  There are many dishes on the menu that are "typical" food for what you see in an Indian restaurant for non-Indians (palak paneer, chicken masala), that they cook in the typical Indian restaurant style, that is heavy and greasy.  That's what you get on Devon, and that's what you should expect here for some of the dishes.  Indian food is not usually light, unless you're in the south. That doesn't mean it's bad at all, though - it's spiced right, and individually made.2.  It's individually made.  That means sometimes you will wait a long time.  There is an old Muslim woman in the back cooking for you.  And they're on Indian time.  Stop being in such a hurry!  Her son will get you your water, treat you quietly and formally, and take your order at some point.  You food is being made especially for you, so you will wait a half hour.  If you're in such a hurry, go to the buffets on Devon.3.  They're from Hyderabad.  That means, order the biryani, get it spicy; order the chicken curry, spicy.I love this place.  I miss India, and there are a few places that get close, and this is one.

23.description: Ah-ma-zing. The restaurant is in a weird, quiet part of town, and it is a small business run by a family, but please, please stay for the food and then come again.You will be blown away. Best Indian food that I have ever found in this city, and I have been looking for years, and you can't beat the price. Cheapest Indian restaurant in the city. Much better than anything on Devon or any other nook and cranny in this city. YUMMY!

47.description: I went with 3 other people and we ordered samosa,  chicken vindaloo, chicken tiki masala, chicken biryani, lamb biryani, chicken curry, paratha, and riatha...I think I have a new favorite restaurant....I personally don't eat much Indian food at all but that was pretty amazing!!!! The Indian food "expert" in the group says its the best Indian food she has ever eaten....although we did feel like we were sitting in a cafeteria and it was freezing....wait time was long but IT WAS ABSOLUTELY WORTH IT!!! There were four orders in the hour and a half we were there....don't miss out on this place....you will not be sorry

8.description: This place is right off of Jarvis, so you don't have to walk far if you're coming off the L. It's definitely a family-owned business and when I got there... they were "open" but no one was there and the door was locked. After checking our phones to make sure we were correct about the times (we went there for lunch), a guy comes out from the liquor store (literally next door) and he asks us if we were going to eat at the restaurant. We say yes, and he proceeds to open the door. I guess he calls the cook, and she comes in and starts to cook. Interesting, but I have to say... they make DELICIOUS indian food. We ordered the:Butter ChickenPalak PaneerChana masalaThey were all delicious. It came with a side of rice and we ordered some naan (but it wasn't called naan.. it was similar). Anyways, everything was delicious. My friends (from India) said it was pretty close to home, so it was a win for me, since I'm not too familiar with authentic indian food... aside from the restaurants I've been to on Devon and the Indian buffets. I found this place very enjoyable and I'll definitely be back.

31.description: Terrible! I got half-way through my plate of really sub-par chicken saag (mostly shredded chicken) to find a RUBBERBAND!!!!! Really????!!!!!! So sick to my stomach! I will never go back!!!!!

34.description: Great food and service. My only complaint is that occasionally if you ask for mild it is too bland. Wish they delivered!

16.description: The menu in the picture is incorrect. The prices have gone up. Please update your menu so you don't have issues with guests.

13.description: This place is fantastic. I know a lot of folks calling it Indian, but this is actually Pakistani food, pretty similar but just thought i would set the record straight. Anyway, worth the trip as it is literally just under the Jarvis redline stop. Parking is also easy right there. Its BYOB and highly recommend.

11.description: On a friends recommendation, we came here for the first time. Let me say...the house rice is heavenly! Laced with lime leaves, it's very buttery and fragrant.The fish vindaloo in a green curry was very good and the lamb curry with eggplant was ultra tender!A small family place, get here early.

39.description: This would be a one-star review if the food weren't so good, because the service at this place is terrible.  I get that it's a mom and pop shop and you won't have a hovering waiter and a sommelier, but my dining companion didn't even get the food she had ordered!  The waiter kept offering us the check and to-go boxes, trying to hustle us out of the place, and we had to keep asking him where the second entree was.  After (no kidding) five requests, he finally brought it out (piping hot; clearly they had completely forgotten it and freshly whipped it up).  It was delicious, of course, but we were pretty much done eating by then.The kicker was that they still charged us for the forgotten entree.  Shouldn't it have been comped?  The food was really outstanding, but that's no rarity this close to Devon.  I don't think I'll be back.

37.description: If it weren't for the small size of this place I really would give it 5 stars! And the only reason I complain about the size is because I was so hungry and just honestly craving the food from here and there was not a table available, though I am not surprised at all. Even if this restaurant was larger I feel like it would crowded all the time. The food and service are amazing. If you want traditional indian food from northern indian, you need to go here!

0.description: solid spot for quick and reasonably priced Indian food. I get the chicken curry there pretty often and haven't been disappointed yet

38.description: The food is amazing! I used to think nothing could live up to Hemma's Kitchen but based just on the quality and flavor of the food, this place may surpass it. Now, it's in a weird area, it's small, mostly for take out and the dining area isn't exactly that of a fine dining restaurant...But who cares, the food rocks! I will definitely go back!It is BYOB.

51.description: I was very disappointed. The chicken masala was quite watery. The lamb with okra was just ok. The only great thing was the parantha bread. What I disliked the most was the very unfriendly owner. He didn't make us feel welcome...actually I think he is just an unfriendly looking person. Service was sooooo slow. Will never return

27.description: 6 of us met here at noon on Sunday. I made a reservation, but we wouldn't have needed one. The food magically appeared much more quickly than we expected, based on other reviews. Every dish was really really good and pleased our eclectic crowd of Indian food lovers and Indian food novices. There is little atmosphere, but the space feels personal as opposed to plastic. Definitely would recommend.

32.description: The food is PERFECTLY spiced and flavorful. Some of the best Indian food I have had. Only reason I didn't give the full 5 stars is because they are a little heavy handed on the oil in their dishes.

54.description: A hidden gem of the Rogers Park neighborhood and Jarvis Square. This place has some great  food. I had a vegetable samosa (which was huge and worth the $1.50), Butter Chicken, a side of naan, and a Mango Lassi. I would strongly recommend everything I had and my boyfriend had the Lamb Vindaloo, which was spicy and delicious. It was about $30 for all of our order, and we had plenty leftover for another meal for each of us.   This place is tucked in right beside the Jarvis Red Line stop, so it's easy to miss this place. I ordered carry-out, and it took about 20 min after the call to be ready.

48.description: Take it from a Indian person! There aloo palak (spinach/potato) was delicious..I enjoyed there chicken Briyani.... This is a family owned Restuarant, owners are nice.. A lot of people flock here for the tasty food.. Best food outside Devon....

44.description: The only thing that wasn't perfect was the chicken tandoori. Otherwise it was simply exceptional. Very casual atmosphere. Perfect Friday night after a long week place. Just fabulous. The chicken masala has only a limited amount of chicken which was perfect. Two "confident" eaters had a lamb and a chicken dish after two appetizers and bread. There were no leftovers and the "oh my god I'm full and satisfied" level was just right. "Spicy" was warm but just enough to create heat and leave room for the taste. We are going back!

24.description: This is reallyyy high quality Indian food. This is the kind of food that I would expect of when I am rich and graduated from school; I am so glad these prices are budget-friendly! The amount of cream in my chicken makhani was OUTSTANDING. Likewise, the lamb curry had a excellent silky texture. Some tandoori chicken and shami kabob to start and a mango lassi to temper all the spices. Because it will always be too spicy for me :(There is a yelper that noted the slow service... uhhh, yes. Tough, boo-boo. You're here for the food, not to be waited on like royalty. We were the only patrons and, after all the food was served, I actually walked up to the counter to order my mango lassi. It was a small price to pay. Given the chance, I would choose this food over top-rated service any day.

7.description: So this is definitely one of those Rogers Park hidden gems.  You could be forgiven for walking by and not noticing or thinking to stop, but for those in the know, Luzzat is an amazing stop.  This mom and pop shop is worth its weight in gold.  What it lacks in decor and ambience, it makes up for in absolutely amazing food.Get the nan and make sure it's the buttered version.  YUM.  Their samosas are great, the chicken tiki masala is great and so is the chicken vindaloo.And of course adding to all of the winning that's already happening is the fact that it's BYOB.  Also I'd be a fool if I didn't mention the great service.  Top notch establishment.

49.description: This place rocks! It is all about the food here. There is very little ambience and the decor is sort of weird (floral curtains/sink in the dining room...), but that does not matter at all once you taste the dishes. I would come back here anytime!

40.description: My search for amazing chicken biryani continues...Recently moved to the north side and desperately looking for amazing chicken biryani. Was friends with a coworker's Pakistani family( until they moved away unfortunately) and I looked forward to the days when I was invited over for dinner and was lucky enough to receive a king's portion with an over easy fried egg and freshly cut onion, tomato, and Serrano peppers. Has to be my favorite dish of any kind and I'd be ecstatic if I could find biryani that could even shadow it. I just got back with my take out order. I heard great things but it's not good at all. I'd say pretty bad actually. I'm so disappointed. I couldn't even finish it and that's a first for me. If your curious, then give it a try, but if you want chicken biryani I'd say look else where.

53.description: You know this is going to be a great and authentic restaurant when you look in the kitchen and see the mother/wife/husband/owner doing the cooking.Great gosht with okra, dal baigan and palak paneer. Biryani was ok.Ohh, one more thing: you can bring any bottled alcoholic drinks without any corking fees.

30.description: Easily the spiciest Indian food I've found in Rogers Park. I used to be a fan of their price too but I think they raised it a little bit since the first time I ate there (about 2 years ago). Food is great, portions are great, space is okay.

46.description: I love Indian food, and this place is two blocks from my house, so I really wanted it to be a win. The one time a friend and I were able to spend half our evening getting a menu, ordering, and eating, the food was fine. A little on the salty side, not amazing, but perfectly acceptable. The menu contains the usual suspects. I'd go back, sure. BUT.Others have describe the service as "kinda slow." KINDA?!? It's an eternity. I went once by myself and left because after 20 minutes I still hadn't received a menu; another time a friend and I left before ordering because we'd been sitting for about 20 minutes waiting to order, and it was clear that the one waiter was also helping in the kitchen, and we had someplace to be.  Don't get me wrong; I don't like to rush, and I like to enjoy the dining experience, but this place is ridiculous.  There are plenty of other places that are not as convenient, but I'll take the bus to Devon for amazing food and good service over Luzzat, which is too bad, because they are really nice and I want them to do well. It sounds like there are enough people willing to spend a lot of time waiting, so that's good for Luzzat, but I won't be one of them.

1.description: Sadly, the quality of the food has declined dramatically here.  On a recent trip, our two chicken dishes featured big hunks of dry white meat in sauces that were, regardless of the dish's name, bland and indistinguishable.  Biryani was a big pile of flavorless rice.  Papadum was dripping in oil.  Cauliflower was mushy and swimming in a boring tomato sauce.Service always has been lacking in courtesy and responsiveness, but they wait staff has reached new lows.  Example:  I asked asked about the difference between two different rolls listed in the appetizer section.  I was told they were similar.  I asked which one he liked better, and he told me to order whatever I wanted.  Thanks so much.  He also pestered us to order our entrees, even though we had just gotten our appetizers, because he wanted to close the restaurant early on a Friday night.  He came by every three minutes asking us to order.Without good food, there is no longer a reason to endure the rude service and dumpy atmosphere.  So long, Luzzat.

55.description: Luzzat has very good food. No doubt about it. I always get take out. The reason I docked one star is just because the service is slow and sometimes the guy taking the order acts like you've interrupted him in the middle of something important. The parathas are delicious, as are the palak paneer and chicken mughlai.

9.description: Luzzat is a place you go where no one knows your name and frankly doesn't care because they are on this planet to do one thing and one thing only: prepare and cook the BEST DARN INDIAN FOOD IN CHICAGO! Please don't expect excellent service or even clean tables. Luzzat is too busy feeding you a delicious meal that you'll be talking about for weeks. Half of the menu is vegetarian (which I normally don't solicit but here I love) and the other half allows you to order from a variety of proteins like chicken, lamb, and seafood. All dishes are rich and flavorful and go perfectly over a hot plate of rice. We usually order enough for leftovers because it sometimes tastes even better the next day. Don't forget that this place is BYOB and they're always happy to provide glasses and corkscrews if asked. Don't be fooled by the looks of this place (it's not fancy and the quintessential "hole in the wall" but trust me, it's the real deal!

26.description: We arrived at Luzzat around 5.20pm with only two other tables occupied, excited and hungry to try the food that was rated high by other Yelpers.We ordered a vegetable samosa, two buttered paratha, chicken vindaloo, buttered chicken, and mango kulfi for dessert. It took about 20 minutes for our food to arrive, which was a slightly long wait when there were so few others to serve.The vegetable samosa was good, chicken vindaloo and paratha were alright, but the buttered chicken wasn't really to my taste, nor was it anything special. Personal preference: I would've preferred naan instead of paratha, although the latter is slightly healthier as it's made of whole wheat flour as opposed to white flour. Naan is also more chewy in texture. The only thing I really enjoyed was the mango kulfi we ordered last minute for dessert even though we were already full. I'm a huge fan of kulfi, and another Indian dessert - gulab jamun. I would die for these things. The only complaint I have about it is that the kulfi was too sweet. Cut down on the sugar and I'll be coming back again and again for more, and this time ordering the gulab jamun to go along with it as well. On the other hand, my partner thought everything was good, but not as cheap as people have indicated. Not sure about you but I think $11 per chicken curry-ish entree is overpriced.

25.description: Met some friends for dinner. Small, cozy space off the Jarvis redline stop, felt like I was eating in someones dining room. Friday night was fairly busy with most tables full. We made the mistake of ordering 3 chicken entrees (Chana, masala, and butter). To me the Chana chicken was way too spicy despite asking for mild spice, but I should preface with the fact I do not tolerate spicey food well. Further, I probably shouldn't be eating Indian food to begin with. Despite the profuse sweating I couldn't stop eating the chicken sitting in the bowl of lava. Fantastic flavor!I also ordered a keema samosa which consisted of seasoned ground beef and onions encased in a dough and deep fried. It was ok, just a tad too oily for me, but again it had great flavor. It's served with two dipping sauces. The ambiance is lacking but the food more than makes up for this fact. It's BYOB and there is a wine store across the street (they also sell beer). I noticed their take-out business seemes to be quite popular.

12.description: Ah-ma-zing. The restaurant is in a weird, quiet part of town, and it is a small business run by a family, but please, please stay for the food and then come again.You will be blown away. Best Indian food that I have ever found in this city, and I have been looking for years, and you can't beat the price. Cheapest Indian restaurant in the city. Much better than anything on Devon or any other nook and cranny in this city. YUMMY!

59.description: Very happy with my food curry chicken, veg pakora was incredible, and the samosas are very flaky. A little dining room so keep that in mind.

21.description: This place is right off of Jarvis, so you don't have to walk far if you're coming off the L. It's definitely a family-owned business and when I got there... they were "open" but no one was there and the door was locked. After checking our phones to make sure we were correct about the times (we went there for lunch), a guy comes out from the liquor store (literally next door) and he asks us if we were going to eat at the restaurant. We say yes, and he proceeds to open the door. I guess he calls the cook, and she comes in and starts to cook. Interesting, but I have to say... they make DELICIOUS indian food. We ordered the:Butter ChickenPalak PaneerChana masalaThey were all delicious. It came with a side of rice and we ordered some naan (but it wasn't called naan.. it was similar). Anyways, everything was delicious. My friends (from India) said it was pretty close to home, so it was a win for me, since I'm not too familiar with authentic indian food... aside from the restaurants I've been to on Devon and the Indian buffets. I found this place very enjoyable and I'll definitely be back.

17.description: After all the ecstatic reviews we thought it would be better.Prices have been jacked up $2 compared to the photograph of the menu currently posted on Yelp. Entrees are $12-$13.The samosa had a thin skin, as real samosas do and unlike Devon where the dough is thick, leathery and uncooked on the inside. But it was not freshly made; it was just heated up. And the filling was mostly potatoes with a token pea or two.Because of all the warnings here, we asked for mild entrees. The result was that everything was flavorless. There is a distinction between spicy=hot and spicy=spiced; "mild" at this restaurant was not just not hot, it had no Indian cooking spice flavors. The only thing we could taste was a tomato-y base that was used for everything, whether vegetables or fish.And how can a "home cooking" restaurant serve lamb? There's absolutely no lamb in India; with their wool coats, they would die of the heat. In India, red meat means goat meat. Even the ultracheap Gareeb Nawaz on Devon cooks goat meat.

10.description: I have lived in India and love the cuisine. This place is simply decorated but the food is excellent, inexpensive and plentiful. Samosas are large , the rice free and the butter chicken terrific. Service is friendly but I sometimes have to walk up to Window to get check. They don't rush you. Best Indian food in town.

5.description: Found this restaurant using Yelp and it was great find!  The peoplr working there are great, very helpful and friendly.  The portion sizes are huge.  The food was absolutely delicious.  While not located in the best area, the food is too amazing not to go.  Small inside area to eat.  BYOB.

3.description: Met some friends for dinner. Small, cozy space off the Jarvis redline stop, felt like I was eating in someones dining room. Friday night was fairly busy with most tables full. We made the mistake of ordering 3 chicken entrees (Chana, masala, and butter). To me the Chana chicken was way too spicy despite asking for mild spice, but I should preface with the fact I do not tolerate spicey food well. Further, I probably shouldn't be eating Indian food to begin with. Despite the profuse sweating I couldn't stop eating the chicken sitting in the bowl of lava. Fantastic flavor!I also ordered a keema samosa which consisted of seasoned ground beef and onions encased in a dough and deep fried. It was ok, just a tad too oily for me, but again it had great flavor. It's served with two dipping sauces. The ambiance is lacking but the food more than makes up for this fact. It's BYOB and there is a wine store across the street (they also sell beer). I noticed their take-out business seemes to be quite popular.

35.description: I haven't tried Indian food in Chicago before and was hoping to find a good place near by.  I went to Luzzat a couple of days ago with my brother and a couple of girl friends.  It was a little bit hard to find only because I'm never in the area and it isn't the fanciest of places, but parking in the plaza area worked out for us.  When we got to the restaurant it wasn't really busy (it was about 2p on a Saturday).  We had a seat and ordered samosas, chicken masala, and shrimp biryani.  It served all four of us and was inexpensive and it was delicious.

19.description: The best Indian/Pakistani food in the city, hands down. This place does get packed because of its great reputation, so be ready for that. The quality of the food more than makes up for the wait, though. I don't live in the neighborhood, so this is a hike for me, but it's well worth it. BYOB doesn't hurt either, and there's a liquor store nearby if you forget.

28.description: Service was SERIOUSLY lacking.  He didn't check back, didn't upsell... he just sat the check on the table & walked away.  Was hoping to find a nice little family run restaurant in my new neighborhood and this is not it.  The food was overpriced & bland.   Samosa's were dry, bland & grainy.  Curry Fish tasted of curry but otherwise bland & a small portion for $10.  Tandoori Chicken was so DRY!!!!!  Had 2 other dishes not worth mentioning.  SO disappointed!

45.description: One of my favorite Rogers Park locations! No frills, down to earth hole in the wall with delicious food. I order from here all the time and am NEVER disappointed. They don't deliver, but its worth the schlep to get it. Its right by the train so Its easy to get to and the staff is friendly. Its packed most nights with sit-in diners. I've yet to have a bad experience and recommend this restaurant to anyone and everyone! such a hidden north-side gem

33.description: Luzzat's very good. The menu isn't very big but what they do have is delicious. Chicken Vindaloo is especially amazing. Definitely a perfect option for RP locals who are a little further North of Devon.

43.description: My husband and I are absolutely obsessed with this place. You can't order a bad thing! We love the samosas and palak paneer the best! It's awesome for take out (fast and stays super hot) and a great little hole in the wall place to have a fine in dinner as well. And it's BYOB making it even more budget friendly than it all ready is!Don't let it's 'hole in the wall' feel deter you! It's part of its charm, and it's a family run business- one worth supporting!

2.description: My housemates and I were craving Indian food, and saw a ton of reviews claiming Luzzat had some of the best in town. So, we walked in on a rainy Friday night and were immediately seated - however, service was pretty slow. At one point, a pitcher of water was placed on our table, but we had to wait a good 10-15 minutes to get cups... That being said, the waiters were really fun and friendly (and gladly helped us get a group picture after dinner!). While our food was also a little slow to come out, it was worth the wait. I ordered the lamb biryani, and got a huge portion of spicy rice and the most tender lamb I've ever tasted. I got the medium spiciness and my nose was running, so I'm guessing the spiciest option would have been too much to handle. The bread was also delicious and came to us right out of the oven, but the timing wasn't the best. Overall, I loved the taste of everything I ordered and was happy with the amount of food I got for the price. I'll be back at some point, but definitely not if I'm in a hurry to get somewhere!

18.description: Terrible! I got half-way through my plate of really sub-par chicken saag (mostly shredded chicken) to find a RUBBERBAND!!!!! Really????!!!!!! So sick to my stomach! I will never go back!!!!!

41.description: This place is bloody good! Phenomenal Vindaloo. 4 stars since I have been their only once. Will add the next 1/2 star on my next visit based on their consistency and their biryani ;) Half star less since the shrimp was overcooked (I'm being harsh but I cannot stand overcooked shrimp)The lady who cooks is one of the kindest and most polite peeps I have ever come across.

52.description: As many have mentioned the service is spotty and slow.  If you are in a hurry don't eat here.  If you want to be served and dine at a more relaxed pace, this is the place for you.  It is BYOB so chill, have some wine and enjoy your spouse or friends.The food is excellent and can be made spicey. Some of the best Indian food I have ever had.

50.description: Wow, this was really good. The Jeera rice is amazing. I'd eat the largest plate they would bring me. The Samosas were so so. Vindaloo chicken was really good, very hot. Could not stop eating the sauce, oh my. Megan had the chana masala, that was good too. More tomatoes than I normally like but good flavor. Well worth the drive.

4.description: Curries are the ultimate comfort food, IMO. Poor reviews on Yelp be damned. I had the Aloo Baigan and the Lamb Vindaloo. Both were hella; perfectly savory and toothsome. I've had the leftovers in the fridge for a couple hours and keep going back for one...more...bite... (If you like heat, order the spicy or the level above it. The spicy is enough to warm you up and make your mouth tingle, but it's not in that "hurts so good" range which I love.)

6.description: Great little BYOB place in ropo! We get the vindaloo veggie for me and chicken for him. Yes we do want spicy( go spicier actually) ! Ignore that we seem too american lol . Second time in and we shall return I'm certain.

22.description: Luzzat is a place you go where no one knows your name and frankly doesn't care because they are on this planet to do one thing and one thing only: prepare and cook the BEST DARN INDIAN FOOD IN CHICAGO! Please don't expect excellent service or even clean tables. Luzzat is too busy feeding you a delicious meal that you'll be talking about for weeks. Half of the menu is vegetarian (which I normally don't solicit but here I love) and the other half allows you to order from a variety of proteins like chicken, lamb, and seafood. All dishes are rich and flavorful and go perfectly over a hot plate of rice. We usually order enough for leftovers because it sometimes tastes even better the next day. Don't forget that this place is BYOB and they're always happy to provide glasses and corkscrews if asked. Don't be fooled by the looks of this place (it's not fancy and the quintessential "hole in the wall" but trust me, it's the real deal!

15.description: Anyone who knows me, knows how much I love BYOB. Yep, I'm a girl who likes my beer, wine, and cocktails - pretty much any drink put in front of me. Now, being the considerate girl that I am, when going out on a date, I try to find spots that are BYOB to save the fella a little dinero. Why not save a few dollah bills on booze!?So I picked up a couple bottles from Lynfred and off we went to Luzzat. It's a hole in the wall type place in Rogers Park with really fantastic food! I had the chicken masala and asked for it super mild so my weak tastebuds wouldn't die. It still had quite a bit of spice and I went through water pretty quick but it was just the right amount of spice for me. The chicken was really moist and a good sized portion for $10.When we went the CC machine was down so had to grab cash a couple doors down. Our server was nice and on top of refilling our water and checking on us.They have many dishes that look great on the menu so I'm determined to go back. Free street parking is plentiful or it's right off the

57.description: been meaning to try this place forever and finally did.had the vindaloo lamb spicey, and it was very good.it comes with A LOT of sauce, which is nice, but i could have gone for a bit more lamb and potato, especially in proportion to the sauce.  anyway - i'll be back to try more things.  i got my food to go, but the small simple space is inviting enough to imagine myself there with a friend or a date and a bottle of wine

20.description: I ordered the butter chicken, with naan bread and a vegetable samosa. The main course was delicious but the bread was really gross. I'm a bread person and I was really let down by the naan here. yuck. Also, they forgot my samosa! Another letdown!

36.description: Omg. The best Indian food in Chicago. Awesome. Live this place.  Byob and enjoy. She cooks your order fresh.  This place is great.

14.description: *This is my third(and last) time eating here.If there was option on Yelp to immediately report a place to the Sanitation Department and eventually get it closed, through a star selection, that's what this place deserves.  We arrive at the restaurant and only one table had a lone customer at it eating and one waiting to order.  At first, I think "good, we'll be served fast and the food will be relatively quick".  I was ill prepared for what was to come in the next 30 minutes.  There was no "hello" or any greeting whatsoever.  I asked if we should order up at the counter or take a seat,  trying to give them an opportunity to clean off one of the three dirty tables so we can sit.  He led us to one of those and proceeded to remove the dirty dishes. He removed the dishes but failed to come back to clean off the table, something that in hindsight I'm glad he did not do(read further and you'll know why).  As I sat at the table, 2 takeout customers came in to pick up and were held up for what seemed to be no apparent reason whatsoever. I worked in the restaurant industry for a long time and immediately my restaurant "spidey senses" went off.  I knew then something wasn't right.  Eventually, one of them received the yogurt or tea(something in a cup to go) and they were able to get on their way.  All the while my table still hasn't been cleaned and neither has any of the other dirty ones.  The lady waiting to get her order taken seemed perplexed and eventually decided to leave(perhaps after she saw me point out to the friend I was dining with that there was a used soda can left and rice on our table still. More customers walked in and same lack of service was displayed. We ordered.  5 minutes later I decided I didn't want to eat at place didn't clean and sanitize the tables for customers but the guy behind the counter told me it was coming out in a bit.  SHOCKING!! since there was no food being cooked on the stove, even though there was 4 or 5 people in the back, none of which seemed interested in cleaning tables.  Then fears were realized. The ding sounds that I heard was food being heated in a microwave.  My food didn't taste bad, it just wasn't hot.  My friends dish on the other hand looked like it had been cooked a few days ago and reheated SEVERAL times. We ate, only because we were taught to never let food go to waste.  Someone else might have had it packed up and given it to a homeless person but that would also be wrong(given the quality of the food and sanitation of this place). We paid. As I waited to pay, I peeped in to the kitchen and saw things I have only seen at the worst places.  Gordon Ramsey would have a heart attack if he would have had this place on Kitchen Nightmares.  They were pouring newly made sauce in to a pot that looked like it had been there for days.  Old Dean's sour cream containers being used for storage of something but uncovered and also crusty.  Counters that had caked on flour, dirt and who knows what else.  Refrigerators meant for home use in a commercial kitchen.  Old soda coolers( 7UP sign on the side) being used for storage of what I hope is not raw food.  A rickety shopping cart in the middle of the kitchen.  Cooks wearing sandals. no one wearing gloves.  Dishwasher removing dishes from water that clearly had no to little soap in it (what about rinsing, explains why my plate wasn't squeaky). The cherry on top?  My friend pokes me in the arm and points for me to look toward the left. O...M...G! Grocery store spice packs stored in another salvaged. cooler.I should have walked out right there but I had already given the guy my credit card.As we walked out we looked at ourselves disappointed and wondering why the soda can at our table still hadn't been removed.  So, who knows what kind of water and cloth washing procedures they have, if any.  I'm sure glad they didn't use it on our table before our meal. The only thing they did right.

1.description: So, I have been walking around/checking out my new Hood of Residencewhen I came across East View Grocery.Now, I stopped here after I left public storage cause I needed Caffeine,so thought I'd pick up some Diet Coke.As I entered this pretty small grocery/convenience store It was very dark/dimin there and I thought maybe business wasn't too good and they didn't paythe Electric Bill..However, there was some light, Enough to see the typical conveniencestore type items, Cigarettes, Holy Crap! I'm so glad I never smoked thoseSuckers are expensive! Not sure if they have booze/beer, if they did I  wouldpurchase some of that! Only Miller Lite though!I saw some cookies and donuts at the checkout, they had some funky brand name on them so I didn't want to take a chance on any of that stuff..And I saw some Spaghetti-O's, yadda, yadda,Now, the good thing about this little store is that it is located very nearthe Jarvis Red Line Stop, and I suppose if you are having a nicotine fit thisplace may suit your needs.However, I wanted to say Thank You to all 11 of you who liked my checkin at East View Grocery yesterday because you all liked it more than I did.But, in all fairness I guess it works in a pinch...But not for much else...

0.description: I had to check out this little convenience store, because as I was eating in Luzzat next door, I watched as 20-30 people made their way in and out! I was so curious, so we stopped by after a tasty meal.East View is like your standard convenience store, but it's pretty tiny. There are 3 main aisles with not that much room to walk, and the shelves are all stocked. I appreciated how every item had a little orange price sticker, unless the price was already on the product (like my favorite 99 cent arizona green teas). Prices seemed fair. They had a pretty good variety of things, like house goods, snacks, frozen foods,, drinks, ice cream, etc. It's a nice little neighborhood shop, and is conveniently located close to the Jarvis el stop.

56.description: I walked in here with a friend one time. I wasn't really expecting much from this place, but was pretty impressed at the great service she got from the sales people. We were in and out with a bunch of things in very little time. They also had a little section with lots of ethinic/kosher products, which my friend told me were much more reasonably priced than the bigger grocers. And another bonus for this place was that they had their own little parking area as well.

29.description: I grew up in a Jewish household of Southerners. That is, they ate fried chicken on the sabbath. And bacon with their morning brunches. Good stuff. In that vein (the being-a-non-kosher-Jew one) I swore up and down that I'd never find a tastier hot dog that Vienna Beef's. Certainly not an all-beef Kosher dog. Then, at a friend's place, I tried a grilled-to-blistered hot dog from Romanian... and my world was turned upside down. Best. Hot dogs. Ever. And I'm dogmatic about this.Romanian Kosher Sausage Co. is a little old building in Rogers Park with ancient signage and practically no ambiance. Walk on in, though, and you're struck by the most astoundingly wonderful smell of smoke and spices. Friendly (albeit a little inefficient) employees. Incredibly wonderful food.Highly recommend their hot dogs (they have nitrate-free ones now too!), beef sticks (who doesn't love a high-sodium snack?), smoked turkey, and extra lean corned beef. Be prepared to pay a bit of a premium since this is all Glatt kosher.Parking is easy in their side lot with simple access to Touhy.

42.description: Who says the service is rude?  Everybody was really nice to us, including a grandmother/customer.  Everybody took their time and smiled as they explained the differences between meats, etc.The meat is great.  The tastiest tongue I've had.  What's nice is that, unlike sit-down delis, they don't make monster sandwiches that you can't finish eating and you can't afford. The sandwiches are just the right size.Yiddishkheit still lives here.

23.description: Great place to buy Kosher meats! A bit pricey, but you do get what you pay for.  The only reason that I gave it 4 stars is that it would be great if the store had at least one night to stay open late.  It's always closed by the time I would get home from work.  However, the hot dogs are the BEST you will taste EVER! Love this place!

47.description: Just like you remember from your Bubbe's house when you were a kid. The corned beef and pastrami will shame Manny's, Ada's, and The Bagel out of business. Delicious breads, and shelf staples that were in every Jewish mother's pantry. Like has been said, buy your bread and corned beef individually and make your own sandwiches--just buy them both here. The staff is warm and helpful and they look happy to see you when you walk in; whether you've been there once or 100 times. It's out of the way from most of the city, but oh-so-worth it to make the trip.

8.description: Delicious four dollar pastrami sandwich. To-go sandwiches are few and basic, but they're exactly what you want when you're in the mood for mustard and meat on rye or kaiser. Very affordable.I didn't purchase anything to take home, but they had a veritable Noah's Ark of red meat.Also, walking in there is a time warp and who doesn't love a good time warp.

31.description: There is no ambience here what so ever. This is as plain and simple as you can get a butcher shop. In fact, it is kind of cold and stark. Ahhhh, but what treasures it conceals!!!!I popped in on a cold and rainy day (as opposed to a dark and stormy night). I had heard the tales and I was determined to find out for myself, if they were true. What I fould was utterly delicious pastrami, tender tantalizing corned beef, flavorful, practically perfect hot dogs and fresh, creamy yummy chopped liver.  I also got some frozen kishke, which I haven't tried yet. Everything I tried was amazing (ok, so I wasn't nuts about the cole slaw, who cares?)I will be back again and again, I can feel it in my soul. To make things easier, they have a parking lot, so I am beyond thrilled. I just finished a pastrami sandwich, and all is right with the world.

34.description: I traveled to this place the morning of "the blizzard", to beat the snowstorm, [which i did!].  After finding great parking in there private lot, i walked into the store, which was simple, not so modern, and a bit dull looking.  It's not a big place, but there is a buzz from the workers, who seem like they know exactly what they are doing and are precise in running the store.  A jewish man came in and for a moment, i thought he was a rabbi, but wasn't sure.  He looked like he had come in many times before, which was true, because everyone knew him by name.  I almost wanted to ask questions about kosher meats, but he was in and out, so i continued looking at all the choices of meats.  A young lady behind the counter asked if i needed help, which i did, and i proceeded to ask a few questions.  This was my first experience buying kosher meats from a recognized place and i am not jewish, but appreciate how meat should be prepared for a variety of reasons.  She offered me a sample of pastrami and bologna, which took me by surprise, because both were simply delicious.  When asked for a sandwich, i couldn't resist, i knew this was going to be good, simple, fresh and kosher!  I read about the hot-dogs, so i stocked up and bought several packages.  I ended up buying a basket full load of meats, knowing this was a long haul from clear across the city, so i wanted to make it worth my while. When i got home, i made some hot dogs, and they were excellent. Three for three! I'm planning on making some chili with the beef packages and coming back for the "kishka?" and maybe some livers.  For me, it was worth the trip and boy am i glad i beat the 18 inches of snow!

16.description: We checked this place out after finding it on yelp-- my grandpa lives just five minutes away (and has for all thirty two years of my life) but I never knew it was here... It's a gem! It has such an old-world feeling. The cashier told me that it's the last kosher butcher/deli that makes its own meat in the Chicago area, and I'm so glad it's still around. We stockpiled beef bacon, salami, dogs, pastrami and corned beef to take back to Austin in our suitcase! Places like this just don't exist in Texas. Luckily some of the meat was available in vacuum packed packaging, so the whole suitcase didn't end up smelling like meaty-garlicky goodness, although I guess that wouldn't have been so bad. Best bacon ever.

13.description: There is none better. Hot Dogs that will have you converted. But true love and the best product is the salami. I take the salami home and let it hang until it is hard and then slice it thin and this is heaven. Come to the deli but watch the hours

11.description: There is no ambience here what so ever. This is as plain and simple as you can get a butcher shop. In fact, it is kind of cold and stark. Ahhhh, but what treasures it conceals!!!!I popped in on a cold and rainy day (as opposed to a dark and stormy night). I had heard the tales and I was determined to find out for myself, if they were true. What I fould was utterly delicious pastrami, tender tantalizing corned beef, flavorful, practically perfect hot dogs and fresh, creamy yummy chopped liver.  I also got some frozen kishke, which I haven't tried yet. Everything I tried was amazing (ok, so I wasn't nuts about the cole slaw, who cares?)I will be back again and again, I can feel it in my soul. To make things easier, they have a parking lot, so I am beyond thrilled. I just finished a pastrami sandwich, and all is right with the world.

39.description: Let me preface this by saying: I do not like hot dogs. I do not like corned beef. I do not like pastrami or salami or any other cold sliced meats. However, I LOVE the Kosher dogs here and always reserve a special place in my stomach for at least one when they are served at parties.Thank you, Romanian Kosher Sausage Co for restoring my faith in the deliciousness of meat in a casing.

37.description: I love Romanian Meat! Their salamis and Italian sausages are the best I have ever had. I tried many different types of kosher meat from all over and nothing compares to Romanian's meat. I know many people who come in from New York and stock up on Romanian.

0.description: This place is known around the world for their top notch meats. People in Israel and New York would constantly ask me about Romanian and if I can bring back some meats for them when I visited Chicago.You must try their Beef Sticks (aka Salami Sicks). Their Salami, Pastrami, Corned beef and chopped liver are my favorites. Veteran shoppers of this place by their Salami and Salami Sticks and hang them to dry.If you're a meat lover and appreciate people who love and care about their craft, this is the place for you. You will not be disappointed.

38.description: OK Living in Chicago my whole life, Ive passed this place a thousand times and didn't think about it til I had a craving for good pastrami. The Milk Pail, that used to be on Devon in Lincolnwood, used have great Pastrami and Corn Beef, they have since closed years ago. I Google "Pastrami" and Yelp shows me the Romanian Kosher Sausage Co. So I drove over and gave it a try. The woman behind the counter and I talk about Pastrami and she tells me they have the best and that I'll be back for more. And wouldn't you know it it, SHE WAS RIGHT,  IT WAS OUTSTANDING!! I ate a lb of Pastrami in 2 days. I'll be going back this week for 2 lbs. the Corn Beef was very good too. I always said if you're going to get Pastrami it has to be from a Kosher deli. They have found a customer for life.

51.description: Does anyone else love chopped liver as I do?  If so, you have got to get it from this place.  They were recently written about in the Chicago magazine, but I really found out about it thanks to some other yelpers.  Yummy yummy chopped liver!  The salami's pretty good, too.

27.description: This review is a long distance review, as I have never actually been to Romanian Kosher Sausage Co.  My dad travels on business to Chicago a few times a month and stops here to buy salami and beef fry.  When he knows I'm coming home for a visit from Atlanta to Ohio he stocks up so I can load up my cooler and bring it back with me to Atlanta.  I have never had better salami and the concept of beef fry is just amazing!  I don't eat pork, but to use beef fry and get the BLT type sandwich that is still kosher is the best!  I highly recommend this place for kosher meats!

32.description: This place has tons of great meats for sale and at a resonable price as well. I have lived next to Romanian Kosher Sausage Co. for almost 6 years and I have never gone in until today. I got a packaged of hotdogs and a pastrami sandwich. I can officially say that the pastrami sandwich is the best I have ever had. I'm glad I finally took the time to go here!

54.description: Their pastrami is great.  I mean, amazingly great.  Heeb Magazine rated it one of their favorite foods in the country.  The only problem is that if you want a sandwich, they give it to you on a little mushy piece of rye.  My advice:  get a half pound, take it home, and don't feel guilty about putting some swiss cheese on your sandwich.

48.description: Brisket to die for, kishke to make you swoon, kosher sausages to warm you heart, chopped liver like bubbe makes. You won't be sorry. When I work my way through the whole selection I will let you know.

44.description: The meat at this place is wonderful, and I will definitely go back.  Beware though when you buy the no-nitrate/no-nitrite hot dogs, as they are INDIVIDUALLY WRAPPED within the larger shrink-wrap.  There is no indication on the package that they are each covered in plastic, so I ended up heating up the hot dog and eating it with plastic!!  Normally hot dogs have a casing, so it wasn't odd to have a little chewiness on the outside, but something just wasn't right.  I called the store and they told me you have to remove it before eating.  Still not sure how to do that with frozen hot dogs though, but I'll try to slice it off with a knife next time I go to cook one.   Very tasty insides, but just don't eat the plastic!!

24.description: The hot dogs are better than candy! - That's what my 6 year old says.

7.description: I left Chicago with 2 salami's in my carryon luggage.  The TSA flagged my bag and went through it.  Upon finding the sausages, the agent laughed and said "Even if they have kosher sausages where you're going, I'll bet these are better."  They did the swab check then let me go.  So, listen up...Get a salami.  Take it home.  Hang it until it gets hard and shriveled. Slice it thin.  Enjoy.  Repeat.  Seriously, the house made salami and hot dogs here are the best of the best to be had across the country.  Rumor has it they can ship anywhere in the USA too!

49.description: Some of the best corned beef I have ever had.  Sliced then, very, very good taste.  Not dry at at all.  Very flavorful.  I would agree with the other review - buy yourself a 1/2 pound and make your own sandwich (on rye).  Or buy a pound and make yourself a sandwich for now and one for later.  I was pleasantly surprised at the breadth of the selection and the prices were pretty reasonable.  Its also worth noting that they have a parking lot (enter on Clark).

40.description: "The pastrami, corned beef, salami, turkey pastrami, and hot dogs are among the best I have ever encountered" *** UPDATE:  I had hot dogs for dinner tonight, and they were amazing.  Diced onion, yellow mustard, Detroit's finest buns. Tubular bliss, *** I went to Romanian for the first time this past weekend with a very knowledgeable friend and we ended up tasting a wide variety of their offerings. All were extremely delicious. I had some soft salami, hard salami, smoked turkey breast, hunter like sausages, a pastrami sandwich on a kaiser roll, cole slaw, and new pickles. The pastrami sandwich was very delicious, and at $3.50 a real bargain. The sandwich was very simple. Pastrami on one of those great hard crust kaiser rolls that you can only find in Chicago with only mustard as a condiment. Please don't ask for cheese. Its true kosher establishment. Later I tried a bite of a bagel sandwich that was made with a New York Bagel poppy seed bagel, Romanian turkey pastrami, soft salami, cole slaw, and Dijon mustard. What a heavenly combination. Also amazing is the hard salami. I had a few slices, and we decided that a kosher salami omelet would be a delicious breakfast creation. The store is in front of the manufacturing area, and the staff was very helpful and friendly. We spent a few minutes joking with cashier about the proper pronunciation of Rokeach. Good times indeed.

53.description: This is, without question, the best kosher butcher in Chicago.  They make their own kosher sausages and salamis on the premises, and they're really exceptional.  They also make their own corned beef briskets.  I get the garlic sausages (which are like kielbasa).  They also make their own kishka.  My mother tells me that they used to make authentic kishka (if you don't know what that means, then you probably don't want to).  This is no longer the case, and the kishka comes in a plastic, removable casing.  It's still very good.Kosher meat is expensive, but there are definitely some deals to be had here.  They run weekly specials that are often very good.  Also, they have bone-in ribeye steaks for only $7.99 a pound, which is several dollars cheaper than at any other kosher market.  The staff can be a bit abrupt, but Sharon at the cash register is always sunny, chatty and cheerful.

30.description: The pastrami sandwiches here are great value and the folks working here are all very nice.  Recommended.

46.description: Quality meat is something that's always worth the price, especially when you think--not too hard, let's not get queasy--about the alternatives from major grocery chains that you might subject your gut to. So naturally I wanted to check out Romanian, and was tickled with what I found: excellent corned beef for samiches, quality cuts of meat at not-unreasonable prices, and a genuine, friendly, and refreshingly ethnic atmosphere where even the odd tall shicksa's made welcome. I will probably end up revising this review to five stars as I haul home more meaty fare, but whether you keep kosher or not, you'll find the kind of good stuff you won't regret stocking the fridge with, and the act of visiting is, in itself, a treat.

1.description: Finally got in here and I had a great corned beef on rye.  It sure hit the spot on a cold winter's  day.   It was excellent!I will return to try some of the other items offered.  Unfortunately, there isn't anywhere to really sit and eat but there is off street parking which is very nice.Recommended!

55.description: I've been going to this butcher my whole life (mom would bring me with). As the previous reviewer says, the staff there are really great people. The meat is fantastic and if there's any cut of meat you don't see, ask for it and they'll order/prepare it for you (as long as it's Kosher!). Romanian is an old time butcher shop which is quite rare these days of giant grocery store. Check them out, you'll love it!

9.description: I did not like either the food (sampled a few things) or the service (extremely slow and indifferent) and left without buying anything.

26.description: If you are looking for fancy shopping carts, TV screens at the checkout lanes or even in store special newspapers you would be in the wrong store.But if you want to enjoy the BEST Corned Beef, Pastrami, and Kosher Sausage in the Midwest (I am from Milwaukee) take the time to stop at Romanian Kosher Sausage and shop. The food prep area is spotless and all the handling of the products being sold is handled as if it was being sold to royalty i.e.: You the Customer.I now know where my kosher meat stop will be when in the city of Chicago. You Chicago folks are fortunate to have a treasure like Romanian.

25.description: Great corned beef sandwich, also great hard salami.  Looking forward to trying their other meats.

12.description: I have participated in all the Hot Dog Wars in the tri-state area.  I have eaten at all the iconic dog houses around.NOTHINGcompares to a Romanian Polish on the grill served on a D'amato's bunTHE END.  PERIOD

21.description: The best salami, pastrami and hot dogs in the Chicagoland area. Meats are wonderful as well, I have had salami drying in my kitchen for 30+ years. No, not the same one. I rotate them every month. I buy 3 at a time so while 3 are curing, I am knawing on the hardest one. If our friends want to have a bbq, I will take time off and get 4 pounds of the most wonderful garlic franks ever. thank G-d for Romanian.

17.description: I grew up in a Jewish household of Southerners. That is, they ate fried chicken on the sabbath. And bacon with their morning brunches. Good stuff. In that vein (the being-a-non-kosher-Jew one) I swore up and down that I'd never find a tastier hot dog that Vienna Beef's. Certainly not an all-beef Kosher dog. Then, at a friend's place, I tried a grilled-to-blistered hot dog from Romanian... and my world was turned upside down. Best. Hot dogs. Ever. And I'm dogmatic about this.Romanian Kosher Sausage Co. is a little old building in Rogers Park with ancient signage and practically no ambiance. Walk on in, though, and you're struck by the most astoundingly wonderful smell of smoke and spices. Friendly (albeit a little inefficient) employees. Incredibly wonderful food.Highly recommend their hot dogs (they have nitrate-free ones now too!), beef sticks (who doesn't love a high-sodium snack?), smoked turkey, and extra lean corned beef. Be prepared to pay a bit of a premium since this is all Glatt kosher.Parking is easy in their side lot with simple access to Touhy.

10.description: LOVE this place. Garlic hot dogs are amazing. Everything is great here.

5.description: Until you've eaten from this butcher you've NEVER eaten meat.The food is incredible. The dogs require no toppings after being cooked. Everything is so flavorful. Grab as much as you can because their hours are weird but well worth the trip!

3.description: The staff behind the counter is usually unpleasant in appearance.  A couple of them are particularly rude if they see you are not one of their kind.  The meat served here isn't anything special, either.  Being Kosher is one thing, but tasting great is something the food here does not do very well.  You're better off shopping elsewhere or at your local grocery store for better service and quality of meat.

35.description: I have participated in all the Hot Dog Wars in the tri-state area.  I have eaten at all the iconic dog houses around.NOTHINGcompares to a Romanian Polish on the grill served on a D'amato's bunTHE END.  PERIOD

19.description: Selection of meats is very good. Lots of kosher options and deli type cuts.

28.description: Flat out...  I challenge anyone to find better chopped liver.  This applies to their hot dogs, salami, pastrami and corned beef.  I have friends in NYC who ask me to ship them hot dogs and chopped liver. When they share it with their other New Yorker friends the get requests to ship more and more.  I just want to see Anthony Bourdain and Andrew Zimmer try the chopped liver...  sorry Tony,  Barney Greengrass'  chopped liver has got nothing on Romanian!

45.description: Romanian has the best quality kosher cured meats available in my 40 years of experience. Some frozen things are available, and some bakery goods (mostly from Queen Esther if I recall correctly). There are eleventy-seven tzedaka boxes available for your mitzvic satisfaction.NOTE: Romanian is a deli, not a restaurant. Take a number, buy your stuff, leave. There's no sitting down.

33.description: Excellent pastrami, salami and hot dogs.  Excited to try the brisket.   Thanks yelpers, definitely a great place to go. With parking.Also, they sell great kaiser rolls up front and everyone was really nice.

43.description: if you complain about the somewhat-gruff service, you're missing the point.   you come here for the best non-italian deli meat in chicago, bar none.  the sandwiches are unreasonably low-priced - remember, this is kosher meat we're talking about here, and a pastrami sandwich (on rye bread from tel-aviv kosher bakery) costs $5 less than you'd pay at, say, frances' deli.  besides, if you come here once a week, as i do, the gruff service gets positively chummy.

2.description: I am a 68 year old Gentile that has been enjoying the Salamis, Beef Sticks and Hot dogs since 1976, when I lived in Chicago. I moved to So Cal in early 1980s and have been putting Romanian products in my luggage on my bi-annual trips to Chicago. I found out several years ago that Romanian had started shipping Salamis and Beef Sticks so I satisfied my Kosher meat jones via parcel post. I have a couple of sons who are hooked on Romanian products and a couple of times a year they get a delivery from Clark St. Getting ready to place my Holiday order for me and the boys. I love this place.David S Long Beach CA

18.description: Flat out...  I challenge anyone to find better chopped liver.  This applies to their hot dogs, salami, pastrami and corned beef.  I have friends in NYC who ask me to ship them hot dogs and chopped liver. When they share it with their other New Yorker friends the get requests to ship more and more.  I just want to see Anthony Bourdain and Andrew Zimmer try the chopped liver...  sorry Tony,  Barney Greengrass'  chopped liver has got nothing on Romanian!

41.description: For years I have been hearing about the Romanian from my neighbors and always see signs at the Hungarian advertising that they have "Romanian Sausages and Salami."  I wound up hear due to the shortage of larger kosher turkeys for Thanksgiving.  Apparently the process for making kosher turkeys (something to do with salt) makes poultry much more juicy and tasty- many cooking shows now recommend a kosher turkey for thanksgiving now.  The Romanian was the only place I could find that would reserve a kosher turkey over 12 lbs.  They were pricier than the Hungarian, Jewel or Trader Joe's but the price was well worth it.  This year's turkey was the best I have ever had and unlike the Hungarian you won't be left plucking out feathers with a pliers.As everything looked great I wound up with the best pastrami I have ever had- moist and flavorful.  I also got a few of their large hot dogs which were the best hot dogs ever and trust me I've been to all of the great hot dog places except hot dough's (I'm not waiting an hour for a hot dog).    I'm waiting to cut open the hard salami once I finish the turkey.  This place is pretty much a butcher and don't expect any ambiance.  The service was a bit lacking as well but based on food alone its fantastic.

52.description: I love all their meat products, especially the pastrami.  I also looooooooooooove their kishke.  It's the only kishke I have found that approximates the stuff that Kaufman's used to sell, Sarah's Kishke.  Of course, Sarah's Kishke was stuffed into a natural casing and Romanian's is in plastic but I guess that's progress, right? Anyhow, it's so much better than that awful Best's Kosher kishke, crumbly, not gluey, and full of that wonderful flavor of beef fat!  They also make a pareve kishke that kicks ass! It almost tastes like their regular kishke... maybe they made a mistake in labeling?I admit I haven't been back here for a few years, when I found that the Highland Park Jewel carried the kishke, hotdogs and salami.  I'm only giving 4 stars because I found service lacking when I did come here, but maybe it's improved since then.

50.description: Great meat.I'm still working on tasting thier entire selection.

4.description: Food is still excellent. Taking away a star for subpar customer service. Several times I've tried to go only to find the store closed with no notice on the webpage or in the window. Call before you go. Also, they should have a system where you can prepay if you're purchasing 20+items. It is frustrating to have to wait 10 min to checkout when someone is purchasing hundreds of items and I have 2 items. Why can't a second cashier open?

6.description: Romanian Kosher has been family owned and operated for years by the nicest people who provide the best service and quality of Kosher food that you will find. Some may tell you to head northwest towards Hungarian Kosher in Skokie. They will tell you about how Hungarian has better prices and is a fully stocked kosher grocery store; however, Hungarian's products are not only subpar, but they are not even in the same realm as Romanian. Romanian is dedicated to beef, meat, poultry, and the like. They are committed to providing quality product, and the price reflects that quality.  Whether you're in to get yourself some beef sticks, garlic hot dogs, or kishke for that latest batch of cholent, this place is the mecca for all kosher carnivorous fare.

22.description: Close your eyes and walk in. Ignore the boxes in the windows. Ask questions....everyone there has the answers and are willing and ready to educate you. Chopped liver like nobody's business. Just go, trust me.

15.description: "The pastrami, corned beef, salami, turkey pastrami, and hot dogs are among the best I have ever encountered" *** UPDATE:  I had hot dogs for dinner tonight, and they were amazing.  Diced onion, yellow mustard, Detroit's finest buns. Tubular bliss, *** I went to Romanian for the first time this past weekend with a very knowledgeable friend and we ended up tasting a wide variety of their offerings. All were extremely delicious. I had some soft salami, hard salami, smoked turkey breast, hunter like sausages, a pastrami sandwich on a kaiser roll, cole slaw, and new pickles. The pastrami sandwich was very delicious, and at $3.50 a real bargain. The sandwich was very simple. Pastrami on one of those great hard crust kaiser rolls that you can only find in Chicago with only mustard as a condiment. Please don't ask for cheese. Its true kosher establishment. Later I tried a bite of a bagel sandwich that was made with a New York Bagel poppy seed bagel, Romanian turkey pastrami, soft salami, cole slaw, and Dijon mustard. What a heavenly combination. Also amazing is the hard salami. I had a few slices, and we decided that a kosher salami omelet would be a delicious breakfast creation. The store is in front of the manufacturing area, and the staff was very helpful and friendly. We spent a few minutes joking with cashier about the proper pronunciation of Rokeach. Good times indeed.

20.description: All the way from the farthest West state of Hawaii, we got to enjoy RKS salami and hot dogs.  A dear friend of ours always shares with us when her family from Chicago comes to Hawaii and what do they bring with them - Salami and Hot Dogs - Yummy!  From Honolulu, Hawaii - just happy to write-up this review to let everyone know how much we enjoy the delicious Salami and Hot Dogs.  Aloha to all that reads this review and Mahalo to RKS for having such fine products that people will take it with them thousands of miles to share with their family and then to friends - Yay!

36.description: I learned about RKS a few years ago from a friend. Having grown up in Milwaukee, Wisconsin (Chicago's northernmost suburb *WINK*) my family would often travel south for the best Kosher this and that. I now live in Denver, Colorado. RKS is so good that once or twice a year I find a way to bring them to Denver. Even treif eaters have commented, when I've served these to them, that these are hands down the best dogs (and Polishs and Italians) they've ever had (Kosher or otherwise). The only complaint I have is RKS doesn't have a license to export out of the state. It would be so much easier on me if I could just pick up the phone and have them ship an order to me. Here's a quick tip--ask them if they will make some special preparation for you. Ex: foot-long-nitrate-free-Polishs or 1/10# Italians or some other exciting combination of size and fill. Now if only they came in a fat, cholesterol and calorie free variety, I might just consider giving up all other food.

14.description: Awesome awesome meat. That's all. Go there.

58.description: I've been living in Chicago for over four years and Giordano's is always delicious. This Roger's Park location seems to cater to the college students. They slice the pizza like the deep dish and I've always had it cut in squares. This was the least of my concerns because it doesn't taste like the ones on Belmont or Montrose. I ordered a large thin crust chicken pizza. It didn't have the same quality taste like Chicago pizza. Also, the crust seems to be more chewy than the other locations. I could be wrong but why should a Chicago pizza place cater to some non-Chicagoans. It doesn't make sense. If they don't like the pizza then maybe they should go to Pizza Hut or Domino's. Next time I might try the deep dish because they can't change the way they make it or I might try J.B. Alberto's on Morse.

56.description: Slipped through the cracks. I am a lazy reviewer. I just plain forgot. I do not know why. I have a horrible memory. There are too many pizza places in Chicago. I have no idea, am making no other excuses. Who knows why I never got around to reviewing Giordano's before now? Whatever the reason, they are a dependable, if not cheap, Chicago pizza chain. I know what I am getting each and every time I order from them. I never eat in, just pick up the phone and dial. My N&N love the thin crust. It hits the spot for both of these picky kids. The deep dish is a good value, will last for D-a-y-s until you are so sick of pizza you never want to eat it again. Never a problem but delivery can be a bit slow on busy nights. Nothing surprising!
